        ğŸŸ¢ğŸ‘†â¨‚â®mhÄgacch + i + mhÄ{516}gacchimhÄagacchimhÄ, gacchimha, agacchimha
        ğŸ”µğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€â®Äa + gacch + Ä{519}agacchÄgacchÄ, agacchittha, gacchittha
        ğŸ”µğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚â®Å«a + gacch + Å«{519}agacchÅ«gacchÅ«
        ğŸ”µğŸ¤˜â¨€â®segacch + i + se{516}gacchiseagacchise
        ğŸ”µğŸ¤˜â¨‚â®vhaá¹gacch + i + vhaá¹{516}gacchivhaá¹agacchivhaá¹
        ğŸ”µğŸ‘†â¨€â®aá¹gacch + aá¹gacchaá¹agacchaá¹, agaccha, gaccha
        ğŸ”µğŸ‘†â¨‚â®mhegacch + i + mhe{516}gacchimheagacchimhe
        ğŸŸ¢ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€â­ssatigacch + i + ssati{516}gacchissati
        ğŸŸ¢ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚â­ssantigacch + i + ssanti{516}gacchissantigacchissare
        ğŸŸ¢ğŸ¤˜â¨€â­ssasigacch + i + ssasi{516}gacchissasi
        ğŸŸ¢ğŸ¤˜â¨‚â­ssathagacch + i + ssatha{516}gacchissatha
        ğŸŸ¢ğŸ‘†â¨€â­ssÄmigacch + i + ssÄmi{516}gacchissÄmi
        ğŸŸ¢ğŸ‘†â¨‚â­ssÄmagacch + i + ssÄma{516}gacchissÄma
        ğŸ”µğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€â­ssategacch + i + ssate{516}gacchissategacchissare
        ğŸ”µğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚â­ssantegacch + i + ssante{516}gacchissante
        ğŸ”µğŸ¤˜â¨€â­ssasegacch + i + ssase{516}gacchissase
        ğŸ”µğŸ¤˜â¨‚â­ssavhegacch + i + ssavhe{516}gacchissavhe
        ğŸ”µğŸ‘†â¨€â­ssaá¹gacch + i + ssaá¹{516}gacchissaá¹
        ğŸ”µğŸ‘†â¨‚â­ssÄmhegacch + i + ssÄmhe{516}gacchissÄmhe
        ğŸŸ¢ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€â­ssÄgacch + i + ssÄ{516}gacchissÄagacchissÄ, agacchissa, gacchissa
        ğŸŸ¢ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚â­ssaá¹sugacch + i + ssaá¹su{516}gacchissaá¹suagacchissaá¹su
        ğŸŸ¢ğŸ¤˜â¨€â­ssegacch + i + ssase{516}gacchissaseagacchissase, agacchissasa, gacchissasa {517}
        ğŸŸ¢ğŸ¤˜â¨‚â­ssathagacch + i + ssatha{516}gacchissathaagacchissatha
        ğŸŸ¢ğŸ‘†â¨€â­ssaá¹gacch + i + ssaá¹{516}gacchissaá¹agacchissaá¹
        ğŸŸ¢ğŸ‘†â¨‚â­ssÄmhÄgacch + i + ssÄmhÄ{516}gacchissÄmhÄagacchissÄmhÄ, agacchissÄmha, gacchissÄmha
        ğŸ”µğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€â­ssatagacch + i + ssata{516}gacchissataagacchissata
        ğŸ”µğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚â­ssiá¹sugacch + i + ssiá¹su{516}gacchissiá¹suagacchissiá¹su
        ğŸ”µğŸ¤˜â¨€â­ssasegacch + i + ssase{516}gacchissaseagacchissase
        ğŸ”µğŸ¤˜â¨‚â­ssavhegacch + i + ssavhe{516}gacchissavheagacchissavhe
        ğŸ”µğŸ‘†â¨€â­ssaá¹gacch + i + ssaá¹{516}gacchissaá¹agacchissaá¹
        ğŸ”µğŸ‘†â¨‚â­ssÄmhasegacch + i + ssÄmhase{516}gacchissÄmhaseagacchissÄmhase

        Note that some of the terminations are the same so in practice we will need to distinguish which tense is being used from context. Note also the irregular forms, particularly the aorist ones. The irregular aorists tend to be more commonly used than the regular forms. This is so prevalent other grammar books such as MoggalÄá¹‡a VyÄkaraá¹‡a and RÅ«pasiddhi created rules to accomodate them.

        Voices

        Like Sanskrit, Pali supports 3 different ways of expressing sentences, based on the “voice”:

        1. the active voice (kattu) {444}-{452}
        2. the passive voice (kamma)
        3. the impersonal voice (bhÄva)

        However, in Pali literature, bhÄva (middle, or impersonal, voice) is seldom used, probably because most of the literature is based on the Buddha (or a disciple) “speaking” to a group of monks, which has then been transformed into a structure suitable for memorisation and chanting.

        ğŸ”´ Passive verb endings VattamÄnÄ Vibhatti {440}-{443}

        A passive verb is created by using the attanopada (ğŸ”µ) endings together with an infix of ya in between the root and the ending.

        Note that passive verbs can only be formed based on roots that can be expressed in a “passive” (kamma) sense - some roots can only result into “active” verbs and cannot be transformed this way.

        Example transformation (based on the root paca (to cook)):

        paca + ya + te {440}
        â†’ paca + y(cc)a + te {441}
        â†’ paccate (“is cooked”)

        The full set of attanopada (ğŸ”µ) endings of in the present tense vattamÄna (â–¶ï¸) across the 3 persons and plurality:

        voicenumberpersontenseendingtransformationresult
        ğŸ”´ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€â–¶ï¸tepaca + y(cc)a + tepaccate
        ğŸ”´ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚â–¶ï¸antepaca + y(cc)a + antepaccante
        ğŸ”´ğŸ¤˜â¨€â–¶ï¸sepaca + y(cc)a + sepaccase
        ğŸ”´ğŸ¤˜â¨‚â–¶ï¸vhepaca + y(cc)a + vhepaccavhe
        ğŸ”´ğŸ‘†â¨€â–¶ï¸epacca + y(cc)a + epacce
        ğŸ”´ğŸ‘†â¨‚â–¶ï¸mhepaccca + y(cc)a + Ä + mhepaccÄmhe

        Because the middle voice is seldom used, rule {518} allows these verbs to be retransformed into “reversed” parassapada (ğŸŸ¢) endings:

        voicenumberpersontenseendingtransformationresult
        ğŸ”´ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€â–¶ï¸tipaccate + tipaccati
        ğŸ”´ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚â–¶ï¸antipaccante + antipaccanti
        ğŸ”´ğŸ¤˜â¨€â–¶ï¸sipaccase + sipaccasi
        ğŸ”´ğŸ¤˜â¨‚â–¶ï¸thapaccavhe + thapaccatha
        ğŸ”´ğŸ‘†â¨€â–¶ï¸mipacce + Ä + mipaccÄmi
        ğŸ”´ğŸ‘†â¨‚â–¶ï¸mapaccÄmhe + Ä + mapaccÄma

        Typically we would use the parassapada (ğŸŸ¢) endings for passive verbs.

        Other examples (using different rules):

        kara (“to do”)
        â†’ kara + ya + te {440}
        â†’ kara + Ä« + ya + te {442}
        â†’ kara + Ä« + ya + te {521}
        â†’ karÄ«yate (“is done”)

        vaá¸ha (“to grow”)
        â†’ vaá¸ha + ya + te {440}
        â†’ vaá¸ha + ya(á¸á¸ha) + te {443}
        â†’ vuá¸á¸hate (“is grown”)

        ğŸŸ  Causative verbs

        There are two types of causative verbs:

        1. Causative verb in the active voice
        2. Causative verb in the passive voice

        There 4 typical causative affixes (kÄrita) used to construct causative verbs {438}:

        • á¹‡e
        • á¹‡aya
        • á¹‡Äpe
        • á¹‡Äpaya

        Just like for tadhikka noun affixes, the á¹‡ is typically elided when joined to a root, leaving the remaining letters. {523}

        Various vowel gradation transformations may also take place when joining the affix to the noun as per rule {483}.

        Example transformation (based on the root paca (to cook)) and the causative affix á¹‡e:

        paca + á¹‡e + ti {438}
        paca + á¹‡e + ti {521}
        â†’ pac + á¹‡e + ti {523}
        â†’ pa(Ä)c + e + ti {483}
        â†’ pÄceti ("(he) causes to cook”)

        ğŸŸ  Causative (active) verbs {438}

        The full set of causative versions of the vattamÄna (â–¶ï¸) forms of the root paca (to cook) using parassapada (ğŸŸ¢) endings:

        voicenumberpersontenseendingcausativetransformationresultirregular forms
        ğŸŸ ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€â–¶ï¸tiá¹‡epa(Ä)ca + á¹‡e + tipÄceti
        ğŸŸ ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€â–¶ï¸tiá¹‡ayapa(Ä)ca + á¹‡aya + tipÄcayati
        ğŸŸ ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€â–¶ï¸tiá¹‡Äpepa(Ä)ca + á¹‡Äpe + tipÄcÄpetipacÄpeti
        ğŸŸ ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€â–¶ï¸tiá¹‡Äpayapa(Ä)ca + á¹‡Äpaya + tipÄcÄpayatipacÄpayati
        ğŸŸ ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚â–¶ï¸antiá¹‡epa(Ä)ca + á¹‡e + antipÄcenti
        ğŸŸ ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚â–¶ï¸antiá¹‡ayapa(Ä)ca + á¹‡aya + antipÄcayanti
        ğŸŸ ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚â–¶ï¸antiá¹‡Äpepa(Ä)ca + á¹‡Äpe + antipÄcÄpentipacÄpenti
        ğŸŸ ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚â–¶ï¸antiá¹‡Äpayapa(Ä)ca + á¹‡Äpaya + antipÄcÄpayantipacÄpayanti
        ğŸŸ ğŸ¤˜â¨€â–¶ï¸siá¹‡epa(Ä)ca + á¹‡e + sipÄcesi
        ğŸŸ ğŸ¤˜â¨€â–¶ï¸siá¹‡ayapa(Ä)ca + á¹‡aya + sipÄcayasi
        ğŸŸ ğŸ¤˜â¨€â–¶ï¸siá¹‡Äpepa(Ä)ca + á¹‡Äpe + sipÄcÄpesipacÄpesi
        ğŸŸ ğŸ¤˜â¨€â–¶ï¸siá¹‡Äpayapa(Ä)ca + á¹‡Äpaya + sipÄcÄpayasipacÄpayasi
        ğŸŸ ğŸ¤˜â¨‚â–¶ï¸thaá¹‡epa(Ä)ca + á¹‡e + thapÄcetha
        ğŸŸ ğŸ¤˜â¨‚â–¶ï¸thaá¹‡ayapa(Ä)ca + á¹‡aya + thapÄcayatha
        ğŸŸ ğŸ¤˜â¨‚â–¶ï¸thaá¹‡Äpepa(Ä)ca + á¹‡Äpe + thapÄcÄpethapacÄpetha
        ğŸŸ ğŸ¤˜â¨‚â–¶ï¸thaá¹‡Äpayapa(Ä)ca + á¹‡Äpaya + thapÄcÄpayathapacÄpayatha
        ğŸŸ ğŸ‘†â¨€â–¶ï¸miá¹‡epa(Ä)ca + á¹‡e + mipÄcemi
        ğŸŸ ğŸ‘†â¨€â–¶ï¸miá¹‡ayapa(Ä)ca + á¹‡aya + mipÄcayami
        ğŸŸ ğŸ‘†â¨€â–¶ï¸miá¹‡Äpepa(Ä)ca + á¹‡Äpe + mipÄcÄpemipacÄpemi
        ğŸŸ ğŸ‘†â¨€â–¶ï¸miá¹‡Äpayapa(Ä)ca + á¹‡Äpaya + mipÄcÄpayamipacÄpayÄmi
        ğŸŸ ğŸ‘†â¨‚â–¶ï¸maá¹‡epa(Ä)ca + á¹‡e + mapÄcema
        ğŸŸ ğŸ‘†â¨‚â–¶ï¸maá¹‡ayapa(Ä)ca + á¹‡aya + mapÄcayama
        ğŸŸ ğŸ‘†â¨‚â–¶ï¸maá¹‡Äpepa(Ä)ca + á¹‡Äpe + mapÄcÄpemapacÄpema
        ğŸŸ ğŸ‘†â¨‚â–¶ï¸maá¹‡Äpayapa(Ä)ca + á¹‡Äpaya + mapÄcÄpayamapacÄpayÄma

        Note: not all forms of the above are encountered in Pali literature - they represent the full theoretical set of causative forms that can be generated.

        ğŸŸ ğŸ”´ Causative passive verbs

        It is also possible to construct causative verbs in the passive voice, just by adding the passive ya affix after the causative affix. The á¹‡aya and á¹‡Äpaya causative affixes are rarely used in the passive voice.

        Example transformation (based on the root paca (to cook)) and the causative affix á¹‡e and the passive affix ya:

        paca + á¹‡e + ya + ti {438,440}
        paca + á¹‡e + ya + ti {521}
        â†’ pac + á¹‡e + ya + ti {523}
        â†’ pa(Ä)c + ya + ti {483}
        â†’ pÄciyati (“is caused to be cooked”)

        voicenumberpersontenseendingcausativetransformationresult
        ğŸŸ ğŸ”´ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€â–¶ï¸tiá¹‡epa(Ä)ca + á¹‡e + i + ya + tipÄciyati
        ğŸŸ ğŸ”´ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€â–¶ï¸tiá¹‡Äpepa(Ä)ca + á¹‡Äpe + i + ya + tipÄcÄpiyati
        ğŸŸ ğŸ”´ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚â–¶ï¸antiá¹‡epa(Ä)ca + á¹‡e + i + ya + antipÄciyanti
        ğŸŸ ğŸ”´ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚â–¶ï¸antiá¹‡Äpepa(Ä)ca + á¹‡Äpe + i + ya + antipÄcÄpiyanti
        ğŸŸ ğŸ”´ğŸ¤˜â¨€â–¶ï¸siá¹‡epa(Ä)ca + á¹‡e + i + ya + sipÄciyasi
        ğŸŸ ğŸ”´ğŸ¤˜â¨€â–¶ï¸siá¹‡Äpepa(Ä)ca + á¹‡Äpe + i + ya + sipÄcÄpiyasi
        ğŸŸ ğŸ”´ğŸ¤˜â¨‚â–¶ï¸thaá¹‡epa(Ä)ca + á¹‡e + i + ya + thapÄciyatha
        ğŸŸ ğŸ”´ğŸ¤˜â¨‚â–¶ï¸thaá¹‡Äpepa(Ä)ca + á¹‡Äpe + i + ya + thapÄcÄpiyatha
        ğŸŸ ğŸ”´ğŸ‘†â¨€â–¶ï¸miá¹‡epa(Ä)ca + á¹‡e + i + ya + mipÄciyÄmi
        ğŸŸ ğŸ”´ğŸ‘†â¨€â–¶ï¸miá¹‡Äpepa(Ä)ca + á¹‡Äpe + i + ya + miPÄcÄpiyÄmi
        ğŸŸ ğŸ”´ğŸ‘†â¨‚â–¶ï¸maá¹‡epa(Ä)ca + á¹‡e + i + ya + mapÄciyÄma
        ğŸŸ ğŸ”´ğŸ‘†â¨‚â–¶ï¸maá¹‡Äpepa(Ä)ca + á¹‡Äpe + i + ya + mapÄcÄpiyÄma

        ÄkhyÄta examples

        â–¶ï¸ vattamÄna {414}

        (used to express actions or events which occur) at the present

        pÄá¹­aliputtaá¹ gacchati

        PÄá¹­aliputta (city) / he goes
        He goes to PÄá¹­aliputta.*

        sÄvatthiá¹ pavisati

        SÄvatthi (city) / he enters
        He enters SÄvatthi.

        â¹ piÃ±camÄ« {415}

        (used to express)

        • Äá¹‡atti (command)
        • ÄsÄ«sa (wish)

        at a non-specific time-frame mode (anuttakÄla)

        karotu kusalaá¹

        do / meritorious deed
        (Please) do meritorious deed.

        sukhaá¹ te hotu

        happiness / for you / be
        May you be happy.

        â¯ sattamÄ« {416}

        (to express)

        • anumati (permission)
        • parikappa (thought)

        at a non-specific time (anuttakÄla).

        tvaá¹ gaccheyyÄsi you / can go You can go.

        kimaâ€™haá¹ kareyyÄmi
        what I (kiá¹ + ahaá¹) / shoud do
        What should I do?

        ğŸ”„ parokkhÄ {417}

        Note

        paroâ€™kkhÄ = para + akkha
        beyond (ie. past) / physical senses

        (to be applied to express things happened in oneâ€™s absence, in a situation where the speaker is not a witness to) at a past time-frame mode (atÄ«ta - past).

        supine kilaâ€™mÄha

        in the dream / apparently / (he) said (kila + Äha)
        (He is supposed to have) said.

        evaá¹ kila porÄá¹‡Äâ€™hu

        thus / apparently / ancient sages / said (porÄá¹‡Ä + Ähu)
        Ancient sages are supposed to have said thus.

        Note

        kila is a nipÄta (particle) used in indirect hearsay where the speaker is uncertain of the truthfulness of what he heard or not a witness to the actual event occurred. Sometimes it means an asseveration or an emphasis.

        â†©ï¸ hiyyattanÄ« {418}

        (used to express events that took place) in past time (yesterday or before), either being witnessed or not witnessed (by the speaker)

        so agamÄ maggaá¹

        he / went / road
        He went along the road.

        te agamÅ« maggaá¹

        they / went / road
        They went along the road.

        Note

        mÄ is a nipÄta (particle) used to indicate negation, and is typically associated with verbs with hiyyattanÄ« endings, but the verb is not associated with the past (or any other) tense. {420}

        mÄ gamÄ

        do not / gone
        Do not go.

        mÄ vacÄ

        do not / said
        Do not say.

        â® ajjatanÄ« {419}

        (used to express things happened) in the near past starting from today, either being witnessed or not witnessed (by the speaker)

        so maggaá¹ agamÄ«

        he / road / gone
        He has (just) gone along the road.

        te maggaá¹ agamuá¹ they / road / gone
        They have (just) gone along the road.

        â­ bhavissanti {421}

        (to be used) in the (expression of) future

        so gacchissati, karissati

        he / will go / will do
        He will go, will do.

        te gacchissanti, karissanti

        they / will go / will do
        They will go, will do.

        ğŸ”€ kÄlÄtipatti {422}

        (to be used) in (the expression of) an action that was past (without being materialised due to adverse conditions or lack of the supporting causes)

        so ce taá¹ yÄnaá¹ alabhissÄ, agacchissÄ

        he / if / that / vehicle / should have got / might have gone already
        If he had gotten that vehicle, he might have gone already.

        te ce taá¹ yÄnaá¹ alabhissaá¹su, agacchissaá¹su

        they / if / that / vehicle / should have got / might have gone already
        If they had gotten that vehicle, they might have gone already.

        Example sentence constructions

        kattu-vÄcaka vÄkya (active voice sentences)

        An active voice sentence is a subject-principal sentence where KattÄ (the agent, doer subject) is much more dominant.

        1. kattu (subject) - Kathita KattÄ or `Vutta-kattÄ`` (predominant-subject) must be in 1st case (â‘ )
        2. kamma (object) - Akathita-kamma or Avutta-kamma (non-principal object) must be in 2nd case (â‘¡)
        3. The verb must be either in the parassapada termination (ğŸŸ¢) in most cases or in the attanopada termination (ğŸ”µ) with or without an affix of kattu sense. [Affixes of kamma sense such as ya, or kita affixes eg. tabba, ta, etc. cannot be used]
        4. The persons (subjects) and verbs should be concordant.
        Subject (â‘ )Object (â‘¡)VerbMeaning
        Purisoodanaá¹pacatiMan cooks the rice
        PurisÄodanaá¹pacantiMen cook the rice
        BuddhÄdhammaá¹desentiBuddha teach the Dhamma
        Tvaá¹odanaá¹pacasiYou cook the rice
        Tumheodanaá¹pacathaYou (plural) cook the rice
        Ahaá¹odanaá¹pacÄmiI cook the rice
        Mayaá¹odanaá¹pacÄmaWe cook the rice

        Kamma-vÄcaka VÄkya (passive voice sentences)

        A passive voice sentence is a object-principal sentence where the Kamma (the thing being done, the object) is more visibly dominant by being in the 1st case (â‘ ).

        The rules in a passive voice sentence are:

        1. kamma (object) - Kathita Kamma or Vutta-kamma (predominant-object) must be in 1st case (â‘ )
        2. kattÄ (subject) - Akathita-kattÄ or an Avutta-kattÄ (non-principal subject) must be in 3nd case (â‘¢)
        3. The verb should be mainly in the attanopada termination (ğŸ”µ) or it can be in a reversed parassapada form (ğŸŸ¢) with an affix which has a Kamma-sense only. {440}-{443}.
        4. The object (not the subject!) and verb should be in agreement.
        Subject (â‘¢)Object (â‘ )VerbMeaning
        PurisenaodanopacÄ«yateThe rice is cooked by man
        PurisehiodanopacÄ«yateThe rice is cooked by men
        BuddhenadhammodesÄ«yateThe Dhamma is taught by Buddha
        RÄjenatvaá¹dÄ«yaseBy king, you are given
        RÄjenatumhedÄ«yavheBy king, you (plural) are given
        RaÃ±Ã±Äahaá¹dÄ«yeBy king, I am given
        RaÃ±Ã±Ämayaá¹dÄ«yÄmheBy king, we are given

        bhÄva (impersonal) middle voice sentences

        It’s like a passive voice sentence except the focus is purely on the action and does not focus on either the subject or object. Therefore the verb tends to be in â¨€ (ekavacana) ğŸ¤Ÿ (paá¹­hama purisa) form. If there is a subject, it can be (but not always) be in 3rd (â‘¢) or 6th case (â‘¥).

        Subject (â‘¢)VerbMeaning
        DevadattenabhÅ«yateDevadattaâ€™s being
        Pabbatenaá¹­hÄ«yateThe mountainâ€™s standing
        PurisenakathÄ«yateThe man’s speaking

        Causative sentences

        There are four integral parts in a causative sentence:

        1. Causative subject - Hetu-kattÄ (the prompter), or Payojaka-kattÄ (the mover)
        2. Subordinate Object - KÄrita-kamma (causative object)
        3. Root-object - dhÄtu-kamma, the object of the root which has direct connection/meaning to the root
        4. Causative verb

        If the root is a dual-kamma-indicative root (dvikammaka) such as nÄ« (to carry), duha (to milk), then there can be three objects.

        Causative Subject (â‘ )Subordinate Object (â‘¡)The root-object (â‘¡)Causative VerbMeaning
        Purisopurisaá¹odanaá¹pÄcetiMan causes the other man to cook the rice
        PurisÄpuriseodanaá¹pÄcentiMen cause the other men to cook the rice

        ğŸ”½ kibbidhÄna (kita-affixed nouns) {524}-{623}

        This is a class of words which are verbs transformed into “verb nouns” through the addition of suffixes.

        These “verb nouns” are nouns, and have noun vibhatti endings applied to them, but can function like verbs in a sentence, or as auxiliary verbs such as the absolutive (also called gerund), the present participle and past participle.

        verbal affixes

        useaffixrulevoiceliá¹…ga
        Verb or adjectivetabba{540}ğŸ”´ (sometimes ğŸ”µ)variable
        anÄ«ya{540}ğŸ”´ (sometimes ğŸ”µ)variable
        á¹‡ya{541}ğŸ”´ (sometimes ğŸ”µ)ğŸš» (sometimes variable)
        teyaby ca of {541}ğŸ”´ (sometimes ğŸ”µ)ğŸš» (sometimes variable)
        kha{560}ğŸ”´ (sometimes ğŸ”µ)ğŸš» (sometimes variable)
        ta{555} , {556}, {557}ğŸŸ¢ğŸ”´ğŸ”µvariable

        gerund or auxiliary verbs

        useaffixrulevoiceliá¹…ga
        to-infinitivetave{561}--
        tuá¹{561}, {562}, {563}--
        gerundtuna, tvÄna, tvÄ{564}no voice, but sense of “active”-
        Present participle or adjective or adverbmÄna, anta{565}ğŸŸ¢ (or ğŸ”´ with ya affix)variable

        Individual noun affixes

        All of these can be variable gender, even when a gender is specified in the following table.

        noaffixrulegender
        1á¹‡a{ 524, 528, 529}variable
        2a{525, 526, 527, 553}variable
        3á¹‡vu, tu, ÄvÄ«{527}ğŸš¹
        4kvi{530}ğŸš¹
        5ramma{531}ğŸš»ğŸš¹
        6á¹‡Ä«, tu, ÄvÄ«{532}ğŸš¹
        7yu{533, 553}variable
        8rÅ«{534, 535}ğŸš¹
        9á¹‡uka{536}ğŸš¹
        10ra{538}variable
        11ricca{542}ğŸš»
        12i{551}variable
        13ti{552, 553}ğŸšº
        14ririya{554}ğŸšº
        15tavantu, tÄvÄ«{555}ğŸš¹
        16ina{558, 559}ğŸš»ğŸš¹
        17ratthu{566}ğŸš¹
        18ritu{567}ğŸš¹
        19rÄtu{567}ğŸšº
        20tuka{569}ğŸš¹
        21ika{570}ğŸš¹

        Example

        Here is a worked through example of how a root transforms into a kita-affixed noun (from caja, using the á¹‡a affix):

        caja “to share generously”
        â†’ caja {521}
        â†’ caj + á¹‡a {529}
        â†’ cajá¹‡a (kÄrita) {621}
        â†’ cajá¹‡a {523}
        â†’ ca(Ä)ja (vuddhi) {483}
        â†’ cÄj(g)a {623}
        â†’ cÄga (noun) {601}
        â†’ cÄga + si (â¨€â‘ )
        â†’ cÄga + si(o) {104}
        â†’ cÄga + o {83}
        â†’ cÄgo (“charitable giving, sharing”)

        Here is another example based on budha (to know):

        budha “to know”
        â†’ budha {521}
        â†’ budh + ta {557}
        â†’ budh + ta(dha) {576}
        â†’ budh(d) + dha {611}
        â†’ buddha (noun) {601}
        â†’ buddha + si (â¨€â‘ )
        â†’ buddha + si(o) {104}
        â†’ buddha + o {83}
        â†’ buddho (“The one who knows truth, who awakened”)

        Given the complexity of the above rules, it’s probably better just to recognise the completed forms whenever you come across them, but try and recognise the affix and associated meaning if you can.

        â¬ uá¹‡Ädi (uá¹‡Ädi-affixed nouns) {624}-{673}

        These are also “verb nouns” that can behave like verbs or auxiliary verbs or future participles.

        The majority of uá¹‡Ädi-affixes, except some verbal affixes, are used mainly in the formation of individual nouns of varying genders.

        Examples:

        sama “to calm”
        â†’ sama + tha {628}
        â†’ samatha {601}
        â†’ samatha + si (â¨€â‘ )
        â†’ samatha + si(o) {104}
        â†’ samatha + o {83}
        â†’ samatho (“that which calms the mind, Samatha meditation”)

        gaha “to take”
        â†’ gaha {521}
        â†’ ga(e)ha {629}
        â†’ geha {601}
        â†’ geha + si(aá¹) {104}
        â†’ geha + aá¹ {219}
        â†’ gehaá¹ (“home”)

        sÄdhana

        The process of attaching either kita or uá¹‡Ädi affixes to create new words is called sÄdhana. Like kÄraka (the syntax of case or vibhatti endings), sÄdhana affixed words can be associated with specific usage meanings.

        sÄdhana-affixed word can be associated with a voice (kattu, kamma, bhÄva), in which case their usage can affect the “voice” of a sentence. This is especially true when sÄdhana-affixed word is used as a verb-noun, ie. it carries the “action” of a sentence.

        Example sentences of kattu sÄdhana-affixed words

        dÄnaá¹ dinno devadatto

        ğŸš»â¨€â‘¡(dÄnaá¹) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ (â¬(ta)(dinno) devadatto)
        alms / gave (past participle) / Devadatta
        Devadatta gave alms.

        kumaro antepuraá¹ gato

        ğŸš»â¨€â‘¡(antepuraá¹) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ (kumaro â¬(ta)(gato))
        King’s palace / prince / went (past participle)
        The prince went into the King’s palace.

        so bhagavÄ sayamâ€™pi cattÄri saccÄni buddho

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ (so bhagavÄ â¬(ta)(buddho)) âï¸(sayam api) ğŸš»â¨‚â‘¡(cattÄri saccÄni)
        that / BhagavÄ / understood (past participle) / by oneself / just / four / truths
        That BhagavÄ (Buddha) understood the four truths just by himself.

        Example sentences of kamma sÄdhana-affixed words

        buddhena dhammo desito

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¢(buddhena) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ (dhammo â¬(ta)(desito))
        by Buddha / dhamma / taught (past participle)
        The Dhamma is taught by the Buddha.

        bhotabbo odano bhavatÄ

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ (â¬(tabba)(bhotabbo) odano) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¢(bhavatÄ)
        eaten (future passive participle) / rice / Your Honourable
        That rice is to be eaten by Your Honourable.

        Example sentences of bhÄva sÄdhana-affixed words

        tassa gÄ«taá¹

        ğŸš»â¨€â‘¥(tassa) ğŸš»â¨€â‘ (ğŸ”½(ta)(gÄ«taá¹))
        of that person / sung (past participle)
        Sung of that person.

        sayitabbaá¹ bhavatÄ

        ğŸš»â¨€â‘ (â¬(tabba)(sayitabbaá¹)) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¢(bhavatÄ)
        eating (future passive particle) / by Your Honourable
        Eating by Your Honourable.

        sÄdhana associated meanings and usage

        The associated meanings are rather weak compared to case endings (vibhatti) and can sometimes have no significant role.

        associationexamplemeaningruleusage
        kattunÄyakothe leader (who leads){527}netÄ«â€™ti nÄyako
        kammakammaá¹work (which is being done){531}karÄ«yate tanâ€™ti kammaá¹
        bhÄvacÄgogenerosity (act of giving, sharing){529}cajate, cajanaá¹ vÄ cÄgo
        karaá¹‡avinayothe discipline (by which one is trained){527}vineti etenÄâ€™ti vinayo
        sampadÄnadÄnÄ«yothe recipient monk (to which alms should be given)databbo assÄâ€™ti dÄnÄ«yo
        apÄdÄnabhemothe fearsome object (from which people fear){627}bhÄyanti etasmÄâ€™ti bhemo
        adhikaraá¹‡aá¹­hÄnaá¹the place (where people stand){548}tiá¹­á¹­hanti tasminâ€™ti

        Exercise

        Our first exercise, and also a celebration for finishing this chapter, is to translate the Saraá¹‡attaya Kp 1 PTS 1. This is a very well known sutta commonly referred to as the Three Jewels (also known as the Triple Gem or Three Refuges) and traditionally recited by disciples of the Buddha as part of a ceremony by which one formally declares oneself a Buddhist.

        Buddhaá¹ saraá¹‡aá¹ gacchÄmi
        Dhammaá¹ saraá¹‡aá¹ gacchÄmi
        Saá¹…ghaá¹ saraá¹‡aá¹ gacchÄmi
        Dutiyampi buddhaá¹ saraá¹‡aá¹ gacchÄmi
        Dutiyampi dhammaá¹ saraá¹‡aá¹ gacchÄmi
        Dutiyampi saá¹…ghaá¹ saraá¹‡aá¹ gacchÄmi
        Tatiyampi buddhaá¹ saraá¹‡aá¹ gacchÄmi
        Tatiyampi dhammaá¹ saraá¹‡aá¹ gacchÄmi
        Tatiyampi saá¹…ghaá¹ saraá¹‡aá¹ gacchÄmi

        Let’s start by examining only the first line. Analysing each word by identifying the form of the vibhatti ending yields:

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¡(buddhaá¹ saraá¹‡aá¹) ğŸŸ¢â¨€ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(gacchÄmi)

        Note

        The notation used here is inspired by functional programming conventions. In mathematics, we refer to \(f(x)\) as the function \(f\) applying on the variable \(x\), so ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¡(x) means all words in x are in the 2nd case, singular (ekavacana) and pulliá¹…ga in gender. Similarly, ğŸŸ¢â¨€ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(y) means all words in y are present indicative (vattamÄna) active (parassapada) verbs in the singular (ekavacana), “first person” (in English, “third person”) form (paá¹­hama purisa).

        Translating each word into English yields:

        Buddha / refuge / (I) go

        Note that in Pali, all words in the same case refer to the same entity, so both “Buddha” and “refuge” refer to the same entity. In other words, the Buddha is the refuge and the refuge is the Buddha. In English, we can regard the equality as “Buddha as refuge”.

        So, rearranging the words into a more idiomatic English sentence, we get:

        I go to the Buddha as refuge.

        For the exercise, translate the remainder of the sutta. It’s okay to leave words like “dhamma” and “sangha” untranslated (and use non-accented characters) as these are well known terms to Buddhists.

        Answer

        I go to the Buddha as refuge.
        I go to the Dhamma as refuge.
        I go to the Sangha as refuge.
        For the second time too, I go to the Buddha as refuge.
        For the second time too, I go to the Dhamma as refuge.
        For the second time too, I go to the Sangha as refuge.
        For the third time too, I go to the Buddha as refuge.
        For the third time too, I go to the Dhamma as refuge.
        For the third time too, I go to the Sangha as refuge.

        Note that dutiyaá¹ƒ and tatiyaá¹ƒ are being used as nipÄta. piis a nipÄta meaning “too” or “also”.

        The sentence structure of this sutta can also be represented as a pseudo UML class diagram:

        classDiagram
  class sentence["dutiyampi/tatiyampi buddhaá¹ƒ/dhammaá¹ƒ/saá¹…ghaá¹ƒ saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gacchÄmi"] {
    <<vÄkya>>
    english((For the second/third time) I go to the Buddha/Dhamma/Sangha as refuge)
  }
  namespace saá¹…khyÄpÅ«raá¹‡a {
    class dutiyaá¹ƒ {
      <<nÄma>>
      â‘¡
      english(second time)
    }
    class tatiyaá¹ƒ {
      <<nÄma>>
      â‘¡
      english(third time)
    }
  }
  class pi {
    <<nipÄta>>
    english(too)
  }
  namespace saraá¹‡a {
    class buddhaá¹ƒ {
      <<nÄma>>
      ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¡
    }
    class dhammaá¹ƒ {
      <<nÄma>>
      ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¡
    }
    class saá¹…ghaá¹ƒ {
      <<nÄma>>
      ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¡
    }
  }
  class saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ {
    <<nÄma>>
     ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¡
    english(as refuge)
  }
  class gacchÄmi {
    <<ÄkhyÄta>>
     ğŸŸ¢â¨€ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸
    english(I go)
  }
  sentence *-- dutiyaá¹ƒ
  sentence *-- tatiyaá¹ƒ
  sentence *-- pi
  sentence *-- buddhaá¹ƒ : kamma
  sentence *-- dhammaá¹ƒ : kamma
  sentence *-- saá¹…ghaá¹ƒ : kamma
  sentence *-- saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ : kamma
  sentence *-- gacchÄmi: kiriya
  buddhaá¹ƒ .. saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ
  dhammaá¹ƒ .. saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ
  saá¹…ghaá¹ƒ .. saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ

        We can also model the successive actions as a pseudo UML sequence diagram:

        sequenceDiagram
participant ahaá¹ƒ as (ahaá¹ƒ)
participant buddhaá¹ƒ
participant dhammaá¹ƒ
participant saá¹…ghaá¹ƒ
  loop (paá¹­hama), dutiyampi, tatiyampi
    ahaá¹ƒ ->> buddhaá¹ƒ : gacchÄmi
    buddhaá¹ƒ ->> saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ : (hoti)
    ahaá¹ƒ ->> dhammaá¹ƒ : gacchÄmi
    dhammaá¹ƒ ->> saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ : (hoti)
    ahaá¹ƒ ->> saá¹…ghaá¹ƒ : gacchÄmi
    saá¹…ghaá¹ƒ ->> saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ : (hoti)
  end

        Finally, the different states of the refuges can be modelled as a pseudo UML state diagram:

        stateDiagram-v2
  state fork_state <<fork>>
  state join_state <<join>>
  [*] --> fork_state : gacchÄmi
  fork_state --> buddhaá¹ƒ
  fork_state --> dhammaá¹ƒ
  fork_state --> saá¹…ghaá¹ƒ
  buddhaá¹ƒ --> join_state
  dhammaá¹ƒ --> join_state
  saá¹…ghaá¹ƒ --> join_state
  join_state --> saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ
  saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ --> fork_state : dutiyampi, tatiyampi

        Conclusion

        Congratulations on finishing this chapter! It is compact and dense, and not every feature of Pali explained here will sink in initially. It may be worthwhile revisiting this chapter from time to time to check your understanding as you progress in your journey in learning Pali.

        The good news is you now know enough of the basics of Pali to start reading the Tipiá¹­aka with the aid of a good dictionary, and looking up every word as you go along. You may encounter sentences that you can’t interpret very well, but that’s okay. Leave it for now, and study the next chapters, which will help you build confidence and skill in your ability to analyse sentences and deduce the correct meaning.

        Remember, the sentences in the Tipiá¹­aka are often repetitive and used in similar forms again and again. They are intentionally structured this way to assist in memorisation and chanting. So, once you have learnt how to correctly interpret a complex sentence, you may encounter it again and again and reading will become easier and easier over time.

        Next Chapter

        2: kÄraka (word ending) meanings

        2.3 - 2: `kÄraka` (word ending) meanings

        Various meanings and usage-rules of word endings in sentences after vibhatti has been applied {271}-{315}
        Part of “A Beginner (Non-Linguist) Guide to Learning Pali”

        kÄraka means the “cause” or “participants” of actions, and the relationship between various words in a Pali sentence. The following are descriptions of various kÄraka categories, and the typical vibhatti endings that are applied to words belonging to those categories.

        2.3.1 - 2.1: apÄdÄna (Ablative)

        apÄdÄna words refer to the source from which it occurs and is generally translated as “from”. It is normally (but not always) associated with the fifth case (â‘¤) vibhatti endings. It is often referred to as “ablative” in English Pali grammar books.
        Part of “A Beginner (Non-Linguist) Guide to Learning Pali”

        The usage examples provided here are not exhaustive, other usages are possible.

        2.1.1 Place or source {271}

        • The place or source from which someone left or something originated
        • The source from which fear arises
        • The one from which one learns.

        Example

        gÄmÄ apenti munayo

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤(gÄmÄ) â¨‚(ğŸŸ¢ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(apenti) ğŸš¹â‘ (munayo))
        from village / depart / sages
        The sages depart from the village.

        Exercises

        Translate the following from Pali to English. Look up the words in a dictionary, perform necessary sandhi and compound word deconstruction, and take note of the vibhatti endings to deduce the meaning of the sentence.

        Hint

        You may find the Digital Pali Dictionary useful for looking up words, as well as doing the sandhi and compound word deconstruction.
        1. nagarÄ niggato rÄjÄ
        2. corÄ bhayaá¹ jÄyate
        3. Äcariyuâ€™pajjhÄyehi sikkhaá¹ gaá¹‡hÄti sisso

        Answers

        Note: please do the exercises first before checking the answers.

        1. nagarÄ niggato rÄjÄ

        ğŸš»â¨€â‘¤(nagarÄ) â¨€â‘ (ğŸ”½(ta)(niggato) ğŸš¹(rÄjÄ))
        from city / departed (past participle) / king
        The departed king [is] from the city.

        1. corÄ bhayaá¹ jÄyate

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤(corÄ) â¨€(ğŸš»â‘ (bhayaá¹) ğŸ”µğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(jÄyate))
        from thief / fear / arises
        Fear arises from the thief.

        1. Äcariyuâ€™pajjhÄyehi sikkhaá¹ gaá¹‡hÄti sisso

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤ğŸ†(Äcariya+upajjhÄya) ğŸšºâ¨€â‘¡(sikkhaá¹) â¨€(ğŸŸ¢ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(gaá¹‡hÄti) ğŸš¹â‘ (sisso))
        teacher and preceptor / lesson / takes / pupil
        The pupil takes lesson from the teacher/preceptor.

        2.1.2 With various words and prefixes {272}

        2.1.2.1 parÄ + ji

        • being defeated, to lose in a fight or the struggle

        buddhasmÄ parÄjenti aÃ±Ã±atitthiyÄ

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤(buddhasmÄ) â¨‚(ğŸŸ¢ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(parÄjenti) ğŸš¹â‘ (aÃ±Ã±atitthiyÄ))
        from Buddha / (are) defeated / (those) holding other views, heretics
        The heretics are defeated from (i.e. by) the Buddha.

        2.1.2.2 pa + bhÅ«

        • an initial originating source of a continuous occurrence

        himavatÄ pabhavanti paÃ±ca mahÄnadiyo

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤(himavatÄ) â¨‚(ğŸŸ¢ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(pabhavanti) ğŸšºâ‘ (paÃ±ca mahÄnadiyo))
        from the mount HimavantÄ / originate / five great rivers
        The five great rivers originate from the Himalayas.

        2.1.2.3 From noun

        This is the most common type of apÄdÄna.

        urasmÄ jÄto putto

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤(himavatÄ) â¨€ğŸš¹â‘ (ğŸ”½(ta)(jÄto) putto)
        from chest (womb) / (was) born / the son
        The son was born from chest (i.e. womb).

        2.1.2.4 Indeclinable affix to

        This affix has an ablative sense.

        ubhato sujÄto putto

        âï¸(ubhato) â¨€ğŸš¹â‘ (ğŸ”½(ta)(sujÄto) putto)
        from both sides / well-bred, well-born / the son
        The son was well-bred, well-born from both sides.

        2.1.2.5 From prefix

        Word is used in the context of some upasagga (prefixes)

        apa sÄlÄya Äyanti vÄá¹‡ijÄ

        ğŸ”¼(apa) ğŸšºâ¨€â‘¤(sÄlÄya) â¨‚(ğŸŸ¢ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(Äyanti) ğŸš¹â‘ (vÄá¹‡ijÄ))
        taking off, by avoiding / from the rest house / come / the traders
        The traders come by skirting (avoiding) from the rest-house.

        ghataâ€™massa telasmÄ pati dadÄti

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¡(ghataá¹) *ï¸âƒ£ğŸ¤ŸğŸš¹â¨€â‘£(assa) ğŸš»â¨€â‘¤(telasmÄ) ğŸ”¼(pati) ğŸŸ¢â¨€ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(dadÄti)
        ghee / to that person / from sesame oil / instead of / [he] gives
        He gives him ghee instead of sesame oil.

        2.1.2.6 Starting from …

        ito pakkhasmÄ vijjhati migaá¹ luddako

        âï¸(ito) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤(pakkhasmÄ) ğŸŸ¢â¨€ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(vijjhati) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¡(migaá¹) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ (luddako)
        from this day / from a fortnight (15 days) / shoots / deer / the hunter
        Starting from today within a fortnight, the hunter [will] shoot the deer.

        2.1.2.7 api (exception)

        The prefix api can mean “but” or “however”. Similarly, other words such as rahitÄ, rite, nÄnÄ, vinÄ with the sense of “except” can be associated with words with â‘¤,â‘¡ or â‘¢ endings to convey the meaning of “except for.”

        rahitÄ mÄtujÄ puÃ±Ã±aá¹ katvÄ dÄnaá¹ deti

        ğŸšºâ¨€â‘¤(rahitÄ mÄtujÄ) ğŸš»â¨€â‘¡(puÃ±Ã±aá¹) ğŸ”½(tvÄ)(katvÄ) ğŸš»â¨€â‘¡(dÄnaá¹) ğŸŸ¢â¨€ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(deti)
        except/abandoning son / meritorious deed / having done / alms / [he] gives
        Having done meritorious deed without son, he gives alms.

        Note the following variations (using â‘  or â‘¢ case endings) are also acceptable:

        rahitÄ mÄtujaá¹ puÃ±Ã±aá¹ katvÄ dÄnaá¹ deti rahitÄ mÄtujena puÃ±Ã±aá¹ katvÄ dÄnaá¹ deti

        2.1.2.8 From pronouns (sabbanÄma)

        yatoâ€™haá¹ bhagini ariyÄya jÄtiyÄ jÄto

        âï¸(yato) â¨€ğŸ‘†â‘ (ahaá¹) ğŸš»â¨€â“ª(bhagini) â¨€(ğŸšºâ‘¤(ariyÄya jÄtiyÄ) ğŸš¹ğŸ”½(ta)(jÄto))
        since the time when / I / sister / by noble birth / [was] born
        Sister, since I was born (by being enlightened).

        Exercises

        The great lakes originate from lake Anavatatta.

        1. aciravatiyÄ pabhavanti kunnadiyo

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤(aciravatiyÄ) â¨‚(ğŸŸ¢ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(pabhavanti) ğŸšºâ‘ (kunnadiyo))

        The small creeks originate from the river AciravatÄ«.

        1. bhÅ«mito niggato raso

        ğŸšºâ¨€â‘¤(bhÅ«mito) â¨€ğŸš¹â‘ (ğŸ”½(ta)(niggato) raso)
        from earth / came out / the taste (of fruit etc.)
        The taste came out from the earth.

        1. mÄtito sujÄto putto

        âï¸(mÄtito) â¨€ğŸš¹â‘ (ğŸ”½(ta)(sujÄto) putto)
        from motherâ€™s side / well-bred, well-born / the son
        The son was well-bred, well-born from motherâ€™s side.

        1. ubhato sujÄto putto

        âï¸(pitito) â¨€ğŸš¹â‘ (ğŸ”½(ta)(sujÄto) putto)
        from fatherâ€™s side / well-bred, well-born / the son
        The son was well-bred, well-born from fatherâ€™s side.

        1. Ä brahmalokÄ saddo abbhuggacchati

        ğŸ”¼(Ä) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤(brahmalokÄ) â¨€(ğŸš¹â‘ (saddo) ğŸŸ¢ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(abbhuggacchati))
        till, up to / the high heavens of BrahmÄ / the sound / rises up
        The sound (of applause) rises up to the high heavens of BrahmÄ.

        1. upari pabbatÄ devo vassati

        ğŸ”¼(upari) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤(pabbatÄ) â¨€(ğŸš¹â‘ (devo) ğŸŸ¢ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(vassati))

        The rain pours above the mountain.

        1. buddhasmÄ pati sÄriputto dhammadesanÄya bhikkhÅ« Älapati temÄsaá¹

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤(buddhasmÄ) ğŸ”¼(pati) â¨‚ğŸš¹â‘¡(bhikkhÅ«) â¨€(ğŸš¹â‘ (sÄriputto) ğŸšºâ‘£(dhammadesanÄya) ğŸŸ¢ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(Älapati)) â¨€ğŸš»â‘¡(temÄsaá¹)

        representing (from) Buddha, Venerable SÄriputta addresses the monks in order to teach Dhamma for three months.

        1. uppalaâ€™massa padumasmÄ pati dadÄti

        ğŸš»â¨€â‘¡(uppalaá¹) *ï¸âƒ£ğŸ¤ŸğŸš¹â¨€â‘£(assa) ğŸš»â¨€â‘¤(padumasmÄ) ğŸ”¼(pati) ğŸŸ¢â¨€ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(dadÄti)

        1. kanakaâ€™massa hiraÃ±Ã±asmÄ pati dadÄti

        1. kosÄ vijjhati kuÃ±jaraá¹

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤(kosÄ) ğŸŸ¢â¨€ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(vijjhati) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¡(kuÃ±jaraá¹)
        from a distance of a Kosa* / [he] shoots / the elephant
        [He] shoots the elephant from (a distance of) a kosa.
        *A kosa is a unit of measurement representing the distance a human voice could be heard from (roughly 3 km)

        1. mÄsasmÄ bhuÃ±jati bhojanaá¹

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤(mÄsasmÄ) ğŸŸ¢â¨€ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(bhuÃ±jati) ğŸš»â¨€â‘¡(bhojanaá¹)
        from a period of a month / [he] eats / food
        [He] eats food from (since) a month.

        1. rite saddhammÄ kuto sukhaá¹ labhati (saddhammaá¹, saddhammena)

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤(rite saddhammÄ) âï¸(kuto) ğŸš»â¨€â‘¡(sukhaá¹) ğŸŸ¢â¨€ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(labhati)
        except noble way of Dhamma / where? / happiness / alms / [one can] get
        Where (one) can get happiness without (except) the noble way of Dhamma?

        1. te bhikkhÅ« nÄnÄ kulÄ pabbajitÄ

        ğŸš¹â¨‚â‘ (*ï¸âƒ£ğŸ¤Ÿ(te) bhikkhÅ« ğŸ”½(ita)(pabbajitÄ)) ğŸš»â¨€â‘¤(âï¸(nÄnÄ) kulÄ)
        those monks / from various families and homes / came forth (become)
        Those monks became [monks] [after] leaving various families.

        1. vinÄ saddhammÄ natthaâ€™Ã±Ã±o koci nÄtho loke vijjati (saddhammaá¹, saddhammena)

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤(vinÄ saddhammÄ) âï¸(natthaâ€™Ã±Ã±o) âï¸(koci) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ (nÄtho) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¦(loke) ğŸŸ¢â¨€ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(vijjati)
        except noble way of Dhamma / no other / refuge/help / in the world / [there] is
        There is no other refuge/help in the world except the noble way of Dhamma.

        1. vinÄ buddhasmÄ natthaâ€™Ã±Ã±o koci nÄtho loke vijjati (buddhaá¹, buddhena)

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤(vinÄ buddhasmÄ) âï¸(natthaâ€™Ã±Ã±o) âï¸(koci) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ (nÄtho) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¦(loke) ğŸŸ¢â¨€ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(vijjati)
        except from Buddha / no other / refuge/help / in the world / [there] is
        There is no other refuge/help in the world except from Buddha.

        1. yato sarÄmi attÄnaá¹

        âï¸(yato) ğŸŸ¢â¨€ğŸ‘†â–¶ï¸(sarÄmi) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¡(attÄnaá¹)
        since / [I] remember / oneself
        Since or as far as I remember myself.

        1. yato pattoâ€™smi viÃ±Ã±utaá¹

        âï¸(yato) â¨€ğŸš¹â‘ (ğŸ”½(ta)(patto)) ğŸŸ¢â¨€ğŸ‘†â–¶ï¸(asmi) ğŸšºâ¨€â‘¡(viÃ±Ã±utaá¹)
        since / the one who attained / [I] am / to a state of being mature, wise
        Since [I] reach a state of being wise (capable of knowing right and wrong, mature adulthood).

        1. yatvÄâ€™dhikaraá¹‡aâ€™menaá¹ cakkhundriyaá¹ asaá¹vutaá¹ viharantaá¹ abhijjhÄ, domanassÄ pÄpakÄ akusalÄ dhammÄ anvÄâ€™saveyyuá¹

        âï¸(yatvÄâ€™dhikaraá¹‡aá¹) ğŸš»â¨€â‘ (*ï¸âƒ£ğŸ¤Ÿ(enaá¹) cakkhundriyaá¹ ğŸ”½(ta)(asaá¹vutaá¹) ğŸ”½(anta)(viharantaá¹)) â¨‚â‘ (ğŸšº(abhijjhÄ) ğŸš»(domanassÄ pÄpakÄ akusalÄ dhammÄ)) ğŸŸ¢â¨‚ğŸ¤Ÿâ¯(anvÄâ€™saveyyuá¹)
        for the reason which / to that (person) / the faculty of eye / without restraining / (to the one who is) living / desire / aversion / those which are bad / unwholesome / mental states / may repeatedly arise
        For (such a) reason of (casually) living without restraining oneâ€™s eye, bad, unwholesome mental states (such as) desire, and aversion etc., may repeatedly arise to (the mind of) that person.

        2.1.3 To protect or prevent from {273}

        Example

        kÄke rakkhanti taá¹‡á¸ulÄ

        â¨‚(ğŸš¹â‘¡(kÄke) ğŸŸ¢ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(rakkhanti)) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤(taá¹‡á¸ulÄ)
        crows / [people] prevent / from [snatching] rice
        [People] prevent crows from [eating] the rice.

        Exercises

        1. yavÄ paá¹­isedhenti gÄvo

        Answers

        1. yavÄ paá¹­isedhenti gÄvo

        ğŸš»â¨€â‘¤(yavÄ) ğŸŸ¢â¨‚ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(paá¹­isedhenti) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¡(gÄvo)
        from [eating] barley / [people] prevent / the cattle
        [People] prevent cattle from [eating] the barley.

        2.1.4 Hiding from {274}

        When one wishes not to be seen by someone, that person from which one wants to hide is an apÄdÄna.

        Example

        upajjhÄyÄ antaradhÄyati sisso

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤(upajjhÄyÄ) â¨€(ğŸŸ¢ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(antaradhÄyati) ğŸš¹â‘ (sisso))
        from preceptor (teacher) / hides / the pupil
        The pupil hides from the preceptor.

        Sometimes the â‘¦ case ending is used rather than â‘¤ in connection with a disappearance.

        jetavane antaradhÄyati bhagavÄ

        ğŸš»â¨€â‘¦(jetavane) â¨€(ğŸŸ¢ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(antaradhÄyati) ğŸš¹â‘ (bhagavÄ))
        at Jetavana temple / disappears / Buddha
        Lord Buddha disappears at Jetavana temple.

        Exercises

        1. mÄtarÄ ca pitarÄ ca antaradhÄyati putto

        Answers

        1. mÄtarÄ ca pitarÄ ca antaradhÄyati putto

        ğŸšºâ¨€â‘¤(mÄtarÄ) âï¸(ca) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤(pitarÄ) âï¸(ca) â¨€(ğŸŸ¢ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(antaradhÄyati) ğŸš¹â‘ (putto))
        from mother / also / from father / also / hides / son
        The son hides from mother and father also.

        2.1.5 Additional usage {275}

        Used for expressing measurement of distance, time, direction along with words such as dura (distant, far) or antika (near) or similar words.

        Also used for analytical comparison, abstinence, purity, release/freedom from, reason, arrested, result (from virtue) etc.

        2.1.5.1 dura (â€œdistant and farâ€)

        kÄ«va dÅ«ro ito naá¸·akÄragÄmo

        âï¸(kÄ«va) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ (dÅ«ro) âï¸(ito) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ (naá¸·akÄragÄmo)
        how much / far / from here / bamboo-crafterâ€™s village
        How far is from here to bamboo-crafterâ€™s village?

        Can also use with â‘  and â‘¢ vibhatti endings (eg. dÅ«raá¹, dÅ«rena)

        2.1.5.2 antika (â€œnearâ€)

        antikaá¹ gÄmÄ

        ğŸš¹â¨€(â‘ (antikaá¹) â‘¤(gÄmÄ))
        [is] near / from village
        [is] near village

        Can also use with â‘  and â‘¢ vibhatti endings (eg. gÄmaá¹, gÄmena)

        2.1.5.3 Measure of geographic distance

        ito mathurÄya catÅ«su yojanesu saá¹…kassaá¹ nÄma nagaraá¹ atthi, tattha bahÅ« janÄ vasanti

        âï¸(ito) ğŸšºâ¨€â‘¤(mathurÄya) ğŸš»â¨‚â‘¦(catÅ«su yojanesu) â¨€(ğŸš¹â‘ (saá¹…kassaá¹ nÄma nagaraá¹) ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(atthi)) âï¸(tattha) â¨‚(ğŸš¹â‘ (bahÅ« janÄ) ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(vasanti))
        from here / from city of “MathurÄ” / at 4 yojana (~20 km) / city named â€œSaá¹…kassaâ€ / [there] is / there / many / people / live
        At four “yojana” distance from MathurÄ, there is a city named “Saá¹…kassa”. Many people live there.

        2.1.5.4 Measure of time

        ito bhikkhave ekanavutikappe vipassÄ« nÄma bhagavÄ loke udapÄdi

        âï¸(ito) ğŸš¹â¨‚â“ª(bhikkhave) ğŸš»â¨‚â‘¦(ekanavutikappe) ğŸš»â¨‚â‘¦(loke) â¨€(ğŸš¹â‘ (vipassÄ« nÄma bhagavÄ) ğŸ¤Ÿâ®(udapÄdi))
        from here / monks! / at a time of 91 eons / in the world / Buddha named VipassÄ« / appeared
        Monks! at a time of 91 eons from now, the Buddha named â€œVipassÄ«â€, appeared in the world.

        2.1.5.5 Implied absolutive

        pÄsÄdÄ saá¹…kameyya

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤(pÄsÄdÄ) â¨€ğŸ¤ŸğŸ”€(saá¹…kameyya)
        from mansion or palace / (he should) move
        He should move from mansion.

        This implies previously he has moved (ascended) to mansion.

        pÄsÄdaá¹ abhiruhitvÄ

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¡(pÄsÄdaá¹) ğŸ”½(tvÄ)(abhiruhitvÄ)
        to the mansion or palace / having gone up
        Having gone up to mansion.

        2.1.5.6 Direction and physical points

        avicito yÄva upari bhavaggaâ€™mantare bahÅ« sattanikÄyÄ vasanti

        âï¸(avicito) âï¸(yÄva) âï¸(upari) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¡(bhavaggaá¹ƒ) âï¸(antare) â¨‚(ğŸš¹â‘ (bahÅ« sattanikÄyÄ) ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(vasanti))
        from lowest hell / up to / above / the highest heaven / in between / many diverse groups of living beings / live
        Many diverse groups of beings live in between from the lowest hell (underneath) to the highest heaven above.

        2.1.5.7 Comparison / distinction

        yato paá¹‡Ä«tataro vÄ visiá¹­á¹­hataro vÄ natthi

        âï¸(yato) â¨€(ğŸš¹â‘ (paá¹‡Ä«tataro) âï¸(vÄ) ğŸš¹â‘ (visiá¹­á¹­hataro) âï¸(vÄ) âï¸(na) ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(atthi))
        from which / the best / or / the most outstanding thing / or / no / [there] is
        There is nothing better or more outstanding [than the Dhamma].

        2.1.5.8 Abstinence

        gÄmadhammÄ vasaladhammÄ asaddhammÄ Ärati virati paá¹­ivirati

        â¨€(ğŸš¹â‘¤(gÄmadhammÄ vasaladhammÄ asaddhammÄ) ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(Ärati virati paá¹­ivirati))
        from the way of villagers / from impious way / from ignoble way / (mental) abstinence / (physical) abstinence / sustained abstinence

        pÄá¹‡ÄtipÄtÄ veramaá¹‡Ä«

        â¨€(ğŸš¹â‘¤(pÄá¹‡ÄtipÄtÄ) ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(veramaá¹‡Ä«))
        from killing / abstinence

        2.1.5.9 Purity

        lobhaniyehi dhammehi suddho asaá¹…saá¹­á¹­ho

        ğŸš¹â¨‚â‘¤(lobhaniyehi dhammehi) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ ğŸ”½(ta)(suddho asaá¹…saá¹­á¹­ho)
        from greed-causing / phenomenon / (is) pure / (is) dissociated
        It is pure and dissociated from greed-causing phenomenon.

        2.1.5.10 Freedom and release

        parimutto dukkhasmÄâ€™ti vadÄmi

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ ğŸ”½(ta)(parimutto) ğŸš»â¨‚â‘¤(dukkhasmÄ) âï¸(iti) ğŸ‘†â¨€â–¶ï¸(vadÄmi)
        is free / phenomenon / from suffering / (quote) / (I) say
        I say “It is freedom from suffering”.

        2.1.5.11 Reason

        kasmÄ hetunÄ

        ğŸš¹â¨‚â‘¤(kasmÄ hetunÄ)
        for what / reason
        for what reason, why?

        Similarly, can also use â‘¢ and â‘¥ vibhatti endings:

        ğŸš¹â¨‚â‘¢(kena hetunÄ)
        ğŸš¹â¨‚â‘¥(kissa hetunÄ)

        2.1.5.12 Dissociation

        vivitto pÄpakÄ dhammÄ

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ ğŸ”½(ta)(vivitto) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤(pÄpakÄ dhammÄ)
        is dissociated, being detached from / unwholesome / mental state
        Being detached from unwholesome mental state.

        2.1.5.13 Measurement

        dÄ«ghaso navavidatthiyo sugatavidatthiyÄ pamÄá¹‡ikÄ kÄretabbÄ. majjhimassa purisassa aá¸á¸ha-teá¸·asahatthÄ

        âï¸(dÄ«ghaso) ğŸšºâ¨‚â‘ (navavidatthiyo) ğŸšºâ¨€â‘¤(sugatavidatthiyÄ) ğŸšºâ¨‚â‘ (pamÄá¹‡ikÄ ğŸ”½(tabba)(kÄretabbÄ)) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¥(majjhimassa purisassa) ğŸš¹â¨‚â‘ (aá¸á¸ha-teá¸·asahatthÄ)
        by length / by Buddha’s vidatthi (length between outstretched thumb and little finger) measurements / measurement / should be made measured / of medium / of man / half / thirteen / measure of length (measure from elbow to extended little-finger tip)
        By measure of Buddhaâ€™s vidatthi measurement, nine vidatthi in length, half-thirteen feet by measure of a medium height man are to be measured.

        2.1.5.14 Before, previously

        pubbeâ€™va sambodhÄ

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¦(pubbe) âï¸(eva) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤(sambodhÄ)
        before, previously / only / from (the time of) enlightenment
        at the previous time from enlightenment (prior to enlightenment)

        2.1.5.15 To arrest

        satasmÄ bandho naro

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤(satasmÄ) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ (bandho naro)
        for hundred / arrested / man
        Man got arrested for a hundred.

        Can also use â‘¢ vibhatti ending:

        satena bandho naro raÃ±Ã±Ä iá¹‡atthena

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¢(satena) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ (bandho naro) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¢(raÃ±Ã±Ä) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¢(iá¹‡atthena)
        for hundred / arrested / man / by king / by reason of debt
        Man was arrested by king for reasons of (unpaid) debt of a hundred.

        2.1.5.16 Result or benefit

        extolling the result or benefit of a virtue or a specific quality (note â‘¢ vibhatti ending):

        puÃ±Ã±Äya sugatiá¹ yanti

        ğŸš»â¨€â‘¢(puÃ±Ã±Äya) ğŸšºâ¨€â‘ (sugatiá¹) ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚â–¶ï¸(yanti)
        by meritorious deed / to good destiny (re-birth). / (people) go
        People go to a good (destiny of) re-birth by virtue of meritorious deed.

        2.1.5.17 Questioning and Answering (of teachings)

        Used together without a tvÄ-gerund Kita verb:

        abhidhammÄ pucchanti

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤(abhidhammÄ) ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚â–¶ï¸(pucchanti)
        from abhidhamma / (they) ask
        They ask question from (i.e. regarding) Abhidhamma.

        Also used with â‘¡ and â‘¢ vibhatti endings:

        abhidhammaá¹ pucchanti
        abhidhammena pucchanti

        This implies they have previously listened to the Abhidhamma, and have a “standing” question to ask:

        abhidhammaá¹ sutvÄ
        abhidhamme á¹­hatvÄ

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¡(abhidhammaá¹) âï¸ğŸ”½(tvÄ)(sutvÄ) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¦(abhidhamme) âï¸ğŸ”½(tvÄ)(sutvÄ)
        abhidhamma / having listened / abhidhamma / standing (there as point of question)
        Having listened to Abhidhamma, having stood on Abhidhamma, …

        Also used with answering:

        abhidhammÄ pucchanti

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤(abhidhammÄ) ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚â–¶ï¸(kathayanti)
        from abhidhamma / (they) answer
        They answer question from (i.e. regarding) Abhidhamma.

        Some other words that can be used in this manner (replacing abhidhamma):

        • vinaya
        • suttÄ
        • geyyÄ (stanza)
        • gÄthÄya (verse)
        • veyyÄkaraá¹‡Ä (explanatory non-stanza discourses)
        • udÄnÄ (joyous utterances)
        • itivuttakÄ ((re-narrated) discourses)
        • jÄtakÄ (Buddhaâ€™s former life stories)
        • abbhutadhammÄ (inspirational discourses)
        • vedallÄ (joyous sayings)

        2.1.5.18 A little, a meagre amount

        thokÄ muccanti

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤(thokÄ) ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚â–¶ï¸(muccanti)
        from reasons of little (excuse) / (they) are free (from confinement)
        They are free by means of a little excuse.

        Some other words that can be used in this manner (replacing thokÄ):

        • appamattakÄ (from little amount. muccanti)
        • kicchÄ (from being weary)

        Also used with â‘¢ vibhatti ending:

        thokena muccanti

        2.1.5.19 Non-agent words indicative of obvious reason

        kammassa katattÄ upacitattÄ ussannattÄ vipulattÄ cakkhuviÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ uppannaá¹ hoti

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¥(kammassa) ğŸš»â¨€â‘¤(katattÄ upacitattÄ ussannattÄ vipulattÄ) ğŸš»â¨€â‘¤(cakkhuviÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ ğŸ”½(tÄ)(uppannaá¹)) ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€â–¶ï¸(hoti)
        of (good) kamma / for having done / for having collected / for having accumulated / for having increased / the eye-consciousness / act of arising / is
        For reasons of having done, for having collected, for having accumulated, for having increased the (good) kamma, the eye-consciousness arises.

        from here / of three months / on passing / (the Buddha) will expire
        On passing of three months from now, the Buddha will enter into parinibbÄna.

        1. pabbatÄ saá¹…kameyya. pabbataá¹ abhiruhitvÄ

        1. ÄsanÄ vuá¹­á¹­haheyya. Äsane nisÄ«ditvÄ

        1. yato khemaá¹ tato bhayaá¹

        from where / (it is) safe / from there / (it is) unsafe
        Where (it used to be) safe (before), is no longer safe.

        1. puratthimato dakkhiá¹‡ato pacchimato uttarato aggÄ« pajjalanti

        From East, South, West, North fires are aflame.

        1. yato assosuá¹ bhagavantaá¹

        âï¸(yato) â¨‚ğŸ¤Ÿâ®(assosuá¹) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¡(bhagavantaá¹)

        1. uddhaá¹ pÄdatalÄ adho kesamatthakÄ

        1. channavutÄ«naá¹ pÄsaá¹‡á¸Änaá¹ dhammÄnaá¹ pavaraá¹ yadidaá¹ sugatavinayo

        since / of ninety-six / impious / ideas / (is) the most excellent / that which is / the discipline of Buddha
        Of the ninety-six impious ideas, the discipline (teaching) of Buddha [is] the most excellent.

        1. mÄtito ca pitito ca suddho asaá¹…saá¹­á¹­ho anuâ€™pakuddho agarahito

        ğŸšºâ¨€â‘¥(mÄtito) âï¸(ca) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¥(pitito) âï¸(ca) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ ğŸ”½(ta)(suddho asaá¹…saá¹­á¹­ho anuâ€™pakuddho agarahito)
        from motherâ€™s side / and / from fatherâ€™s side / and / (is) pure / (is) not mixed (with other castes). / (is) not censured / (is) not reproached
        (He) is not to be censured nor to be reproached as he is pure and not racially mixed either from the motherâ€™s side or from the fatherâ€™s side.

        1. muttoâ€™smi mÄrabandhanÄ

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ ğŸ”½(ta)(mutto) ğŸ‘†â¨€â–¶ï¸(asmi) ğŸš»â¨‚â‘¤(mÄrabandhanÄ)
        free / (I) am / from MÄra’s bonds
        I am free from MÄra’s bonds.

        1. na te muccanti maccunÄ

        âï¸(na) *ï¸âƒ£ğŸ¤ŸğŸš¹â¨‚â‘ (te) ğŸ‘†â¨‚â–¶ï¸(muccanti) ğŸš»â¨‚â‘¤(maccunÄ)
        not / they / are free / from death
        They are not being free from death.

        1. kasmÄ nu tumhaá¹ daharÄ na mÄ«yare

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤(kasmÄ) âï¸(nu) *ï¸âƒ£ğŸ¤˜âš§â¨‚â‘¥(tumhaá¹) â¨‚(ğŸš¹â‘ (daharÄ) âï¸(na) ğŸ”µğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸(mÄ«yare))

        Why the young ones among you (in the family) do not die young?

        1. kasmÄ idheâ€™va maraá¹‡aá¹ bhavissati

        Why [my] death will be only here?

        1. vivicceâ€™va kÄmehi

        â¨€ğŸ¤˜â¹(vivicca) âï¸(eva) ğŸš¹â¨‚â‘¤(kÄmehi)

        Being detached from sensual pleasures only.

        1. vivicca akusalehi dhammehi

        â¨€ğŸ¤˜â¹(vivicca) ğŸš¹â¨‚â‘¤(akusalehi dhammehi)

        Being detached from unwholesome mental states.

        1. cÄgÄya vipulaá¹ dhanaá¹

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¢(cÄgÄya) ğŸš»â¨€â‘ (vipulaá¹ dhanaá¹)

        1. paÃ±Ã±Äya vimutti mano

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¢(paÃ±Ã±Äya) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ (vimutti mano)

        The mind is free by virtue of wisdom.

        1. issariyÄya janaá¹ rakkhati rÄjÄ

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¢(issariyÄya) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¡(janaá¹) ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€â–¶ï¸(rakkhati) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ (rÄjÄ)

        1. vinayÄ pucchanti. vinayaá¹ sutvÄ. vinaye á¹­hatvÄ

        ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¤(vinayÄ) ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚â–¶ï¸(pucchanti) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¡(vinayaá¹) âï¸ğŸ”½(tvÄ)(sutvÄ) ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¦(vinaye) âï¸ğŸ”½(tvÄ)(sutvÄ)

        Having listened to Vinaya, having stood on Vinaya, they ask question from (i.e. regarding) Vinaya.

        2.4 - 3: Awakening

        Translation of the bodhisutta Ud 1.1-1.3 PTS 1-3 Verses 1-3
        Part of “A Beginner (Non-Linguist) Guide to Learning Pali”

        Paá¹­hamabodhisutta

        Evaá¹ me sutaá¹â€” ekaá¹ samayaá¹ bhagavÄ uruvelÄyaá¹ viharati najjÄ neraÃ±jarÄya tÄ«re bodhirukkhamÅ«le paá¹­hamÄbhisambuddho. Tena kho pana samayena bhagavÄ sattÄhaá¹ ekapallaá¹…kena nisinno hoti vimuttisukhapaá¹­isaá¹vedÄ«. Atha kho bhagavÄ tassa sattÄhassa accayena tamhÄ samÄdhimhÄ vuá¹­á¹­hahitvÄ rattiyÄ paá¹­hamaá¹ yÄmaá¹ paá¹­iccasamuppÄdaá¹ anulomaá¹ sÄdhukaá¹ manasÄkÄsi:

        â€œIti imasmiá¹ sati idaá¹ hoti, imassuppÄdÄ idaá¹ uppajjati, yadidaá¹â€” avijjÄpaccayÄ saá¹…khÄrÄ, saá¹…khÄrapaccayÄ viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹, viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡apaccayÄ nÄmarÅ«paá¹, nÄmarÅ«papaccayÄ saá¸·Äyatanaá¹, saá¸·ÄyatanapaccayÄ phasso, phassapaccayÄ vedanÄ, vedanÄpaccayÄ taá¹‡hÄ, taá¹‡hÄpaccayÄ upÄdÄnaá¹, upÄdÄnapaccayÄ bhavo, bhavapaccayÄ jÄti, jÄtipaccayÄ jarÄmaraá¹‡aá¹ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupÄyÄsÄ sambhavanti. Evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo hotÄ«â€ti.

        Atha kho bhagavÄ etamatthaá¹ viditvÄ tÄyaá¹ velÄyaá¹ imaá¹ udÄnaá¹ udÄnesi:

        â€œYadÄ have pÄtubhavanti dhammÄ,
        Ä€tÄpino jhÄyato brÄhmaá¹‡assa;
        Athassa kaá¹…khÄ vapayanti sabbÄ,
        Yato pajÄnÄti sahetudhammanâ€ti.

        Dutiyabodhisutta

        Evaá¹ me sutaá¹â€” ekaá¹ samayaá¹ bhagavÄ uruvelÄyaá¹ viharati najjÄ neraÃ±jarÄya tÄ«re bodhirukkhamÅ«le paá¹­hamÄbhisambuddho. Tena kho pana samayena bhagavÄ sattÄhaá¹ ekapallaá¹…kena nisinno hoti vimuttisukhapaá¹­isaá¹vedÄ«. Atha kho bhagavÄ tassa sattÄhassa accayena tamhÄ samÄdhimhÄ vuá¹­á¹­hahitvÄ rattiyÄ majjhimaá¹ yÄmaá¹ paá¹­iccasamuppÄdaá¹ paá¹­ilomaá¹ sÄdhukaá¹ manasÄkÄsi:

        â€œIti imasmiá¹ asati idaá¹ na hoti, imassa nirodhÄ idaá¹ nirujjhati, yadidaá¹â€” avijjÄnirodhÄ saá¹…khÄranirodho, saá¹…khÄranirodhÄ viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡anirodho, viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡anirodhÄ nÄmarÅ«panirodho, nÄmarÅ«panirodhÄ saá¸·Äyatananirodho, saá¸·ÄyatananirodhÄ phassanirodho, phassanirodhÄ vedanÄnirodho, vedanÄnirodhÄ taá¹‡hÄnirodho, taá¹‡hÄnirodhÄ upÄdÄnanirodho, upÄdÄnanirodhÄ bhavanirodho, bhavanirodhÄ jÄtinirodho, jÄtinirodhÄ jarÄmaraá¹‡aá¹ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupÄyÄsÄ nirujjhanti. Evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hotÄ«â€ti.

        Atha kho bhagavÄ etamatthaá¹ viditvÄ tÄyaá¹ velÄyaá¹ imaá¹ udÄnaá¹ udÄnesi:

        â€œYadÄ have pÄtubhavanti dhammÄ,
        Ä€tÄpino jhÄyato brÄhmaá¹‡assa;
        Athassa kaá¹…khÄ vapayanti sabbÄ,
        Yato khayaá¹ paccayÄnaá¹ avedÄ«â€ti.

        Tatiyabodhisutta

        Evaá¹ me sutaá¹â€” ekaá¹ samayaá¹ bhagavÄ uruvelÄyaá¹ viharati najjÄ neraÃ±jarÄya tÄ«re bodhirukkhamÅ«le paá¹­hamÄbhisambuddho. Tena kho pana samayena bhagavÄ sattÄhaá¹ ekapallaá¹…kena nisinno hoti vimuttisukhapaá¹­isaá¹vedÄ«. Atha kho bhagavÄ tassa sattÄhassa accayena tamhÄ samÄdhimhÄ vuá¹­á¹­hahitvÄ rattiyÄ pacchimaá¹ yÄmaá¹ paá¹­iccasamuppÄdaá¹ anulomapaá¹­ilomaá¹ sÄdhukaá¹ manasÄkÄsi:

        â€œIti imasmiá¹ sati idaá¹ hoti, imassuppÄdÄ idaá¹ uppajjati, imasmiá¹ asati idaá¹ na hoti, imassa nirodhÄ idaá¹ nirujjhati; yadidaá¹â€” avijjÄpaccayÄ saá¹…khÄrÄ, saá¹…khÄrapaccayÄ viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹, viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡apaccayÄ nÄmarÅ«paá¹, nÄmarÅ«papaccayÄ saá¸·Äyatanaá¹, saá¸·ÄyatanapaccayÄ phasso, phassapaccayÄ vedanÄ, vedanÄpaccayÄ taá¹‡hÄ, taá¹‡hÄpaccayÄ upÄdÄnaá¹, upÄdÄnapaccayÄ bhavo, bhavapaccayÄ jÄti, jÄtipaccayÄ jarÄmaraá¹‡aá¹ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupÄyÄsÄ sambhavanti. Evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo hoti.

        AvijjÄya tveva asesavirÄganirodhÄ saá¹…khÄranirodho, saá¹…khÄranirodhÄ viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡anirodho, viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡anirodhÄ nÄmarÅ«panirodho, nÄmarÅ«panirodhÄ saá¸·Äyatananirodho, saá¸·ÄyatananirodhÄ phassanirodho, phassanirodhÄ vedanÄnirodho, vedanÄnirodhÄ taá¹‡hÄnirodho, taá¹‡hÄnirodhÄ upÄdÄnanirodho, upÄdÄnanirodhÄ bhavanirodho, bhavanirodhÄ jÄtinirodho, jÄtinirodhÄ jarÄmaraá¹‡aá¹ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupÄyÄsÄ nirujjhanti. Evametassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa nirodho hotÄ«â€ti.

        Atha kho bhagavÄ etamatthaá¹ viditvÄ tÄyaá¹ velÄyaá¹ imaá¹ udÄnaá¹ udÄnesi:

        â€œYadÄ have pÄtubhavanti dhammÄ,
        Ä€tÄpino jhÄyato brÄhmaá¹‡assa;
        VidhÅ«payaá¹ tiá¹­á¹­hati mÄrasenaá¹,
        SÅ«riyova obhÄsayamantalikkhanâ€ti.

        2.5 - A: Symbols and Glossary of Pali technical terms

        List of symbols used in this book and their meanings
        Part of “A Beginner (Non-Linguist) Guide to Learning Pali”
        symbolmeaningexplanation
        ğŸš¹pulliá¹…gamajor (masculine) gender
        ğŸš»napuá¹sakaliá¹…gaspecial (neuter) gender
        ğŸšºitthiliá¹…gaminor (feminine) gender
        â¨€ekavacanasingular
        â¨‚bahuvacanaplural
        ğŸŸ¢parassapada, kattuactive voice
        ğŸ”µattanopada, bhÄvamiddle voice - impersonal
        ğŸ”´kammapassive voice
        ğŸŸ kÄritacausative
        ğŸ¤Ÿpaá¹­hama purisafirst person, equivalent to ’third person’ in English
        ğŸ¤˜majjima purisamiddle person, equivalent to ‘second person’ in English
        ğŸ‘†uttama purisaprimary person, equivalent to ‘first person’ in English
        â“ªÄlapanavocative
        â‘ paá¹­hamÄfirst case (nominative)
        â‘¡dutiyÄsecond case (accusative)
        â‘¢tatiyÄthird case (instrumental)
        â‘£catutthÄ«fourth case (dative)
        â‘¤paÃ±camÄ«fifth case (ablative)
        â‘¥chaá¹­á¹­hÄ«sixth case (genitive)
        â‘¦sattamÄ«seventh case (locative)
        âï¸nipÄtaparticle
        ğŸ”¼upasaggaprefix
        ğŸ†samÄsacompound noun
        ğŸ”½taddhitaaffix
        *ï¸âƒ£sabbanÄmapronoun
        â–¶ï¸vattamÄnapresent
        â¹piÃ±camÄ«imperative
        â¯sattamÄ«potential
        ğŸ”„parokkhÄperfect
        â†©ï¸hiyyattanÄ«imperfect
        â®ajjatanÄ«aorist
        â­bhavissantifuture
        ğŸ”€kÄlÄtipatticonditional

        Phonological Terminology

        dÄ«gha
        long
        rassa
        short
        garuka

        lahuka
        metrically short
        sambaddha

        vavatthita
        disjoint utterance
        sithila

        nasal
        vimutta

        SymbolEnglishAá¹­á¹­hakathÄ
        â‘ nominativepaccatta

        Types of nominals

        • Technical Terms and Technique of the Pali and the Sanskrit Grammars, Mahesh A Deokar, Central Institute of Higher Tibetan Studies (2008)

        2.6 - B: The Pali Alphabet

        Concise summary of the romanised Pali Alphabet
        Part of “A Beginner (Non-Linguist) Guide to Learning Pali”

        Alphabet Order

        Pali consists of 8 vowels (sara) and 33 consonants (vyaÃ±jana), arranged in the following order (the letters in round brackets are unused in the dictionary):

        sara: a, Ä, i, Ä«, u, Å«
        kaá¹‡á¹­hatÄluja: e
        kaá¹‡á¹­hoá¹­á¹­haja: o
        niggahÄ«ta: (á¹ƒ1)
        kavagga: k, kh, g, gh, (á¹…)
        cavagga: c, ch, j, jh, Ã±
        á¹­avagga: á¹­, á¹­h, á¸, (á¸h), (á¹‡)
        tavagga: t, th, d, dh, n
        pavagga: p, ph, b, bh, m
        antaá¹­á¹­ha: y, r, l, (á¸·), (á¸·h)
        dantoá¹­á¹­haja: v
        sakÄra: s
        hakÄra: h

        Alphabet Groups

        Articulation PlacerassadÄ«ghakaá¹‡á¹­hatÄluja kaá¹‡á¹­hoá¹­á¹­hajaanunÄsikaaghosa sithilaaghosa dhanitaghosa sithilaghosa dhanitanÄsikaantaá¹­á¹­hahakÄrasakÄra
        kaá¹‡á¹­hajaaÄkkhgghá¹…h
        tÄlujaiÄ«ecchjjhÃ±y
        muá¸á¸hajaoá¹ƒá¹­á¹­há¸á¸há¹‡r á¸·
        dantajatthddhnv ls
        oá¹­á¹­hajauÅ«pphbbhm

        How to form sounds

        vaggaGroupSound
        kaá¹‡á¹­hajaGutturalspronounced in the throat
        tÄlujaPalatalspressing the tongue on the front-palate
        muá¸á¸hajaLinguals (Cerebrals, Retroflex)bringing the up-turned tip of the tongue in contact with the back of the palate
        dantajaDentalspronounced with the aid of the teeth
        oá¹­á¹­hajaLabialsformed by means of the lips
        hakÄraSpiranta strong aspirated breathing
        sakÄraSibilanthas a hissing sound
        anunÄsikaNasalnasal breathing found only after the short vowels: aá¹ƒ, iá¹ƒ, uá¹ƒ
        aghosaVoiceless (Surds, stops)hard, flat, and toneless
        ghosaVoiced (Sonants)soft and uttered with a checked tone
        dhanitaAspiratespronounced with a strong breathing or h sound added to them
        sithilaNonaspiratespronounced naturally, without effort and without the h sound
        nÄsikaNasalssounded through the nose
        antaá¹­á¹­haLiquids (Resonants, semi-vowels)readily combine with other consonants: (except, perhaps, á¸·)
        -Mutes (Nonsurds)not being readily pronounced without the aid of a vowel

        Pronunciation

        LetterPronunciation
        abut, cut
        Äart, father
        imill, pin
        Ä«bee, machine
        uput
        Å«cool, rule
        eten, fate
        ohot, note
        kkey, kite
        gget, good
        á¹…ring, singer
        cchurch, rich
        jjam, jug
        Ã±signor
        á¹­hat, not
        á¸good, hid
        á¹‡hint, now
        tthumb
        dthey
        nnow
        plip, put
        bbut, rib
        mhim, mind
        yyard, yes
        rrat, right
        llight, sell
        vvile, vine
        ssing, sit
        hhot, hut
        á¸·felt, light
        á¹ƒsing

        1. á¹ƒ (niggahÄ«ta) can be written Î·, á¹ or á¹ƒ ↩︎

        2.7 - C: Pali Grammar Specification

        A concise diagrammatic representation of Pali Grammar
        Part of “A Beginner (Non-Linguist) Guide to Learning Pali”

        This chapter presents a concise summary of the structure of Pali grammar and the technical terms used in KaccÄyana. It is structured using EBNF notation and presented as Syntax Diagrams (also known as “Railroad” diagrams).

        The Pali Alphabet or Orthography (saÃ±Ã±Ä)

        Phonemes {2}

        Pali is an oral language consisting of sounds, but can be transcribed in written form using a combination of phonemes. Overall, there are 41 phonemes, which are grouped as consonants and vowels. These phonemes can be rendered in various scripts, or using Roman letters.

        @startebnf
title Phonemes (akkharÄ)
phoneme = 33 * consonant (* byaÃ±janÄ *) | 8 * vowel (* sarÄ *);
@endebnf

        Vowels {3}-{5}

        The vowels can be short (1 mora in length) or long (2 morae). Some vowels can be short or long depending of circumstances.

        @startebnf
title Vowels (sarÄ)
vowel =
  short (* rassaá¹ƒ, light (lahu), one mora (mattÄ) in length  *) |
  long (* dÄ«ghaá¹ƒ, heavy (garu), two mattÄ in length *) |
  variable (* can be long or short *);
short = "a" | "i" | "u";
long = "Ä" | "Ä«" | "Å«";
variable = "e" | "o";
@endebnf

        Consonants {6}-{9}

        Consonants can be grouped.

        @startebnf
Title Consonants (byaÃ±janÄ)
consonant =
  25 * grouped (* vagga *) |
  7 * ungrouped (* avaggÄ *) |
  1 * niggahita (* niggahita *) ;
grouped =
  5 * ka_group (* kavagga, velar (guttural) *) |
  5 * ca_group (* cavagga, palatal *) |
  5 * dot_ta_group (* á¹­avagga, retroflex *) |
  5 * ta_group (* tavagga, dental *) |
  5 * pa_group (* pavagga, labial *) ;
ka_group = "ka" | "kha" | "ga" | "gha" | "á¹…a" ;
ca_group = "ca" | "cha" | "ja" | "jha" | "Ã±a" ;
dot_ta_group = "á¹­a" | "á¹­ha" | "á¸a" | "á¸ha" | "á¹‡a" ;
ta_group = "ta" | "tha" | "da" | "dha" | "na" ;
pa_group = "pa" | "pha" | "ba" | "bha" | "ma" ;
ungrouped = "ya" | "ra" | "la" | "va" | "sa" | "ha" | "á¸·a" ;
niggahita = "aá¹ƒ" ;
@endebnf

        Voicing

        The grouped consonants can be either voiced or unvoiced.

        @startebnf
Title Voicing
grouped =
  7 * voiceless (* aghosÄ *) |
  25 * voiced (* ghosÄ *) ;
voiceless = "ka" | "kha" | "ca" | "cha" | "á¹­a" | "á¹­ha" | "ta" | "tha" | "pa" | "pha" ;
voiced = "ga" | "gha" | "á¹…a" | "ja" | "jha" | "Ã±a" | "á¸a" | "á¸ha" | "á¹‡a" | "da" | "dha" | "na" | "ba" | "bha" | "ma" ;
@endebnf

        Sentence structure

        Pali text consist of sentences which contain one or more words. Words can be nouns, verbs, prefixes and particles. There is no strictly defined word order in sentences, but is proto-typically subject-object-verb.

        @startebnf
title Sentence Structure
text = {sentence (* vakyÄ *)};
sentence = {word (* padajÄti *)}- ;
sentence = ?subject?, ?object?, ?verb? ;
word =
  noun (* nÄma *) |
  verb (* ÄkhyÄta *) |
  prefix (* upasagga *) |
  particle (* nipÄta *) ;
@endebnf

        Nouns

        @startebnf
title Noun types
noun =
  substantive (* nÄmanÄma *) |
  adjective (* guá¹‡anÄma, visesana *) |
  pronoun (* sabbanÄma *) |
  numeral (* saá¹…khyÄ *) |
  complex_noun (* vutti *) ;
substantive =
  common (* sÄdhÄrananÄma *) |
  proper (* asÄdhÄrananÄma *) ;
@endebnf

        Nouns are constructed from a base, or stem. KaccÄyana refers to the nominal base as the liá¹…ga, but this word is also used to refer to the grammatical gender of nouns. liá¹…ga technically means defining “characteristic” or “attribute” and hence the term is appropriate for both, as the defining characteristic of a noun is the base together with the gender. Other words that can be used to represent the base are pÄá¹­ipadika or sadda.

        A fully formed noun-word is constructed by combining the base with optional prefixes, infixes, affixes and suffixes. The final suffix is the inflectional-ending and expresses the syntactic case (relationship of the noun to other parts of a sentence), number (singular or plural) and gender (masculine, feminine, or neuter).

        @startebnf
title Noun formation
noun =
  {prefix (* upasagga *)},
  {root (* dhÄtu *)}-,
  [infix (* Ägama *)],
  {affixes}- (* paccaya *) ;
affixes = 
  (primary_affix (* kitapaccaya *) |
  secondary_affix (* taddhitapaccaya *)),
  noun_ending (* vibhatti *) ;
noun_ending =
  gender (* liá¹…ga*),
  multiplicity (* vacana *),
  syntactic_case (* vibhatti *) ;
gender =
  ?ğŸš¹ masculine (pulliá¹…ga)? |
  ?ğŸšº feminine (itthiliá¹…ga)? |
  ?ğŸš» neuter (napuá¹ƒsakaliá¹…ga)? ;
multiplicity =
  ?â¨€ singular (ekavacana)? |
  ?â¨‚ plural (bahuvacana)? ;
syntactic_case = case0 | case1 | case2 | case3 | case4 | case5 | case6 | case7 ;
@endebnf

        Semantic cases

        Semantic cases (kÄraka) represent the relationship between words in a sentence (representing various participants) in the context of an action (verb). Pali has 7 different semantic cases, in addition to a vocative case which is sometimes denoted as an 8th case.

        There is a strong association between semantic cases and syntactic cases, but the association is not an equivalance as a semantic case can be represented by more than one syntactic case, and a syntactic case can be used to represent more than one semantic case.

        @startebnf
semantic_case =
  vocative (* Älapana *) | 
  nominative (* kattar, agent or "doer" of action *) |
  accussative (* kamma, object or "deed" of action *) |
  instrumental (* karaá¹‡a, means or implement of agent *) |
  dative (* sampadÄna, beneficiary of action *) |
  ablative (* apÄdÄna, source or cause of action *) |
  genitive (* sÄmi, owner of object *) |
  locative (* okÄsa, place of action *) ;
@endebnf

        Verbs

        Technically, verbs in Pali are finite verbs, conjugated by applying verb endings which represent the perspective and voice of the actor, multiplicity, and the mood/tense of the action.

        Infinitives, participles (past, present, future), absolutives and other forms of words considered as verbs in other languages are technically nouns in Pali - they are created by combining a verbal stem (root) with an affix (kita or kicca) and then inflected/declined by adding a noun ending.

        @startebnf
title Verb types
verb = Bhuvadi | Rudhadi | Divadi | Svadi | Kiyadi| Tanadi | Curadi;
voice_affixes = Kattupaccaya | Kammapaccaya | Bhavapaccaya | Hetukattupaccaya | Hetukammapaccaya;
@endebnf

        @startebnf
title Verb formation
verb =
  {prefix (* upasaggo *)},
  {root (* dhÄtu *)}-,
  [infix (* Ägamo *)],
  voice_affixes (* paccaya *),
  verb_ending (* vibhatti *) ;
verb_ending =
  case_relation (* kÄraka *),
  person (* purisa *),
  multiplicity (* vacana *),
  (tense (* kÄla *) | mood);
time =
  past |
  present |
  future ;
case_relation =
  ?Kattukaraka : Active voice? |
  ?Kammakaraka : passive? ;
person =
  third_person (* paá¹­hamapurisa *) |
  second_person (* majjhimapurisa*) |
  first_person (* uttamapurisa *) ;
multiplicity =
  ?â¨€ singular (ekavacanaá¹ƒ)? |
  ?â¨‚ plural (bahuvacanaá¹ƒ)? ;
voice =
  ?parassapada : active, action favours non-agent? |
  ?attanopada : reflective, action favours self/object?;
mood =
  ?paÃ±camÄ« : Imperative, command or wish? |
  ?sattamÄ« : Optative, permission or thought? |
  ?kÄlÄtipatti : Conditional, should have happened except for ...? ;
tense = 
  ?vattamÄnÄ : Present tense (paccupannakÄla)? |
  ?parokkhÄ : Perfect, actions completed that was not witnessed? |
  ?hÄ«yyattanÄ« : Imperfect, past action excluding today? |
  ?ajjattanÄ« : Aorist, past action completed today? |
  ?bhavissantÄ« : Future tense? ;
@endebnf

        Complex nouns

        Complex nouns include compounds, verbal derivatives (primary) and nominal derivatives (secondary).

        Derivatives are nouns formed by combining either a verbal or nominal stem with an affix, and then inflected/declined by applying noun endings.

        @startebnf
complex_noun =
  compound (* samÄsanÄma *) |
  noun_derivative (* taddhitanÄma *) |
  verb_derivative (* kitanÄma *) ;
compound = 
  ?avyayÄ«bhÄva : Adverbial? |
  ?kammadhÄraya : Apposidonal? |
  ?digu : Numerical? |
  ?tappurisa : Determinative? |
  ?bahubbÄ«hi : Relative? |
  ?dvandva : Copulative? ;
verb_derivative = verb_stem (* liá¹…ga *), primary_affix, noun_ending ;
noun_derivative = noun_stem (* liá¹…ga *), secondary_affix (* taddhita *), noun_ending ;
primary_affix = kita | kicca | unadi;
@endebnf

        Prefixes

        Prefixes can be used as words in a sentence (in which case they are indeclinable), or embedded in another word (in which case they act as prepositions and form part of the word).

        Particles

        @startebnf

(* avyaya *)
indeclinable = particle (* nipÄta *) | prefix (* upasagga *);
particle = conjunction | preposition | adverb | indeclinable ;
@endebnf

        References

        This appendix is drawn upon information provided in the following sources

        • KaccÄyana PÄli VyÄkaraá¹‡aá¹ (KaccÄyana PÄli Grammar), Vols I and II, A. Thitzana, Pariyatti Press (2018)
        • Technical Terms and Technique of the Pali and the Sanskrit Grammars, Mahesh A Deokar, Central Institute of Higher Tibetan Studies (2008)
        • RÅªPASIDDHI: A study of some aspects, Phramaha Sriporn Rachiwong, Department Of Sanskrit And Prakrit Languages, University Of Pune (1995)
        • PÄli Grammar and Grammarians from Buddhaghosa to Vajirabuddhi: A Survey, O.H. Pind, The Journal of the Pali Text Society, Vol. XXXI (2012), pp. 57â€“124
        • MÄ€GADHABHÄ€SÄ€ (PÄ€á¸¶I): A Compendious Grammar on the Language of PÄá¸·i Buddhism, A. Bhikkhu, SÄsanÄrakkha Buddhist Sanctuary (SBS), Revised 2nd Edition (2023)

        2.8 - D: `dhÄtu` (roots)

        A listing of Pali roots and conjugations
        Part of “A Beginner (Non-Linguist) Guide to Learning Pali”

        2.9 - E: `sandhi` Rules

        sandhi rules from KaccÄyana {12}-{51}
        Part of “A Beginner (Non-Linguist) Guide to Learning Pali”

        Key

        • â†’ = â€œbecomes,â€ â€œchanges into,â€ â€œresults in.â€ â¯ â†’ âˆ… = elision.
        • âˆ… â†’ = insertion.
        • / = â€œin the environment of.â€
          • = meeting.
        • # = word boundary.
        • [] = optionality (only after symbols).
        • (VÌ† ) = short vowel.
        • (VÌ„ ) = long vowel.
        • (C) = consonant.
        • (CC) = double consonant.

        â€œvowel â†’ (VÌ„ ) [usually] / __ vowel [same class]â€

        says that any vowel (vowel) in the environment before another vowel (/ __ vowel) of the same class is usually lengthened (â†’ (VÌ„ ) [usually]).

        suttarulebeforeafter
        {12}Vowel â†’ âˆ… / __ vowelyassa+indriyÄniyassâ€™indriyÄni samathaá¹…â€™gatÄni
        hi+etaá¹no heâ€™taá¹ bhante
        sametu+ÄyasmÄsametÄâ€™yasmÄ saá¹ghena
        {13}Vowel / __ dissimilar vowel, dissimilar vowel â†’ âˆ…cattÄro+imecattÄroâ€™me bhikkhave dhammÄ
        kinnu+imÄ+evakinÊ¼nuâ€™mÄâ€™va samaá¹‡iyo
        (exception)paÃ±ca+indriyÄnipaÃ±ciâ€™ndriyÄni
        (exception)tayo+assutayaâ€™ssu dhammÄ jahitÄ bhavanti
        {14}a or Äâ†’âˆ… [occasionally] / __ i or Ä«,i or Ä«â†’ebandhussa+ivabandhusseâ€™va samÄgamo
        {14}a or Äâ†’âˆ… [occasionally] / __ u or Å«,u or Å«â†’ona+upetisaá¹…khyaá¹ â€¢ noâ€™peti vedagÅ«
        (exception)yassa+indriyÄniyassiâ€™ndriyÄni
        (exception)tathÄ+upamaá¹tathÅ«â€™pamaá¹ dhammavaraá¹ adesayi
        {15}Vowel â†’ âˆ… [occasionally] / __ vowel, vowel â†’ (VÌ„)saddhÄ+idhasaddhÄ«â€™dha vittaá¹ purisassa seá¹­á¹­haá¹
        ca+ubhayaá¹anÄgÄrehi â€¢cÅ«â€™bhayaá¹

        (exception)iti+assa muhuttaá¹+apiitiâ€™ssa muhuttamâ€™pi
