        2.10 - F: `upasagga ` meanings

        Detailed Meanings of upasagga Particles
        Part of “A Beginner (Non-Linguist) Guide to Learning Pali”

        Note

        Sometimes, certain upasagga words shown by the â—Š mark can also be used independently in sentences in addition to being used as prefixes.

        pa

        meaningexamplecombinationexample meaning
        specifically, specially, in various wayspajÄnÄtipa + jÄnÄti(he) knows specifically, in various ways
        paÃ±Ã±Äpa + Ã±Äknowing specifically, in various ways, i.e. wisdom, knowledge
        uppaggaá¹‡hÄtipa + gaá¹‡hÄti(He) takes up, lifts up by praise and support etc.
        paggÄhopa + gÄhosuch an act
        away, abroad, far awaypakkamatipa + kamati(He) goes away
        pakkantopa + kantogone away
        pavÄsaá¹pa + vÄsaá¹living abroad, the distant place
        pavÄsÄ«pa + vÄsÄ«lresident abroad, one who lives at a distant region or country
        the sourcepabhavatipa + bhavati(It) originates. i.e. it starts to happen
        pabhavopa + bhavoorigin
        successivelypapitÄmahopa + pitÄmahogreat-grandfather
        panattÄpa + nattÄgreat-grandchildren
        pÄcariyÄpa + ÄcariyÄsuccessive generation of preceding teachers
        chief, noblepadhÄnaá¹pa + dhÄnaá¹chief, principal
        pÄvacanaá¹pa + vacanaá¹the noble words of Buddha, i.e. canonical texts
        paá¹‡Ä«taá¹pa + nÄ«taá¹noble, the best
        being clear and cleanpasÄ«datipa + sÄ«dati(It) settles clear (as the mind being clear with joy and faith)
        pasannopa + sannobeing joyous or pleased with joy etc.
        insidepakkhipatipa + khipati(He) puts inside
        pakkhittopa + khittohaving put inside
        pasassatipa + sassati(He) breathes in
        passÄsopa + ssÄsoinhalation
        intensifierpadahatipa + dahati(He) puts inside
        padhÄnaá¹pa + khittoEffort in meditation practice or in any pursuit
        pavassatipa + vassati(It) rains heavily
        pavanaá¹pa + vanaá¹thick forest

        parÄ

        meaningexamplecombinationexample meaning
        opposite ofparÄjayatiparÄ + jayati(He) fails or is defeated
        parÄjayoparÄ + jayodefeat, failure (compare with jayati - conquers)
        parÄbhavatiparÄ + bhavati(He) loses
        parÄbhavoparÄ + bhavoloss, ruin (compare with bhavati - happens, arises)
        again and again, continuouslyparakkamatiparÄ + kamati(He) makes effort again and again
        parakkamoparÄ + kamocontinuous, successive effort
        wronglyparÄmasatiparÄ + Ämasati(He) touches it wrongly, takes it in wrong way
        parÄmÄsoparÄ + ÄmÄsotouching wrongly, wrong view

        ni

        meaningexamplecombinationexample meaning
        out, awaynikkhamatini + kamati(He) comes out
        niggatoni + gatogone out, left
        down, intonidahatini + dahati(He) keeps underneath, stores (as of precious things by burying) or takes it deeply
        nidhÄnaá¹ni + dhÄnaá¹such an act
        nihitoni + hitohaving kept down
        nikkhipatini + khipati(He) drops down
        nikkhittoni + khittohaving dropped
        nisÄ«datini + sÄ«dati(He) settles down. i.e. sits
        nisinnoni + sinnohaving sat
        niggaá¹‡hÄtini + gaá¹‡hÄti(he) takes down, i.e. censures (compare paggaá¹‡hÄti - lifts up by praise etc.)
        niggahani + gahacensure (compare paggaha - encouragement and support)
        back down, as in going or in an action, opposite ofnivattatini + vattatibacks down or gives up
        nivattanaá¹ni + vattanaá¹returning or act of giving up
        without, lack ofnidukkhoni + dukkhowithout suffering
        nirogoni + rogowithout disease, healthy
        nillajjoni + lajjowithout shame, shameless

        nÄ«

        meaningexamplecombinationexample meaning
        out, off, to removenÄ«haratinÄ« + harati(He) takes out, removes
        nÄ«haraá¹‡aá¹nÄ« + haraá¹‡aá¹act of taking out, removal

        Note

        Both Ni and NÄ« are not different from each other except the fact that one is a lengthened-form of upasagga.

        â€œá¹â€ becomes â€œá¹…â€ as it precedes â€œkhâ€ or â€œgâ€ in the words above.
        â€œá¹â€ becomes â€œmâ€ as it precedes â€œbhâ€.
        â€œá¹â€ becomes â€œnâ€ as it precedes “dh”, â€œdâ€.

        2.11 - G: `vibhatti` Rules

        vibhatti rules from KaccÄyana
        Part of “A Beginner (Non-Linguist) Guide to Learning Pali”

        2.12 - H: `taddhita` (affixes)

        taddhita affixes and their meanings
        Part of “A Beginner (Non-Linguist) Guide to Learning Pali”

        This appendix contains a subset of the examples provided in KaccÄyana - consult the book for a full set of examples.

        tassÄâ€™pacca (“the son or descendant of someone”)

        suttaphrasebaseaffixtransformationwordmeaning
        {344}vasiá¹­á¹­hassa apaccaá¹ vÄvasiá¹­á¹­haá¹‡avasiá¹­á¹­ha + á¹‡a + si [o/Ä«/aá¹]vÄsiá¹­á¹­ho(ğŸš¹) vÄsiá¹­á¹­hÄ«(ğŸšº) vÄsiá¹­á¹­haá¹(ğŸš»)Vasiá¹­á¹­ha’s son/daughter/clan
        {345}vacchassa apaccaá¹ vÄvacchaá¹‡Äyanavasiá¹­á¹­ha + á¹‡Äyana + si [o/Ä«/aá¹]vacchÄyano(ğŸš¹) vacchÄyanÄ«(ğŸšº) vacchÄyanaá¹(ğŸš»)Vaccha’s son/daughter/clan
        {345}vacchassa apaccaá¹ vÄvacchaá¹‡Änavasiá¹­á¹­ha + á¹‡Äna + si [o/Ä«/aá¹]vacchÄno(ğŸš¹) vacchÄnÄ«(ğŸšº) vacchÄnaá¹(ğŸš»)Vaccha’s son/daughter/clan
        {346}kattikÄya apaccaá¹ vÄkattikÄá¹‡eyyakattikÄ + á¹‡eyya + si (o)kattikeyyo(a woman) KattikÄ’s son or descendant
        {347}dakkhassa apaccaá¹ vÄdakkhaá¹‡idakkha + á¹‡i + si (o)dakkhiDakkha’s son or descendant

        {349}vidhavÄya apaccaá¹ vÄvidhavÄá¹‡eravi(e)dhavÄ + á¹‡era + si (o)vedhaverowidow’s son or descendant

        aneâ€™kaâ€™ttha (various meanings)

        suttaexpressionphrasebaseaffixtransformationwordmeaning
        {350}saá¹saá¹­á¹­ha â€œbeing mixed in as an ingredientâ€tilena saá¹saá¹­á¹­haá¹ bhojanaá¹tilaá¹‡ikati(e)la + á¹‡ika + si (á¹)telikaá¹food mixed with sesame
        {350}tarati â€œmode of crossing a river etc.â€nÄvÄya taratÄ«â€™tinÄvÄá¹‡ikanÄvÄ + á¹‡ika + si (o)nÄvikotraveler by boat

        {350}vahati â€œmode of carriageâ€sÄ«sena vahatÄ«â€™tisÄ«saá¹‡ikasÄ«sa + á¹‡ika + si (o)sÄ«sikoone who carries (something) on head
        {350}vasatÄ« “residency”rÄjagahe vasatÄ«â€™tirÄjagahaá¹‡ikarÄjagaha + á¹‡ika + si (o)rÄjagahikoresident/native of RÄjagaha city
        {351}adhÄ«te â€œlearning or subject of studyâ€rvinayaâ€™madhÄ«tevinayaá¹‡ikavi(e)naya + á¹‡ika + si (o)venayiko (i>e vuddhi)Vinaya-learner. i.e. the student of Vinaya texts
        {351}tena kataá¹ â€œmodes of actionâ€kÄyena kataá¹ kammaá¹kÄyaá¹‡ikakÄya + á¹‡ika + si (á¹)kÄyikaá¹bodily action
        {351}sannidhÄna â€œoriginated inâ€sarÄ«re sannidhÄnÄ vedanÄsarÄ«raá¹‡ikasarÄ«ra + á¹‡ika + si (Ä)sÄrÄ«rikÄthe bodily feeling. i.e. bodily pain etc.

        {351}sippa â€œprofession or knowledgeâ€vÄ«á¹‡Ä assa sippaá¹vÄ«á¹‡Äá¹‡ikavÄ«(e)á¹‡Ä + á¹‡ika + si (o)veá¹‡iko (i>e vuddhi)the harp-professional, the harpist

        2.14 - J: `kibbidhÄna` (`kita` affixes)

        kita affixes and their meanings
        Part of “A Beginner (Non-Linguist) Guide to Learning Pali”

        kita affixed nouns {546} usually have a sense of a “doer” (someone who does something). This appendix contains a subset of the examples provided in KaccÄyana - consult the book for a full set of examples.

        Kitaâ€™ntogadha dutiyÄ Tappurisa

        saddÅ«papada â‘¡ (nearby noun eg. kamma-work, kumbha-pot, mÄlÄ-flower) + dhÄtu (eg. kara, gaha) + affix (eg. á¹‡a)

        rulephrasesaddÅ«papadadhÄtuaffixtransformationwordmeaning
        {524}kammaá¹ karotÄ«â€™tikammakaraá¹‡akamma + kara + á¹‡a (o)kammakÄrothe one who does work ie. “worker”, “laborer”
        {525}ariá¹ dametÄ«â€™tiaridamuaari(n) + damu + a (o)arindamothe one who subdues enemies (eg. rÄjÄ)
        {525}taá¹‡haá¹ karotÄ«â€™titaá¹‡hÄkaraataá¹‡hÄ(an) + kara + a (o)taá¹‡haá¹…karothe one who overcomes cravings (eg. bhagavÄ)
        {526}pure dÄnaá¹ adÄsÄ«â€™tipuradadaapura(in) + dada + a (o)purindadothe one who gave alms in the previous past lives (eg. devarÄjÄ)
        {527}taá¹ karotÄ«â€™titakaraata(k) + kara + a (o)takkarothe one who does that deed
        {527}rathaá¹ karotÄ«â€™tirathakaraá¹‡vuratha + ka(Ä)ra(k) + á¹‡vu (o)rathakÄrakothe one who makes chariot, the chariot-maker
        {527}taá¹ karotÄ«â€™titakaratuta(k) + kara(t) + tu (Ä)takkattÄthe one who does that deed
        {527}bhayaá¹ passatÄ«â€™tibhayadisaÄvÄ«bhaya + disa(ass) + ÄvÄ«bhayadassÄvÄ«the one who sees danger

        tassÄ«lÄ (habitual pattern)

        • a habit, habitual pattern, a consistent character (tassÄ«lÄ)
        • an ingrained nature (taddhamma)
        • a dedicated habit of doing things well (tassÄdhukÄrÄ«)
        rulephrasesaddÅ«papadadhÄtuaffixtransformationwordmeaning

        rulephrasedhÄtuaffixtransformationwordmeaning
        {533}ghosanasÄ«losadda, kudha, cala, maá¹‡á¸a, ruca, ghusayughu(o)sa + yu (no)ghosanothe one whose habit is to be vocal, the vocal one, noisy talker

        kicca affixes {545}

        These affixes are associated with passive-voice (kamma) verbal nouns or middle-voice (bhÄva) verbs. Some Pali grammar books refer to them as “future passive particles” but this only describes the kamma sense of these words.

        rulephrasedhÄtuaffixtransformationwordmeaning
        {540}bhavitabbaá¹bhÅ«anÄ«yabhÅ«(av) + anÄ«ya (á¹)bhavanÄ«yaá¹(It) should be (Kamma sense), or the state of being (BhÄva sense)
        {541}kattabbaá¹karaá¹‡yakara(i) + á¹‡ya (á¹)kÄriyaá¹(It) should be done (kamma) or act of doing, an act (bhÄva)
        {541}Ã±Ätabbaá¹Ã±ÄteyyaÃ±Ä + teyya (á¹)Ã±Äteyyaá¹it should be known (kamma) or act of knowing (bhÄva)
        {542}kattabbaá¹karariccakara + ricca (á¹)kiccaá¹something that should be done, i.e. a matter or a case or a duty to do
        {543}bhavitabbobhÅ«á¹‡yabhÅ« + á¹‡ya(abba) (o)bhabbolikely to happen, likely to occur

        {547}kammananditabbaá¹nandayunanda + yu(na) (á¹)nandanaá¹something which should be pleased with, being pleasant or such a thing
        {548}katturajaá¹ haratÄ«â€™tiharayuraja(o) + hara + yu(na) (á¹)rajoharaá¹‡aá¹the dust-remover

        ina affix

        rulesensephrasedhÄtuaffixtransformationwordmeaning
        {558}kattÄpÄpake akusale dhamme jinÄti, ajini, jinissatÄ«â€™tijiinaji + ina (o)jinothe one who subjugates, subjugated and will subjugate the evil, bad, unwholesome mental states, Buddha, the victor of evil
        {559}kattÄsupatÄ«â€™tisupainasupa + ina (á¹)supinaá¹dream, (seen while sleeping)
        {559}bhÄvasupÄ«yatesupainasupa + ina (á¹)supinaá¹sleep

        Ä«saá¹, du, su + kha

        ruledhÄtuaffixtransformationwordmeaning
        {560}siaÄ«saá¹(s) + si + a (yo)Ä«sassayolittle-sleeping, a nap (bhavatÄ)
        {560}siadu(s) + si + a (yo)dussayobadly-sleeping, bad sleep (bhavatÄ)
        {560}siasu(s) + si + a (yo)sussayowell-sleeping sleep (bhavatÄ)

        tuá¹ affix

        rulemeaningphrasedhÄtuaffixtransformationwordmeaning
        {561}â€œwishâ€ or â€œpurposeâ€*puÃ±Ã±Änikaratavekara + tavekÄtaveto do, i.e. for the purpose of doing meritorious deeds
        {561}â€œwishâ€ or â€œpurposeâ€*saddhammaá¹sutuá¹su(o) + tuá¹sotuâ€™micchatiHe wants to listen to the Dhamma
        {562}worthiness and abilitysaddhammaá¹nindatuá¹ninda(i) + tuá¹ninditumâ€™arahatiWho deserves to blame that person?
        {563}â€œappropriatenessâ€ to do somethingalaâ€™meva dÄnÄnidÄtuá¹dÄ + tuá¹dÄtuá¹to offer, i.e. It is only appropriate to offer alms (as it can enrich one in many ways)
        {563}â€œappropriatenessâ€ to do somethingalaâ€™meva puÃ±Ã±Änikaratuá¹kara + tuá¹kÄtuá¹to do, i.e. It is fitting or suitable to do meritorious deeds (as it can lead to wholesome results)

        *in a sentence having one same KattÄ (subject)

        tuna, tvÄna, tvÄ (gerund or absolutive)

        To express concurrent actions of a single doer, one being a preceding action and the other being next subsequent action.

        rulephrasedhÄtuaffixtransformationwordmeaning
        {564}kÄtuna kammaá¹ gacchatikaratunakara(Ä) + tunakÄtunaHe goes (after) having done work
        {564}akÄtuna puÃ±Ã±aá¹ kilissantikaratunana + kara(Ä) + tunakÄtuna(He) will suffer for not having done meritorious deeds
        {564}sattÄ sutvÄna dhammaá¹ modantisutvÄnasu + tvÄnasutvÄnahaving heard Dhamma, the living beings are delighted
        {564}jitvÄna vasatijitvÄnaji + tvÄnajitvÄnaHaving conquered the enemy (ripuá¹), (he) lives
        {564}sutvÄnaâ€™ssa etaâ€™dahosisutvÄnasu + tvÄnasutvÄnahaving heard Dhamma, this thought arose in him (in his mind)
        {564}sutvÄna amutra kathayantisutunasu + tvÄnasutvÄnahaving heard here, they say there (what they heard)
        {564}sutvÄ jÄnissÄmasutvÄsu + tvÄsutvÄWe must know (how to respond) (only after) having heard (from you)

        mÄna, anta (present participle)

        To express an on-going action being done or still taking place at present, (i.e. as yet unfinished action).

        rulephrasedhÄtuaffixtransformationwordmeaning
        {565}saramÄno rodatisaramÄnasara + a + mÄna (o)saramÄno(he) cries while remembering
        {565}gacchanto gaá¹‡hÄtigamuantagamu(cch) + anta (o)gacchanto(he) takes or grabs while going

        ritu, ratthu, rÄtu, tuka, ika

        rulephrasedhÄtuaffixtransformationwordmeaning
        {566}sÄsatÄ«â€™tisÄsaratthusÄsa + ratthu (Ä)satthÄthe one who teaches, the teacher
        {566}sÄsati hiá¹satÄ«â€™ti vÄsÄsaratthusÄsa + ratthu (Ä)satthÄthe one who hurts the defilements, Buddha who hurts defilements
        {567}pÄti puttanâ€™tipÄritupÄ + ritu (Ä)pitÄthe one who protects oneâ€™s offspring, the father
        {568}dhammena puttaá¹ mÄnetÄ«â€™timÄnarÄtumÄna + rÄtu (Ä)mÄtÄthe one who justly adores (her) offspring, the mother
        {568}pubbe bhÄsatÄ«â€™tibhÄsarÄtubhÄsa + rÄtu (Ä)bhÄtÄthe one who speaks (first before other young siblings) i.e. Brother.
        {568}mÄtÄpitÅ«hi dhÄrÄ«yatÄ«â€™tidhararitudhara + ri(Ä«)tu (Ä)dhÄ«tÄthe one who speaks (first before other young siblings) i.e. Brother
        {569}ÄgacchatÄ«â€™tigamutukaÄ + gamu(n) + tuka (o)Ägantukothe one who comes (to visit) (bhikkhu)
        {570}gamissati, gantuá¹ bhabboâ€™tigamuikagamu + ika (o)gamikothe one who will go or who is likely (be going on a trip). the would-be-traveler, the tourist (bhikkhu)

        2.15 - K: `uá¹‡Ädi` (`kita` affixes)

        uá¹‡Ädi affixes and their meanings
        Part of “A Beginner (Non-Linguist) Guide to Learning Pali”

        2.16 - L: `sabbanÄma` (Pronouns)

        List of sabbanÄma and their vibhatti endings
        Part of “A Beginner (Non-Linguist) Guide to Learning Pali”

        Kinds of sabbanÄma

        1. Personal pronoun (puggalanÄmaá¹ƒ).
        2. Demonstrative pronoun (nidassananÄmaá¹ƒ).
        3. Relative pronoun (anvayÄ«nÄmaá¹ƒ).
        4. Interrogative pronoun (pucchÄnÄmaá¹ƒ).
        5. Indefinite pronoun (anÄ«yamanÄmaá¹ƒ).
        6. Possessive pronoun

        List of sabbanÄma

        nosabbanÄmameaning
        1sabbaâ€œallâ€
        2kataraâ€œwhich [of two]?â€
        3katamaâ€œwhich [of many]?â€
        4ubbayaâ€œbothâ€
        5itaraâ€œother [of two]â€
        6aÃ±Ã±aâ€œother [of many]â€
        7aÃ±Ã±ataraâ€œother [of many]â€
        8aÃ±Ã±atamaâ€œa certain [of two]â€
        9pubbaâ€œformerâ€
        10paraâ€œanotherâ€
        11aparaâ€œanotherâ€
        12dakkhiá¹‡aâ€œright,â€ â€œsouthâ€
        13uttaraâ€œupper,â€ â€œnorth,â€ â€œmore thanâ€
        14adharaâ€œlowerâ€
        15yaâ€œwho,â€ â€œwhatâ€
        16taâ€œhe,â€ â€œthatâ€
        17etaâ€œthisâ€
        18imaâ€œthisâ€
        19amuâ€œthatâ€
        20kiá¹ƒâ€œwhat?â€, â€œwhy?â€
        21ekaâ€œoneâ€
        22ubhaâ€œbothâ€
        23dviâ€œtwoâ€
        24tiâ€œthreeâ€
        25catuâ€œfourâ€
        26tumhaâ€œyouâ€
        27amhaâ€œI,â€ â€œweâ€

        ma(d), mam

        This is used as the pronoun for uttama purisa (in English, “1st” person)

        vibhattiâ¨€â¨‚
        â‘ ahaá¹ƒ (amhi, asmi, mhi)amhÄ, amhe, mayaá¹ƒ, mayhaá¹ƒ, no, vayaá¹ƒ
        â‘¡maá¹ƒ, mamaá¹ƒ, mayhaá¹ƒ, mÄm-, meamhÄkaá¹ƒ, amhe, asmÄkaá¹ƒ, asme, no
        â‘¢mayÄ, meamhebhi, amhehi, asmÄhi, asmÄbhi, no
        â‘¤mamato, mayÄ, meamhebhi, amhehi, asmÄhi, asmÄbhi, no
        â‘£â‘¥amhaá¹ƒ, mama(á¹ƒ), mamÄ, maá¹ƒ, mayha(á¹ƒ), meamhaá¹ƒ, amhÄka(á¹ƒ), asmÄkaá¹ƒ, no (ne)
        â‘¦mayi, meamhesu, asmÄsu, asmesu

        ta(d)

        This is used as the pronoun for majjima purisa (in English, “2nd” person)

        vibhattiâ¨€â¨‚
        â‘ taá¹ƒ, tuvaá¹ƒ, tvaá¹ƒtumhe, vo
        â‘¡taá¹ƒ, tavaá¹ƒ, tuvaá¹ƒ, tvaá¹ƒ, tyaá¹ƒ, tetumhÄkaá¹ƒ, tumhe, vaá¹ƒ, ve, vo

        â‘¤tayÄ, te, tvÄyatumhebhi, tumhehi

        â‘¦tayi, tvayitumhesu

        This is used as the pronoun for paá¹­hama purisa (in English, “3rd” person)

        â¨€ ekavacana

        â‘ sa, se, so, sÅ«tad-, tadaá¹ƒ, taá¹ƒ (naá¹ƒ), sesÄ
        â‘¡taá¹ƒ (naá¹ƒ), tetad-, taá¹ƒ (naá¹ƒ), setaá¹ƒ

        2.17 - M: Overview of KaccÄyana

        An overview of KaccÄyana and interpretation guidelines
        Part of “A Beginner (Non-Linguist) Guide to Learning Pali”

        The material in this appendix is mostly drawn from a class called A Short Introduction to the KaccÄyana Pali Grammar: Its Background, Techniques and Terminology taught by Aleix Ruiz-FalquÃ©s, Shan State Buddhist University, Taunggyi, Myanmar in 2020.

        Genesis of KaccÄyana

        There are actually two components of KaccÄyana:

        • KaccÄyana-byÄjkarana (circa 6th century CE) and the author is not known (but ascribed to MahÄ KaccÄyana Thera) - this contains the concisely stated rules (called sutta) that form the basis of Pali grammar; and
        • KaccÄyana-vutti (circa 8th centure CE) by Saá¹…ghanandin, which represents a commentary and explanation of the rules together with examples.

        KaccÄyana itself draws from multiple earlier sources such as:

        • PrÄtiÅ›Äkya treatises, Vedic phonetics (various authors)
        • PÄnini’s Aá¹£á¹­ÄdhyÄyÄ« (“Eight Lessons”)
        • KÄtantravyÄkarana by Å arvavarman

        So, KaccÄyana draws and inherits from a long tradition of Sanskrit grammar and technical terms. According to Pind (2012) approximately 215 sutta from KaccÄyana are based on KÄtantravyÄkarana, and approximately 300 sutta are modifications from Panini. However, more than half the sutta in KaccÄyana are not derived from Sanskrit, so the grammar as a whole does not reflect Sanskrit usage and vocabulary.

        KaccÄyana structure

        mindmap
  KaccÄyana
    I. Sandhi
      i. Definitions
      ii. Vowel sandhi
      iii. Consonant sandhi
      Iiv("iv. niggahÄ«ta (á¹ƒ) sandhi")
      v. Miscellanea
    II. NÄma
      i. Definitions, Internal sandhis, Default Declensions
      ii. Pronominal declension, an-stems
      iii. Pronominal dec. continued, mano-gaá¹‡a, an-stems, tar-stems.
      iv. an-stems cont., feminine stems, adv. pronouns, nta-stems
      v. Adverbial affixes
      vi. KÄ€RAKA
      vii. SAMÄ€SA
      viii. TADDHITA
    III. Ä€khyÄta
      i. Definitions
      ii. Special stems, causatives, bhÄva, vb. classes
      iii. Reduplication, Special stems
      iv. Special affixes and stems
    IV. KibbidhÄna
      i. Definition of kicca and kit affixes
      ii. Use of affixes with tenses, voices, etc.
      iii. niá¹­á¹­hÄ affixes
      iv. Modification of vb. stems in primary derivation
      v. Uá¹†Ä€DI

        Types of rules in KaccÄyana

        Several saÃ±Ã±Ä â€œtechnical termsâ€, within an adhikÄra â€œdomainâ€, following paribhÄsÄ â€œmetarulesâ€, will be subject to vidhi â€œoperationsâ€ in order to derive words or sentences.

        @startebnf
grammar (* KaccÄyana *) = 675 * rule (* sutta *);
rule =
  technical_term (* saÃ±Ã±Ä *) |
  domain (* adhikÄra *) |
  metarule (* paribhÄsÄ *) |
  operation (* vidhi *) ;
technical_term =
  meaningful (* anvattha *) |
  artificial (* rÅ«á¸·hÄ« *) ;
domain =
  lion_way (* sÄ«hagatika *) |
  frog_way (* maá¹‡á¸Å«kagatika *) |
  progressive (* yathÄnupubbika *) ;
metarule =
  meta_definition (* saÃ±Ã±aá¹…ga *) |
  meta_operation (* vidhyaá¹…ga *) |
  meta_other (* aÃ±Ã±aá¹…ga *) ;
operation =
  replacement (* Ädesa *) |
  insertion (* Ägama *) |
  modification (* vikÄra *) |
  elision (* lopa *) |
  metathesis (* viparÄ«ta *) ;
@endebnf

        @startyaml
saÃ±Ã±Ä:
  - anvattha
  - rÅ«á¸·hÄ«
adhikÄra:
  - sÄ«hagatika
  - maá¹‡á¸Å«kagatika
  - yathÄnupubbika
paribhÄsÄ:
  - saÃ±Ã±aá¹…ga
  - vidhyaá¹…ga
  - aÃ±Ã±aá¹…ga
vidhi:
  - Ädesa
  - Ägama
  - vikÄra
  - lopa
  - viparÄ«ta
@endyaml

        How does a vidhi (operation) work

        Most vidhi â€œoperationalâ€ rules teach paccaya â€œaffixationâ€ or Ädesa â€œreplacementâ€ using previous definitions (saÃ±Ã±Ä-s). It is all about adding particles to a base, and then replacing them if/when needed.

        To understand vidhi-s, we should keep in mind the following code of case endings:

        • ABL. = â€œafter Xâ€
        • GEN. = â€œinstead of Xâ€
        • NOM., ACC. = â€œXâ€, Ädesa (“replacement”)
        • LOCATIVE1: â€œbefore Xâ€
        • LOCATIVE2: â€œin the sense of Xâ€

        Affixation (paccaya)

        timeline
  Left : Ablative
    : After X
  A : Nominative
    : Affix A is inserted
        @startebnf
affixation = ablative (* After X *), nominative (* A is inserted *);
ablative = 
  (nominal_base (* liá¹…ga *) |
  verbal_base (* dhÄtu *)), "smÄ" ;
@endebnf

        Replacement (Ädesa)

        timeline
  Left : Ablative
    : Ablative
    : Ablative
    : After X
  A : Genitive
    : Nominative
    : Nominative
    : Replace A
  B : Nominative
    : Nominative
    : Accusative
    : With B
  Right : Locative
    : Locative
    : Locative
    : Before Y
  Marker : ca (and)
    : api (also)
    : vÄ (or)
    : kvaci (sometimes)
    : na (not)
    : niccam (required)
  Semantic : Locative
    : "in the sense of ..."
        @startebnf
replacement = [ablative (* After X *)],
  (
    (
      genitive (* Instead of A *),
      nominative (* replace with B *)
    ) |
    (
      nominative (* Replace A *),
      nominative (* with B *)
    ) |
    (
      nominative (* A *),
      accusative (* becomes B *)
    )
  ),
  [locative (* Before Y *)], [marker], [semantic (* "in the sense of" *)];
marker =
  "ca" (* and *) |
  "api" (* also *) |
  "vÄ" (* or *) |
  "kvaci" (* sometimes *) |
  "na" (* not *) |
  "niccam" (* required *) ;
@endebnf

        Elision (lopaá¹ƒ)

        timeline
  Left : Ablative
    : After X
  A : Nominative
    : Instead of A
  lopaá¹ƒ: Accusative
    : elision
  Right : Locative
    : Before Y
        @startebnf
elision =
  [ablative (* After X *)],
  genitive (* Instead of A *),
  "lopaá¹ƒ" (* elision *),
  [locative (* Before Y *)];
@endebnf

        Structure of a rule (sutta)

        @startebnf
rule =
  aphorism (* sutta *),
  gloss (* vutti *),
  {example} (* udÄharaá¹‡a *),
  {counter_example} (* kimudÄharaá¹‡a *),
  [application] (* payojana *),
  [result] (* gahaá¹‡aphala *);
@endebnf

        stateDiagram-v2
  direction LR
  [*] --> upasagga
  [*] --> dhÄtu
  upasagga --> upasagga
  upasagga --> dhÄtu
  dhÄtu --> paccaya

        3 - Sutta Piá¹­aka

        Summary of key concepts from the Basket of Discourses

        Daá¹­á¹­habbasutta (Five faculties) SN 48.8 PTS SN v 196

        mindmap
paÃ±cindriyÄni

    sotÄpattiyaá¹…gesu
  vÄ«riyindriyaá¹
    sammappadhÄnesu
  satindriyaá¹
    satipaá¹­á¹­hÄnesu
  samÄdhindriyaá¹
    jhÄnesu
  paÃ±Ã±indriyaá¹
    ariyasaccesu

        Daá¹­á¹­habbasutta (Five powers) AN 5.15 PTS 3.12

        mindmap
paÃ±cabalÄni
  saddhÄbalaá¹
    sotÄpattiyaá¹…gesu x4
  vÄ«riyabalaá¹
    sammappadhÄnesu x4
  satibalaá¹
    satipaá¹­á¹­hÄnesu x4
  samÄdhibalaá¹
    jhÄnesu x4
  paÃ±Ã±Äbalaá¹
    ariyasaccesu x4

        TheravÄda Vibhaá¹…ga 5 aggregates paÃ±cupÄdÄnakkhandhÄ 12 sense media dvÄdasâ€™ÄyatanÄni 36 elements 18dhÄtuyo 4 noble truths cattÄri ariyasaccÄni 22 faculties Dependent origination paá¹­iccasamuppÄdo 4 satipaá¹­á¹­hÄnas cattÄro_satipaá¹­á¹­hÄnÄ 4 right efforts cattÄro_sammappadhÄnÄti 4 bases of power cattÄro_iddhipÄdÄ 7 awakening-factors satta_bojjhaá¹…gÄ 8-fold path ariyo aá¹­á¹­haá¹…giko maggo 4 jhÄnas jhÄnaá¹ 4 divine abidings catasso_appamaÃ±Ã±Äyo 5 precepts paÃ±ca_sikkhÄpadÄniÄ 4 discriminations atasso_paá¹­isambhidÄ Khuddakavatthu3 Ã‘Äá¹‡avibhaá¹…ga4 Dhammahadaya5 SarvÄstivÄda Dharmaskandha 5 precepts 4 stream-entry factors 4 confirmed faiths 4 fruits of asceticism 4 ways of practice 4 noble lineages 4 right efforts 4 bases of power 4 satipaá¹­á¹­hÄnas 4 noble truths 4 jhÄnas 4 divine abidings 4 formless 4 samÄdhis 7 awakening-factors Khuddakavatthu 22 faculties 12 sense media 5 aggregates 62 elements Dependent origination Dharmagupta ÅšÄriputrÄbhidharma 12 sense media 18 elements 5 aggregates 4 noble truths 22 faculties 7 awakening-factors 3 unskilful roots 3 skilful roots 4 great elements 5 precepts Elements Kamma Persons1 Knowledge2 Dependent origination 4 satipaá¹­á¹­hÄnas 4 right efforts 4 bases of power 4 jhÄnas 8-fold path Unskilful dhammas6 Saá¹…graha7 Sampayoga PrasthÄna

        classDiagram
dvÄdasÄyatanÄni --> aniccaá¹

        ---
title: Class Diagram of Core Teachings
config:
  theme: base
  themeVariables:
    primaryColor: "#f4dede"

classDiagram
direction LR
namespace 4ariyasaccÄni {
  class cattÄri_ariyasaccÄni {
    english(noble truths)
  }
  class dukkhaá¹ {
    english(suffering)
  }
  class dukkhasamudayaá¹ {
    english(origin of suffering)
  }
  class dukkhanirodhaá¹ {
    english(cessation of suffering)
  }
  class dukkhanirodhagÄminÄ«_paá¹­ipadÄ {
    english(way leading to cessation of suffering)
  }
}
class nibbÄna {
  english(enlightenment)
}
cattÄri_ariyasaccÄni *-- dukkhaá¹

dukkhanirodhaá¹ --> nibbÄna
dukkhanirodhagÄminÄ«_paá¹­ipadÄ --> ariyo_aá¹­á¹­haá¹…giko_maggo

namespace ariyo_8_maggo {
  class ariyo_aá¹­á¹­haá¹…giko_maggo {
    english(noble 8fold path)
  }
  class sammÄdiá¹­á¹­hi {
    english(right views)
  }
  class sammÄsaá¹…kappo {
    english(right intentions)
    nekkhammasaá¹…kappo
    abyÄpÄdasaá¹…kappo
    avihiá¹sÄsaá¹…kappo
  }
  class sammÄvÄcÄ {
    musÄvÄdÄ veramaá¹‡Ä«
    pisuá¹‡Äya vÄcÄya veramaá¹‡Ä«
    pharusÄya vÄcÄya veramaá¹‡Ä«
    samphappalÄpÄ veramaá¹‡Ä«
    english(right speech)
  }
  class sammÄkammanto {
    pÄá¹‡ÄtipÄtÄ veramaá¹‡Ä«
    adinnÄdÄnÄ veramaá¹‡Ä«
    abrahmacariyÄ veramaá¹‡Ä«
    english(right action)
  }
  class sammÄÄjÄ«vo {
    micchÄÄjÄ«vaá¹ pahÄya
    sammÄÄjÄ«vena jÄ«vitaá¹ kappeti
    english(right livelihood)
  }
  class sammÄvÄyÄmo {
    english(right effort)
  }
  class sammÄsati {
    english(right mindfulness)
  }

    english(right concentration)
  }
}
ariyo_aá¹­á¹­haá¹…giko_maggo *-- sammÄdiá¹­á¹­hi

class paÃ±cakkhandhÄ {
  rÅ«pakkhandho

        Seven Sets

        Somestimes called “Wings to Awakening”, originally intended for communal recital as described in in PÄsÄdikasutta DN 29 PTS 3.117â€“3.141

        Also mentioned several other places:

        • MahÄparinibbÄnasutta DN 16 PTS 2.72â€“2.168
        • SampasÄdanÄ«yasutta DN 28 PTS 3.99â€“3.116
        • PahÄrÄdasutta AN 8.19 PTS 4.198â€“4.204
        • Kintisutta MN 103 PTS 2.239â€“2.243
        • SÄmagÄmasutta MN 104 PTS 2.244â€“2.251
        # bodhipÄká¹£ika-dharma
- cattÄro satipaá¹­á¹­hÄnÄ
- cattÄro sammappadhÄnÄ
- cattÄro iddhipÄdÄ

- satta bojjhaá¹…gÄ

        3.1 - cattÄri ariyasaccÄni

        The Four Noble Truths.

        The basic teaching of the four noble truths (dukkham samudayo nirodho magga) can be expressed as a medical diagnosis (The Dawn of Abhidharma p. 113):

        • disease: duá¸¥kha
        • pathogen: craving
        • health: nirvÄá¹‡a
        • cure: eightfold path

        cattÄri ariyasaccÄni

        # cattÄri ariyasaccÄni
## dukkham
- pain
- incapable of suffering
## dukkha-samudayo
- origin
- arising
## dukkha-nirodha
- cease
- suppress
## dukkha-nirodha-gamini patipada
- leading to
- path, way

        This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my essence.

        netaá¹ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attÄtiâ€” evametaá¹ yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ sammappaÃ±Ã±Äya daá¹­á¹­habbaá¹.

        Reference

        • MahÄsatipaá¹­á¹­hÄnasutta DN 22 PTS 2.290â€“2.315 PT
        • Saccavibhaá¹…gasutta MN 141 PTS 3.248â€“3.252
        • MahÄkhandhaka Pli Tv Kd 1 PTS 1.1â€“1.100 P

        3.1.1 - dukkhaá¹ ariyasaccaá¹

        noble truth of suffering
        # dukkhÄ
## jÄti
- (re)birth
## jarÄ

## maraá¹‡aá¹

## yampicchaá¹ na labhati tam
- not getting what you want

        jÄti

### nikkhepo jÄ«vitindriyassupacchedo

        3.1.2 - dukkhasamudayaá¹ ariyasaccaá¹

        noble truth of the origin of suffering

markmap:

# dukkhasamudayaá¹ ariyasaccaá¹
## yÄyaá¹ taá¹‡hÄ ponobbhavikÄ nandÄ«rÄgasahagatÄ tatratatrÄbhinandinÄ«
- the craving that leads to rebirth, that comes with delight and sensual desire, ever delighting in this and that
## kÄmataá¹‡hÄ
- craving for worldly pleasures
## bhavataá¹‡hÄ
- craving for existence
## vibhavataá¹‡hÄ
- craving for prosperity

        Reference

        3.1.3 - dukkhanirodhaá¹ ariyasaccaá¹

        noble truth of the cessation of suffering
        # dukkhanirodhaá¹ ariyasaccaá¹
## taá¹‡hÄya asesavirÄganirodho
- full fading away and ending of all craving
## cÄgo
- giving it up
## paá¹­inissaggo
- relinquishing it
## mutti
- releasing it
## anÄlayo
- letting it go

        3.1.4 - dukkhanirodhagÄminÄ« paá¹­ipadÄ ariyasaccaá¹

        noble truth of the path leading to the end of suffering

        ariyo aá¹­á¹­haá¹…giko maggo (noble eightfold path)

        # ariyo aá¹­á¹­haá¹…giko maggo

        3.2 - adantavaggo

        Restraining, Guarding and Protecting the Mind

        AN 1.4 31-40:

        1. “nÄhaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ ekadhammampi samanupassÄmi yaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ adantaá¹ƒ mahato anatthÄya saá¹ƒvattati yathayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, cittaá¹ƒ. cittaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, adantaá¹ƒ mahato anatthÄya saá¹ƒvattatÄ«"ti.
        2. “nÄhaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ ekadhammampi samanupassÄmi yaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ dantaá¹ƒ mahato atthÄya saá¹ƒvattati yathayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, cittaá¹ƒ. cittaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, dantaá¹ƒ mahato atthÄya saá¹ƒvattatÄ«"ti.
        3. “nÄhaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ ekadhammampi samanupassÄmi yaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ aguttaá¹ƒ mahato anatthÄya saá¹ƒvattati yathayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, cittaá¹ƒ. cittaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, aguttaá¹ƒ mahato anatthÄya saá¹ƒvattatÄ«"ti.
        4. “nÄhaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ ekadhammampi samanupassÄmi yaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ guttaá¹ƒ mahato atthÄya saá¹ƒvattati yathayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, cittaá¹ƒ. cittaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, guttaá¹ƒ mahato atthÄya saá¹ƒvattatÄ«"ti.
        5. “nÄhaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ ekadhammampi samanupassÄmi yaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ arakkhitaá¹ƒ mahato anatthÄya saá¹ƒvattati yathayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, cittaá¹ƒ. cittaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, arakkhitaá¹ƒ mahato anatthÄya saá¹ƒvattatÄ«"ti.
        6. “nÄhaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ ekadhammampi samanupassÄmi yaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ rakkhitaá¹ƒ mahato atthÄya saá¹ƒvattati yathayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, cittaá¹ƒ. cittaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, rakkhitaá¹ƒ mahato atthÄya saá¹ƒvattatÄ«"ti.
        7. “nÄhaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ ekadhammampi samanupassÄmi yaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ asaá¹ƒvutaá¹ƒ mahato anatthÄya saá¹ƒvattati yathayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, cittaá¹ƒ. cittaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, asaá¹ƒvutaá¹ƒ mahato anatthÄya saá¹ƒvattatÄ«"ti.
        8. “nÄhaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ ekadhammampi samanupassÄmi yaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ saá¹ƒvutaá¹ƒ mahato atthÄya saá¹ƒvattati yathayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, cittaá¹ƒ. cittaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, saá¹ƒvutaá¹ƒ mahato atthÄya saá¹ƒvattatÄ«"ti.
        9. “nÄhaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ ekadhammampi samanupassÄmi yaá¹ƒ evaá¹ƒ adantaá¹ƒ aguttaá¹ƒ arakkhitaá¹ƒ asaá¹ƒvutaá¹ƒ mahato anatthÄya saá¹ƒvattati yathayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, cittaá¹ƒ. cittaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, adantaá¹ƒ aguttaá¹ƒ arakkhitaá¹ƒ asaá¹ƒvutaá¹ƒ mahato anatthÄya saá¹ƒvattatÄ«"ti.

        sequenceDiagram
participant ahaá¹ƒ as (ahaá¹ƒ)
participant citta
participant harm as mahato anatthÄya
participant benefit as mahato atthÄya
  ahaá¹ƒ ->> citta : (na) aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ ekadhammampi samanupassÄmi

        stateDiagram-v2
  state fork1 <<fork>>
  state join1 <<join>>
  state fork2 <<fork>>
  state join2 <<join>>
  state "mahato anatthÄya" as harm
  state "mahato atthÄya" as benefit
  [*] --> fork1 : citta
  fork1 --> adantaá¹ƒ
  fork1 --> aguttaá¹ƒ
  fork1 --> arakkhitaá¹ƒ
  adantaá¹ƒ --> join1
  aguttaá¹ƒ --> join1
  arakkhitaá¹ƒ --> join1
  join1 --> harm : saá¹ƒvattati
  [*] --> fork2 : citta
  fork2 --> dantaá¹ƒ
  fork2 --> guttaá¹ƒ
  fork2 --> rakkhitaá¹ƒ
  dantaá¹ƒ --> join2
  guttaá¹ƒ --> join2
  rakkhitaá¹ƒ --> join2
  join2 --> benefit : saá¹ƒvattati

        3.3 - nÄ«varaá¹‡appahÄnavaggo

        Giving up hindrances

        AN 1.2 11-20:

        1. “nÄhaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ ekadhammampi samanupassÄmi yena anuppanno vÄ kÄmacchando uppajjati uppanno vÄ kÄmacchando bhiyyobhÄvÄya vepullÄya saá¹ƒvattati yathayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, subhanimittaá¹ƒ. subhanimittaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, ayoniso manasi karoto anuppanno ceva kÄmacchando uppajjati uppanno ca kÄmacchando bhiyyobhÄvÄya vepullÄya saá¹ƒvattatÄ«"ti.
        2. “nÄhaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ ekadhammampi samanupassÄmi yena anuppanno vÄ byÄpÄdo uppajjati uppanno vÄ byÄpÄdo bhiyyobhÄvÄya vepullÄya saá¹ƒvattati yathayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, paá¹­ighanimittaá¹ƒ. paá¹­ighanimittaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, ayoniso manasi karoto anuppanno ceva byÄpÄdo uppajjati uppanno ca byÄpÄdo bhiyyobhÄvÄya vepullÄya saá¹ƒvattatÄ«"ti.
        3. “nÄhaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ ekadhammampi samanupassÄmi yena anuppannaá¹ƒ vÄ thinamiddhaá¹ƒ uppajjati uppannaá¹ƒ vÄ thinamiddhaá¹ƒ bhiyyobhÄvÄya vepullÄya saá¹ƒvattati yathayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, arati tandÄ« vijambhitÄ bhattasammado cetaso ca lÄ«nattaá¹ƒ. lÄ«nacittassa, bhikkhave, anuppannaÃ±ceva thinamiddhaá¹ƒ uppajjati uppannaÃ±ca thinamiddhaá¹ƒ bhiyyobhÄvÄya vepullÄya saá¹ƒvattatÄ«"ti.
        4. “nÄhaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ ekadhammampi samanupassÄmi yena anuppannaá¹ƒ vÄ uddhaccakukkuccaá¹ƒ uppajjati uppannaá¹ƒ vÄ uddhaccakukkuccaá¹ƒ bhiyyobhÄvÄya vepullÄya saá¹ƒvattati yathayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, cetaso avÅ«pasamo. avÅ«pasantacittassa, bhikkhave, anuppannaÃ±ceva uddhaccakukkuccaá¹ƒ uppajjati uppannaÃ±ca uddhaccakukkuccaá¹ƒ bhiyyobhÄvÄya vepullÄya saá¹ƒvattatÄ«"ti.
        5. “nÄhaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ ekadhammampi samanupassÄmi yena anuppannÄ vÄ vicikicchÄ uppajjati uppannÄ vÄ vicikicchÄ bhiyyobhÄvÄya vepullÄya saá¹ƒvattati yathayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, ayonisomanasikÄro. ayoniso, bhikkhave, manasi karoto anuppannÄ ceva vicikicchÄ uppajjati uppannÄ ca vicikicchÄ bhiyyobhÄvÄya vepullÄya saá¹ƒvattatÄ«"ti.
        6. “nÄhaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ ekadhammampi samanupassÄmi yena anuppanno vÄ kÄmacchando nuppajjati uppanno vÄ kÄmacchando pahÄ«yati yathayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, asubhanimittaá¹ƒ. asubhanimittaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, yoniso manasi karoto anuppanno ceva kÄmacchando nuppajjati uppanno ca kÄmacchando pahÄ«yatÄ«"ti.
        7. “nÄhaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ ekadhammampi samanupassÄmi yena anuppanno vÄ byÄpÄdo nuppajjati uppanno vÄ byÄpÄdo pahÄ«yati yathayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, mettÄ cetovimutti. mettaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, cetovimuttiá¹ƒ yoniso manasi karoto anuppanno ceva byÄpÄdo nuppajjati uppanno ca byÄpÄdo pahÄ«yatÄ«"ti.
        8. “nÄhaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ ekadhammampi samanupassÄmi yena anuppannaá¹ƒ vÄ thinamiddhaá¹ƒ nuppajjati uppannaá¹ƒ vÄ thinamiddhaá¹ƒ pahÄ«yati yathayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, ÄrambhadhÄtu nikkamadhÄtu parakkamadhÄtu.         9. “nÄhaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ ekadhammampi samanupassÄmi yena anuppannaá¹ƒ vÄ uddhaccakukkuccaá¹ƒ nuppajjati uppannaá¹ƒ vÄ uddhaccakukkuccaá¹ƒ pahÄ«yati yathayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, cetaso vÅ«pasamo. vÅ«pasantacittassa, bhikkhave, anuppannaÃ±ceva uddhaccakukkuccaá¹ƒ nuppajjati uppannaÃ±ca uddhaccakukkuccaá¹ƒ pahÄ«yatÄ«"ti.
        10. “nÄhaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ ekadhammampi samanupassÄmi yena anuppannÄ vÄ vicikicchÄ nuppajjati uppannÄ vÄ vicikicchÄ pahÄ«yati yathayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, yonisomanasikÄro. yoniso, bhikkhave, manasi karoto anuppannÄ ceva vicikicchÄ nuppajjati uppannÄ ca vicikicchÄ pahÄ«yatÄ«"ti.
        classDiagram
  class sentence["nÄhaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ ekadhammampi samanupassÄmi yena anuppanno vÄ kÄmacchando uppajjati [n'] uppanno vÄ kÄmacchando [bhiyyobhÄvÄya vepullÄya/pahÄ«yati] saá¹ƒvattati yathayidaá¹ƒ, bhikkhave, [subhanimittaá¹ƒ/asubhanimittaá¹ƒ]"] {

        classDiagram
  class sentence["[subhanimittaá¹ƒ/asubhanimittaá¹ƒ], bhikkhave, ayoniso manasi karoto anuppanno ceva kÄmacchando [n'] uppajjati uppanno ca kÄmacchando [bhiyyobhÄvÄya vepullÄya/pahÄ«yati] saá¹ƒvattatÄ«"] {
    <<vÄkya>>
    english([Beauty/Repulsiveness], bhikkhus, when [a person] dwells on it imprudently, [does not] leads to sensual desire arising [from nonexistence] when it appears, and sensual desire [increasing when it grows/ceasing].)
  }
  namespace trigger {
    class subhanimittaá¹ƒ {
      <<nÄma>>

    ğŸš¹â¨‚â“ª

    english(imprudently)

    }
  }
  class ceva {
    <<nipÄta>>
    english(but then)
  }
  namespace conjunction {
    class ca {
      <<nipÄta>>
      english(and)
    }
    class anuppanno {
      <<atÄ«takiriya>>
      ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ 
      english(nonexistent)
    }
    class uppajjati {
      <<ÄkhyÄta>>
      â¨€ğŸ¤ŸvattamÄna
      english(arises)
    }
    class uppanno {
      <<atÄ«takiriya>>
      ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ 
      english(appeared)
    }
    class bhiyyobhÄvÄya {
      <<nÄma>>
      ğŸš¹â¨€â‘£
      english(increase of)
    }
    class vepullÄya {
      <<nÄma>>
      ğŸš»â¨€â‘£
      english(growth of)
    }
  }
  class saá¹ƒvattati {
    <<ÄkhyÄta>>
    â¨€ğŸ¤ŸvattamÄna
    english(leads to)
  }
  sentence *-- subhanimittaá¹ƒ
  sentence *-- bhikkhave
  sentence *-- ayoniso
  sentence *-- manasi
  sentence *-- karoto
  sentence *-- ceva
  sentence *-- ca
  sentence *-- anuppanno
  sentence *-- kÄmacchando
  sentence *-- uppajjati
  sentence *-- uppanno
  sentence *-- bhiyyobhÄvÄya
  sentence *-- vepullÄya
  sentence *-- saá¹ƒvattati
  ayoniso --> karoto
  manasi --> karoto
  karoto ..> ceva
  ceva ..> anuppanno
  kÄmacchando --> uppajjati : kattar
  kÄmacchando --> bhiyyobhÄvÄya
  uppajjati --> uppanno
  bhiyyobhÄvÄya --> vepullÄya
  anuppanno <-- saá¹ƒvattati
  uppanno <-- saá¹ƒvattati
  vepullÄya <-- saá¹ƒvattati
  subhanimittaá¹ƒ --> saá¹ƒvattati
  subhanimittaá¹ƒ --> karoto
        classDiagram
  class lÄ«nacitta["arati tandÄ« vijambhitÄ bhattasammado cetaso ca lÄ«nattaá¹ƒ"] {
    <<pada>>
    english(thoughts of boredom, laziness, sleepiness, food coma and sluggishness)
  }
  class avÅ«pasantacitta["cetaso avÅ«pasamo"] {
    <<pada>>
    english(thoughts of agitation)
  }
  class ayonisomanasikÄro {
    <<nÄma>>
    ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ 
    english(imprudent use of mind)
  }
  namespace trigger {
    class subhanimittaá¹ƒ {
      <<nÄma>>
      ğŸš»â¨€â‘ 
      english(beauty)
    }
    class paá¹­ighanimittaá¹ƒ {
      <<nÄma>>
      ğŸš»â¨€â‘ 
      english(dislike)
    }
    class lÄ«nacittassa {
      <<nÄma>>
      ğŸš»â¨€â‘¥

    class avÅ«pasantacittassa {
      <<nÄma>>
      ğŸš»â¨€â‘¥
      english(of agitated mind)
    }
    class ayoniso {
      <<kriyÄ>>
      english(imprudently)
    }

  namespace result {
    class kÄmacchando {
      <<nÄma>>
      ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ 
      english(sensual desire)

    class byÄpÄdo {
      <<nÄma>>
      ğŸš¹â¨€â‘

  namespace nontrigger {

      ğŸš»â¨€â‘¥

  subhanimittaá¹ƒ .. kÄmacchando
  kÄmacchando .. asubhanimittaá¹ƒ
  paá¹­ighanimittaá¹ƒ .. byÄpÄdo
  byÄpÄdo .. mettaá¹ƒ
  lÄ«nacitta .. lÄ«nacittassa

  thinamiddhaá¹ƒ .. ÄraddhavÄ«riyassa
  avÅ«pasantacitta .. avÅ«pasantacittassa

  uddhaccakukkuccaá¹ƒ .. vÅ«pasantacittassa
  ayonisomanasikÄro .. ayoniso
  ayoniso .. vicikicchÄ
  vicikicchÄ .. yoniso

        3.4 - saraá¹‡attaya

        The Three Refuges

        Khp. 1:

        buddhaá¹ƒ saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gacchÄmi,
        dhammaá¹ƒ saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gacchÄmi,
        saá¹…ghaá¹ƒ saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gacchÄmi.
        dutiyampi buddhaá¹ƒ saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gacchÄmi,
        dutiyampi dhammaá¹ƒ saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gacchÄmi,
        dutiyampi saá¹…ghaá¹ƒ saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gacchÄmi.
        tatiyampi buddhaá¹ƒ saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gacchÄmi,
        tatiyampi dhammaá¹ƒ saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gacchÄmi,
        tatiyampi saá¹…ghaá¹ƒ saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gacchÄmi.

        classDiagram
  class sentence["dutiyampi/tatiyampi buddhaá¹ƒ/dhammaá¹ƒ/saá¹…ghaá¹ƒ saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ gacchÄmi"] {
    <<vÄkya>>
    english((For the second/third time) I go to the Buddha/Dhamma/Sangha as refuge)
  }
  namespace saá¹…khyÄpÅ«raá¹‡a {
    class dutiyaá¹ƒ {
      <<nÄma>>
      â‘¡
      english(second time)
    }
    class tatiyaá¹ƒ {
      <<nÄma>>
      â‘¡
      english(third time)
    }
  }
  class pi {
    <<nipÄta>>
    english(too)
  }
  namespace saraá¹‡a {
    class buddhaá¹ƒ {
      <<nÄma>>
      ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¡
    }
    class dhammaá¹ƒ {
      <<nÄma>>
      ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¡
    }
    class saá¹…ghaá¹ƒ {
      <<nÄma>>
      ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¡
    }
  }
  class saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ {
    <<nÄma>>
     ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¡
    english(as refuge)
  }
  class gacchÄmi {
    <<ÄkhyÄta>>
     â¨€ğŸ‘†vattamÄna
    english(I go)
  }
  sentence *-- dutiyaá¹ƒ
  sentence *-- tatiyaá¹ƒ
  sentence *-- pi
  sentence *-- buddhaá¹ƒ : kamma
  sentence *-- dhammaá¹ƒ : kamma
  sentence *-- saá¹…ghaá¹ƒ : kamma
  sentence *-- saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ : kamma
  sentence *-- gacchÄmi: kiriya
  buddhaá¹ƒ .. saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ
  dhammaá¹ƒ .. saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ
  saá¹…ghaá¹ƒ .. saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ
        sequenceDiagram
participant ahaá¹ƒ as (ahaá¹ƒ)
participant buddhaá¹ƒ
participant dhammaá¹ƒ
participant saá¹…ghaá¹ƒ
  loop (paá¹­hama), dutiyampi, tatiyampi
    ahaá¹ƒ ->> buddhaá¹ƒ : gacchÄmi
    buddhaá¹ƒ ->> saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ : (hoti)
    ahaá¹ƒ ->> dhammaá¹ƒ : gacchÄmi
    dhammaá¹ƒ ->> saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ : (hoti)
    ahaá¹ƒ ->> saá¹…ghaá¹ƒ : gacchÄmi
    saá¹…ghaá¹ƒ ->> saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ : (hoti)
  end
        stateDiagram-v2
  state fork_state <<fork>>
  state join_state <<join>>
  [*] --> fork_state : gacchÄmi
  fork_state --> buddhaá¹ƒ
  fork_state --> dhammaá¹ƒ
  fork_state --> saá¹…ghaá¹ƒ
  buddhaá¹ƒ --> join_state
  dhammaá¹ƒ --> join_state
  saá¹…ghaá¹ƒ --> join_state
  join_state --> saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ
  saraá¹‡aá¹ƒ --> fork_state : dutiyampi, tatiyampi

        3.5 - saá¸·Äyatanavibhaá¹…go

        Analysis of the Six Sense Fields
        ---
markmap:
  maxWidth: 500
  initialExpandLevel: 2

# saá¸·Äyatanavibhaá¹…go
## cha ajjhattikÄni ÄyatanÄni

## aá¹­á¹­hÄrasa manopavicÄrÄ

## chattiá¹sa sattapadÄ
### cha gehasitÄni somanassÄni
- CakkhuviÃ±Ã±eyyÄnaá¹ rÅ«pÄnaá¹ iá¹­á¹­hÄnaá¹ kantÄnaá¹ manÄpÄnaá¹ manoramÄnaá¹ lokÄmisapaá¹­isaá¹yuttÄnaá¹ paá¹­ilÄbhaá¹ vÄ paá¹­ilÄbhato samanupassato pubbe vÄ paá¹­iladdhapubbaá¹ atÄ«taá¹ niruddhaá¹ vipariá¹‡ataá¹ samanussarato uppajjati somanassaá¹. Yaá¹ evarÅ«paá¹ somanassaá¹ idaá¹ vuccati nekkhammasitaá¹ somanassaá¹.
- SotaviÃ±Ã±eyyÄnaá¹ saddÄnaá¹ â€¦
- ghÄnaviÃ±Ã±eyyÄnaá¹ gandhÄnaá¹ â€¦
- jivhÄviÃ±Ã±eyyÄnaá¹ rasÄnaá¹ â€¦
- kÄyaviÃ±Ã±eyyÄnaá¹ phoá¹­á¹­habbÄnaá¹ â€¦
- manoviÃ±Ã±eyyÄnaá¹ dhammÄnaá¹ â€¦
### cha nekkhammasitÄni somanassÄni
- RÅ«pÄnaá¹ tveva aniccataá¹ viditvÄ vipariá¹‡ÄmavirÄganirodhaá¹, â€˜pubbe ceva rÅ«pÄ etarahi ca sabbe te rÅ«pÄ aniccÄ dukkhÄ vipariá¹‡ÄmadhammÄâ€™ti evametaá¹ yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ sammappaÃ±Ã±Äya passato uppajjati somanassaá¹. Yaá¹ evarÅ«paá¹ somanassaá¹ idaá¹ vuccati nekkhammasitaá¹ somanassaá¹
- SaddÄnaá¹ tveva â€¦
- gandhÄnaá¹ tveva â€¦
- rasÄnaá¹ tveva â€¦
- phoá¹­á¹­habbÄnaá¹ tveva â€¦
- dhammÄnaá¹ tveva aniccataá¹ viditvÄ vipariá¹‡ÄmavirÄganirodhaá¹, â€˜pubbe ceva dhammÄ etarahi ca sabbe te dhammÄ aniccÄ dukkhÄ vipariá¹‡ÄmadhammÄâ€™ti evametaá¹ yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ sammappaÃ±Ã±Äya passato uppajjati somanassaá¹. Yaá¹ evarÅ«paá¹ somanassaá¹ idaá¹ vuccati nekkhammasitaá¹ somanassaá¹.
### cha gehasitÄni domanassÄni
- CakkhuviÃ±Ã±eyyÄnaá¹ rÅ«pÄnaá¹ â€¦ peâ€¦
- sotaviÃ±Ã±eyyÄnaá¹ saddÄnaá¹ â€¦
- ghÄnaviÃ±Ã±eyyÄnaá¹ gandhÄnaá¹ â€¦

- kÄyaviÃ±Ã±eyyÄnaá¹ phoá¹­á¹­habbÄnaá¹ â€¦
- manoviÃ±Ã±eyyÄnaá¹ dhammÄnaá¹ iá¹­á¹­hÄnaá¹ kantÄnaá¹ manÄpÄnaá¹ manoramÄnaá¹ lokÄmisapaá¹­isaá¹yuttÄnaá¹ appaá¹­ilÄbhaá¹ vÄ appaá¹­ilÄbhato samanupassato pubbe vÄ appaá¹­iladdhapubbaá¹ atÄ«taá¹ niruddhaá¹ vipariá¹‡ataá¹ samanussarato uppajjati domanassaá¹. ### cha nekkhammasitÄni domanassÄni
- RÅ«pÄnaá¹ tveva aniccataá¹ viditvÄ vipariá¹‡ÄmavirÄganirodhaá¹, â€˜pubbe ceva rÅ«pÄ etarahi ca sabbe te rÅ«pÄ aniccÄ dukkhÄ vipariá¹‡ÄmadhammÄâ€™ti evametaá¹ yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ sammappaÃ±Ã±Äya disvÄ anuttaresu vimokkhesu pihaá¹ upaá¹­á¹­hÄpeti: â€˜kudÄssu nÄmÄhaá¹ tadÄyatanaá¹ upasampajja viharissÄmi yadariyÄ etarahi Äyatanaá¹ upasampajja viharantÄ«â€™ti iti anuttaresu vimokkhesu pihaá¹ upaá¹­á¹­hÄpayato uppajjati pihapaccayÄ domanassaá¹. Yaá¹ evarÅ«paá¹ domanassaá¹ idaá¹ vuccati nekkhammasitaá¹ domanassaá¹.
- SaddÄnaá¹ tveva â€¦peâ€¦
- gandhÄnaá¹ tveva â€¦
- rasÄnaá¹ tveva â€¦
- phoá¹­á¹­habbÄnaá¹ tveva â€¦
- dhammÄnaá¹ tveva aniccataá¹ viditvÄ vipariá¹‡ÄmavirÄganirodhaá¹, â€˜pubbe ceva dhammÄ etarahi ca sabbe te dhammÄ aniccÄ dukkhÄ vipariá¹‡ÄmadhammÄâ€™ti evametaá¹ yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ sammappaÃ±Ã±Äya disvÄ anuttaresu vimokkhesu pihaá¹ upaá¹­á¹­hÄpeti: â€˜kudÄssu nÄmÄhaá¹ tadÄyatanaá¹ upasampajja viharissÄmi yadariyÄ etarahi Äyatanaá¹ upasampajja viharantÄ«â€™ti iti anuttaresu vimokkhesu pihaá¹ upaá¹­á¹­hÄpayato uppajjati pihapaccayÄ domanassaá¹. Yaá¹ evarÅ«paá¹ domanassaá¹ idaá¹ vuccati nekkhammasitaá¹ domanassaá¹.
### cha gehasitÄ upekkhÄ
- CakkhunÄ rÅ«paá¹ disvÄ uppajjati upekkhÄ bÄlassa mÅ«á¸·hassa puthujjanassa anodhijinassa avipÄkajinassa anÄdÄ«navadassÄvino assutavato puthujjanassa. YÄ evarÅ«pÄ upekkhÄ, rÅ«paá¹ sÄ nÄtivattati. TasmÄ sÄ upekkhÄ â€˜gehasitÄâ€™ti vuccati.
- Sotena saddaá¹ sutvÄ â€¦
- ghÄnena gandhaá¹ ghÄyitvÄ â€¦
- jivhÄya rasaá¹ sÄyitvÄ â€¦
- kÄyena phoá¹­á¹­habbaá¹ phusitvÄ â€¦
- manasÄ dhammaá¹ viÃ±Ã±Äya uppajjati upekkhÄ bÄlassa mÅ«á¸·hassa puthujjanassa anodhijinassa avipÄkajinassa anÄdÄ«navadassÄvino assutavato puthujjanassa. YÄ evarÅ«pÄ upekkhÄ, dhammaá¹ sÄ nÄtivattati. TasmÄ sÄ upekkhÄ â€˜gehasitÄâ€™ti vuccati.
### cha nekkhammasitÄ upekkhÄ

- SaddÄnaá¹ tveva â€¦
- gandhÄnaá¹ tveva â€¦

- phoá¹­á¹­habbÄnaá¹ tveva â€¦

        • Saá¸·Äyatanavibhaá¹…gasutta MN 137 PTS 3.216â€“3.222

        3.6 - paá¹­iccasamuppÄdo

        Dependent Origination

        (DN15):

        • hetu (root, cause, reason, condition)
        • nidÄnaá¹ (cause, ground, underlying and determining factor)
        • samudayo (rise, origin)
        • paccayo (support, requirement, reason, cause, ground, motive, means, condition)

        kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa samudayo (origin of the entire mass of suffering)

        dvÄdasaá¹…ga

        12 link dependent origination

        stateDiagram-v2
  [*] --> avijjÄ
  state fork_state <<fork>>
  state join_state <<join>>
  avijjÄ --> saá¹…khÄrÄ
  saá¹…khÄrÄ --> viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹
  viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ --> nÄmarÅ«paá¹
  nÄmarÅ«paá¹ --> viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ : SN 12.67
  nÄmarÅ«paá¹ --> saá¸·Äyatanaá¹
  saá¸·Äyatanaá¹ --> phasso
  phasso --> vedanÄ
  vedanÄ --> taá¹‡hÄ
  taá¹‡hÄ --> upÄdÄnaá¹
  upÄdÄnaá¹ --> bhavo
  bhavo --> jÄti
  jÄti --> fork_state
  fork_state --> jarÄmaraá¹‡aá¹
  fork_state --> sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupÄyÄsÄ
  jarÄmaraá¹‡aá¹ --> join_state
  sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupÄyÄsÄ --> join_state
  state jarÄmaraá¹‡aá¹ {
    [*] --> jarÄ
    [*] --> maraá¹‡aá¹
  }
  state sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupÄyÄsÄ {
    [*] --> soko
    [*] --> paridevo
    [*] --> dukkho
    [*] --> domanassaá¹ƒ
    [*] --> upÄyÄso
  }
  join_state --> [*]

        Transcendental Dependent Origination

        flowchart TB
  subgraph paá¹­iccasamuppÄdo
    direction LR
    avijjÄ --> saá¹…khÄrÄ
    saá¹…khÄrÄ --> viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹
    viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ --> nÄmarÅ«paá¹
    nÄmarÅ«paá¹ --> saá¸·Äyatanaá¹
    saá¸·Äyatanaá¹ --> phasso
    phasso --> vedanÄ
    vedanÄ --> taá¹‡hÄ
    taá¹‡hÄ --> upÄdÄnaá¹
    upÄdÄnaá¹ --> bhavo
    bhavo --> jÄti
  end
  subgraph transcendental
    direction LR
    saddho --> pÄmojjaá¹ƒ
    pÄmojjaá¹ƒ --> pÄ«ti
    pÄ«ti --> passaddhi
    passaddhi --> sukho
    sukho --> samÄdhi
    samÄdhi --> yathÄbhÅ«taÃ±Äá¹‡adassanaá¹ƒ
    yathÄbhÅ«taÃ±Äá¹‡adassanaá¹ƒ --> nibbidÄ
    nibbidÄ --> virÄgo
    virÄgo --> vimutti
    vimutti --> khayeÃ±Äá¹‡aá¹
  end
  paá¹­iccasamuppÄdo --> transcendental

        Wrong vs Right practice (SN 12.3)

        sequenceDiagram
  alt micchÄpaá¹­ipadÄ
    avijjÄ->>saá¹…khÄrÄ: paccayÄ
    saá¹…khÄrÄ ->> viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹: paccayÄ
    viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ ->> nÄmarÅ«paá¹: paccayÄ
    nÄmarÅ«paá¹ ->> saá¸·Äyatanaá¹: paccayÄ
    saá¸·Äyatanaá¹ ->> phasso: paccayÄ
    phasso ->> vedanÄ: paccayÄ
    vedanÄ ->> taá¹‡hÄ: paccayÄ
    taá¹‡hÄ ->> upÄdÄnaá¹: paccayÄ
    upÄdÄnaá¹ ->> bhavo: paccayÄ
    bhavo ->> jÄti: paccayÄ
  else sammÄpaá¹­ipadÄ
    avijjÄ->>saá¹…khÄrÄ: asesavirÄganirodhÄ
    saá¹…khÄrÄ ->> viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹: asesavirÄganirodhÄ
    viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ ->> nÄmarÅ«paá¹: asesavirÄganirodhÄ
    nÄmarÅ«paá¹ ->> saá¸·Äyatanaá¹: asesavirÄganirodhÄ
    saá¸·Äyatanaá¹ ->> phasso: asesavirÄganirodhÄ
    phasso ->> vedanÄ: asesavirÄganirodhÄ
    vedanÄ ->> taá¹‡hÄ: asesavirÄganirodhÄ
    taá¹‡hÄ ->> upÄdÄnaá¹: asesavirÄganirodhÄ
    upÄdÄnaá¹ ->> bhavo: asesavirÄganirodhÄ
    bhavo ->> jÄti: asesavirÄganirodhÄ
  end

        Analysis (SN 12.2)

        # paá¹­iccasamuppÄdo

        paá¹­iccasamuppannÄ dhammÄ (Dependent origination characteristics) SN 12.20

        This sutta is written in a satirical style (similar to that in AN 3.136) where the Buddha uses the formula for dependent origination to refute core Vedic beliefs, including the Vedic creation myth. The satirical text plays on the Vedic preoccupation with dhamma as regular, invariant natural principles.

        The parallels between the Dependent Origination links and core Vedic beliefs are explored by Joanna Jurewicz in Playing with Fire: The pratÄ«tyasamutpÄda from the perspective of Vedic thought, Journal of the Pali Text Society 26 (2000) pp. 77 â€“ 103.

        flowchart LR
  paá¹­iccasamuppÄdo --> aniccaá¹
  paá¹­iccasamuppÄdo --> saá¹…khataá¹
  paá¹­iccasamuppÄdo --> paá¹­iccasamuppannaá¹
  paá¹­iccasamuppÄdo --> khayadhammaá¹
  paá¹­iccasamuppÄdo --> vayadhammaá¹
  paá¹­iccasamuppÄdo --> virÄgadhammaá¹
  paá¹­iccasamuppÄdo --> nirodhadhammaá¹

        Naá¸·akalÄpÄ«sutta (SN 12.67)

        flowchart LR
  c1>na sayaá¹…kataá¹]
  c2>na paraá¹…kataá¹]
  c3>na sayaá¹…kataÃ±ca paraá¹…kataÃ±ca]
  c4>nÄpi asayaá¹…kÄraá¹ aparaá¹…kÄraá¹ adhiccasamuppannaá¹]
  subgraph paá¹­iccasamuppÄdo
    direction TB
    viÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aá¹ --> nÄmarÅ«paá¹

    phasso --> vedanÄ
    vedanÄ --> taá¹‡hÄ
    taá¹‡hÄ --> upÄdÄnaá¹
    upÄdÄnaá¹ --> bhavo
    bhavo --> jÄti
    jÄti --> jarÄmaraá¹‡aá¹
  end
  c1 --> paá¹­iccasamuppÄdo
  c2 --> paá¹­iccasamuppÄdo

  paá¹­iccasamuppÄdo --> bhikkhu

        Training (SN 12.93)

        3.7 - cattÄro satipaá¹­á¹­hÄnÄ

        the four kinds of mindfulness meditation

        cattÄri ariyasaccÄni

        viharati ÄtÄpÄ« sampajÄno satimÄ vineyya loke abhijjhÄdomanassaá¹ (keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world)

        4 - Abhidhamma Piá¹­aka

        Summary of key concepts from the Abhidhamma

        4.1 - Abhidhamm Sangaha

        Ä€cariya Anuruddhaâ€™s Abhidhammattha Sangaha is the main primer for the study of Abhidhamma used throughout the TheravÄdin Buddhist world.

        thutivacana (Words of Praise)

        SammÄsambuddham atulaá¹
        Sasaddhammagaá¹‡uttamaá¹
        AbhivÄdiya bhÄsissaá¹
        Abhidhammatthasangahaá¹.

        4.1.1 - CatudhÄ Paramattha

        The Fourfold Ultimate Reality

        Tattha vuttâ€™Ã¡bhidhammatthÃ¡
        CatudhÃ¡ paramatthato
        CittaÃ­ cetasikaÃ­ rÃºpaÃ­
        NibbÃ¡nam iti sabbathÃ¡.

        C4Context
      title catudhÃ¡ paramattha
      Enterprise_Boundary(b0, "Abhidhamma") {
        System(citta, "citta", "consciousness")
        System(cetasika, "cetasika", "mental factors")
        System(rupa, "rÅ«pa", "matter")
        System(nibbana, "NibbÄna", "Nirvana")
      }

        4.1.2 - CittasangahavibhÄga

        Compendium of Consciousness

        Tattha cittaá¹ tÄva catubbidhaá¹ hoti:

        1. kÄmÄvacaraá¹;
        2. rÅ«pÄ-vacaraá¹;
        3. arÅ«pÄvacaraá¹;
        4. lokuttaraÃ± cÄ ti.
        lakkhaá¹‡a (salient quality)
        vijÄnana (knowing of an object)
        rasa (function), kicca (performance of a concrete task), sampatti (achievement of a goal)
        pubbangama (forerunner of mental factors)
        paccupaá¹­á¹­hÄna (manifestation)
        sandhÄna (continuity of process)
        padaá¹­á¹­hÄna (proximate cause)
        nÄmarÅ«pa (mind and matter)

package "jÄti (nature)" as jati {
  class kusala {
    Karmically wholesome

    Karmically unwholesome

  package avyÄkata {
    class vipÄka {
      Karmic resultant
    }
    class kiriya {
      Functional

  }

package "kÄmÄvacara (Sense Sphere)" as kamavacara {
  class sobhana {
    Beautiful
    ..
    #kusala/vipÄka/kiriya
    #somanassa/upekkhÄ
    #+/- Ã±Äá¹‡a
    #asaá¹khÄrika/sasaá¹khÄrika
  }
  class kusalavipÄka <<enum>> {
    Wholesome-Resultant
    ..
    cakkhuviÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡a + upekkhÄ (eye)
    sotaviÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡a + upekkhÄ (ear)
    ghÄnaviÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡a + upekkhÄ (nose)
    jivhÄviÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡a + upekkhÄ (tongue)
    kÄyaviÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡a + sukkha (body)
    sampaá¹­icchanacitta + upekkhÄ (receiving)
    santÄ«raá¹‡acitta + somanassa (investigating)
    santÄ«raá¹‡acitta + upekkhÄ (investigating)
  }
  class dosa {
    Hatred
    ..
    +domanassa
    +paá¹­igha
    #asaá¹khÄrika/sasaá¹khÄrika
  }
  class lobha {
    Greed
    ..
    #somanassa/upekkhÄ
    #+/- diá¹­á¹­higata
    #asaá¹khÄrika/sasaá¹khÄrika
  }
  class moha {
    Delusion
    ..
    #upekkhÄ
    +vicikicchÄ/uddhacca
  }
  class akusalavipÄka <<enum>> {
    Unwholesome-Resultant
    ..
    cakkhuviÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡a + upekkhÄ (eye)
    sotaviÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡a + upekkhÄ (ear)
    ghÄnaviÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡a + upekkhÄ (nose)
    jivhÄviÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡a + upekkhÄ (tongue)
    kÄyaviÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡a + dukkha (body)
    sampaá¹­icchanacitta + upekkhÄ (receiving)
    santÄ«raá¹‡acitta + upekkhÄ (investigating)
  }
  class ahetukakiriya <<enum>> {
    Functional
    ..
    paÃ±cadvÄrÄvajjanacitta + upekkhÄ (sense door)
    manodvÄrÄvajjanacitta + upekkhÄ (mind door)
    hasituppÄdacitta + somanassa (smile producing)
  }
}

class domanassa {
  displeasure
}
class paá¹­igha {
  aversion
}
class somanassa {
  joy
}
class upekkhÄ {
  equanimity
}
class sukkha {
  pleasure
}
class dukkha {
  pain
}
class Ã±Äá¹‡a {
  knowledge
}
class diá¹­á¹­higata {
  wrong view
}
class vicikicchÄ {
  doubt
}
class uddhacca {
  restlessness
}

kiriya *-- "3" ahetukakiriya
kiriya *-- "8" sobhana
vipÄka *-- "7" akusalavipÄka
vipÄka *-- "8" kusalavipÄka

akusala *-- "7" akusalavipÄka : ahetuka

kusalavipÄka --> somanassa : sahagata

sobhana --> upekkhÄ : sahagata
sobhana --+ Ã±Äá¹‡a : sampayutta
akusala *-- "8" lobha : mÅ«la
akusala *-- "2" dosa : mÅ«la
akusala *-- "2" moha : mÅ«la
dosa --> domanassa : sahagata
dosa --+ paá¹­igha : sampayutta
lobha --+ diá¹­á¹­higata : sampayutta
lobha --> somanassa : sahagata
lobha --> upekkhÄ : sahagata
moha --+ vicikicchÄ : sampayutta
moha --+ uddhacca : sampayutta
moha --> upekkhÄ : sahagata

package "lokuttaraÃ± (Supramundane)" as lokuttaran {

class sotÄpatti {

}
class arahatta {
  arahantship
}
kusala *-- "4 (x5)" lokuttaracitta
vipÄka *-- "4 (x5)" lokuttaracitta
lokuttaracitta --> sotÄpatti
lokuttaracitta --> sakadÄgÄmÄ«
lokuttaracitta --> anÄgÄmÄ«
lokuttaracitta --> arahatta
@enduml

        cittasangahavibhÄga 89

        cittasangahavibhÄga 121

        4.1.3 - CetasikasangahavibhÄga

        Compendium of Mental Factors

        EkuppÄda-nirodhÄ ca ekÄlambana-vatthukÄ
        CetoyuttÄ dvipaÃ±Ã±Äsa dhammÄ cetasikÄ matÄ.

        @startmindmap
*:==aÃ±Ã±asamÄnacetasika

**:===sabbacittasÄdhÄraá¹‡a

***_ 1. Contact (phassa)

        4.1.4 - Citta-Cetasika

        5 - ğ‘€“ğ‘€˜ğ‘†ğ‘€˜ğ‘€¸ğ‘€¬ğ‘€¦ (KaccÄyana)

        My translation of the earliest available PÄli grammar into modern English, accompanied by diagrams.

        ğ‘€“

        ka /k/

        ğ‘€˜ğ‘†

        c /c/

        ğ‘€˜

        cÄ /ca:/

        ğ‘€¬

        ya /j/

        ğ‘€¦

        na /n/

        The current status of this work is “Idea” - this is currently not in a form suitable for consumption, please ignore unless you will like to contribute to the translation project.

        This work is open source using the Apache licence and the source code is available on Github. If you like this work and wish to show your appreciation, please consider sponsoring me.

        5.1 - Introduction

        This section provides an overview of KaccÄyana in terms of context, structure, other available translations, motivation and reference sources.

        Context

        KaccÄyana is the oldest extant PÄli grammar, and was composed around the sixth century CE, most probably in India. It is partly based on PÄá¹‡ini and KÄtantra:

        • PÄá¹‡ini, Aá¹£á¹­ÄdhyÄyÄ« â€œEight Lessonsâ€ 5thâ€“4th c. B.C.E. ÅšalÄtura Northwest India
        • Åšarvavarman, KÄtantravyÄkaraá¹‡a 2nd c. C.E. South India

        The author of KaccÄyana is attributed to MahÄ KaccÄyana, but modern scholars believe it is authored by multiple compilers and gradually evolved over time. According to James Dâ€™Alwis in An introduction to KachchÄyana’s grammar of the PÄli language:

        • the grammatical aphorisms (sutta), are ascribed to a certain KaccÄyana,
        • the “gloss” or explanation (vutti) is ascribed to a certain Saá¹…ghanandin
        • the examples (payoga) is ascribed to a certain Brahmadatta

        According to the Thai monk Dhammakitti in Saddhammasaá¹…gaha (Saddhamma-s IX, 18-20, 35):

        kaccÄyano kato yogo saá¹ƒghanandi pavuttikÄ, á¹­Ä«kÄ vimalabodhÄ« ca brahmaputto ca kÄrakÄ.
        (SADDHÄ€NANDA, 1890: 63)
        KaccÄyana composed the yoga [â€œruleâ€], Saá¹…ghanandin the pavuttikÄ [â€œnotesâ€], and VimalabodhÄ« the á¹­Ä«kÄ [â€œcommentaryâ€], and Brahmaputto the kÄraka [â€œsection on factor of actionâ€].

        The structure of KaccÄyana

        There are 673 rules (sutta), depending on the edition, spread across the following chapters and sections:

        1. Sandhi
          1. Definitions
          2. Vowel sandhi
          3. Consonant sandhi
          4. niggahÄ«ta (á¹ƒ) sandhi
          5. Miscellanea
        2. NÄma
          1. Definitions, Internal sandhis, Default Declensions
          2. Pronominal declension, an-stems
          3. Pronominal dec. continued, mano-gaá¹‡a, an-stems, tar-stems.
          4. an-stems cont., feminine stems, adv. pronouns, nta-stems
          5. Adverbial affixes
        3. KÄ€RAKA
        4. SAMÄ€SA
        5. TADDHITA
        6. Ä€khyÄta
          1. Definitions
          2. Special stems, causatives, bhÄva, vb. classes
          3. Reduplication, Special stems
          4. Special affixes and stems
        7. KibbidhÄna
          1. Definition of kicca and kit affixes
          2. Use of affixes with tenses, voices, etc.
          3. niá¹­á¹­hÄ affixes
          4. Modification of vb. stems in primary derivation
        8. Uá¹†Ä€DI

        The structure of a sutta

        Each sutta (rule, or grammatical aphorism) is described in a series of subsections or “fields”. The vutti is always present, the other fields may be present.

        fieldfunctiontags
        vuttigloss, or explanationrepeats and expands the words from the sutta
        udÄharaá¹‡aexamplestaá¹ƒyathÄ
        kimudÄharaá¹‡acounter-exampleskasmÄ / kimatthaá¹ƒ
        payojanaapplication/purpose/scope of the rule (“where is it used”)kvattho / kimpayojanaá¹ƒ
        gahaá¹‡aphalaresult of mentioned words, comments on anuvá¹›tti, meaning of ca or vÄ, etc.(xxx)(sadda)ggahaá¹‡ena… eg. rule 35: casaddaggahaá¹‡ena iheva makÄrassa pakÄro hoti.

        Example (the first number is the KaccÄyana rule number, the second is the equivalent PadarÅ«pasiddhi rule number):

        151, 250.Bahuvacanesu vono.
        Sabbesaá¹ƒ tumhaamhasaddÄnaá¹ƒ savibhattÄ«naá¹ƒ yadÄ padasmÄ paresaá¹ƒ vonoÄdesÄ honti yathÄsaá¹…khyaá¹ƒ tatiyÄbahuvacanesu paresu. Kataá¹ƒ vo kammaá¹ƒ, kataá¹ƒ no kammaá¹ƒ. Padatoti kimatthaá¹ƒ? Tumhehi kataá¹ƒ, amhehi kataá¹ƒ. Bahuvacanaggahaá¹‡ena yomhi paá¹­hame vo noÄdesÄ honti. GÄmaá¹ƒ vo gaccheyyÄtha, gÄmaá¹ƒ no gaccheyyÄma.

        fieldtext
        no151
        PadarÅ«pasiddhi250
        suttaBahuvacanesu vono.
        vuttiSabbesaá¹ƒ tumhaamhasaddÄnaá¹ƒ savibhattÄ«naá¹ƒ yadÄ padasmÄ paresaá¹ƒ vonoÄdesÄ honti yathÄsaá¹…khyaá¹ƒ tatiyÄbahuvacanesu paresu.
        udÄharaá¹‡aKataá¹ƒ vo kammaá¹ƒ, kataá¹ƒ no kammaá¹ƒ.
        kimudÄharaá¹‡aPadatoti kimatthaá¹ƒ? Tumhehi kataá¹ƒ, amhehi kataá¹ƒ.
        payojana
        gahaá¹‡aphalaBahuvacanaggahaá¹‡ena yomhi paá¹­hame vo noÄdesÄ honti. GÄmaá¹ƒ vo gaccheyyÄtha, gÄmaá¹ƒ no gaccheyyÄma.

        Other examples:

        361, 388.á¹†avisamÄdÄ«hi.
        á¹†apaccayo hoti visamÄdÄ«hi â€˜â€˜tassa bhÄvoâ€™â€™iccetasmiá¹ƒ atthe. Visamassa bhÄvo vesamaá¹ƒ, sucissa bhÄvo socaá¹ƒ.

        fieldtext
        no361
        PadarÅ«pasiddhi388
        suttaá¹†avisamÄdÄ«hi.
        vuttiá¹†apaccayo hoti visamÄdÄ«hi â€˜â€˜tassa bhÄvoâ€™â€™iccetasmiá¹ƒ atthe.
        udÄharaá¹‡aVisamassa bhÄvo vesamaá¹ƒ, sucissa bhÄvo socaá¹ƒ.
        kimudÄharaá¹‡a
        payojana
        gahaá¹‡aphala

        364, 398.TadassatthÄ«ti vÄ« ca.
        “Tadassatthi"iccetasmiá¹ƒ atthe vÄ«paccayo hoti. MedhÄ yassa atthi, tasmiá¹ƒ vÄ vijjatÄ«timedhÄvÄ«. Evaá¹ƒ mÄyÄvÄ«. Caggahaá¹‡ena sopaccayo hoti. SumedhÄ yassa atthi, tasmiá¹ƒ vÄ vijjatÄ«ti sumedhaso.

        vutti“Tadassatthi"iccetasmiá¹ƒ atthe vÄ«paccayo hoti.

        gahaá¹‡aphalaCaggahaá¹‡ena sopaccayo hoti. SumedhÄ yassa atthi, tasmiá¹ƒ vÄ vijjatÄ«ti sumedhaso.

        59, 182.Te itthikhyÄ po.
        Te ivaá¹‡á¹‡uvaá¹‡á¹‡Ä yadÄ itthikhyÄ, tadÄ pasaÃ±Ã±Ä honti. RattiyÄ, itthiyÄ, dhenuyÄ, vadhuyÄ. ItthikhyÄti kimatthaá¹ƒ? IsinÄ, bhikkhunÄ. Saiccanena kvattho? Pato yÄ.

        57, 71.Ä€lapane si ga saÃ±Ã±o.
        Ä€lapanatthe si gasaÃ±Ã±o hoti. Bhoti ayye, bhoti kaÃ±Ã±e, bhoti kharÄdiye. Ä€lapaneti kimatthaá¹ƒ? SÄ ayyÄ. SÄ«ti kimatthaá¹ƒ? Bhotiyo ayyÄyo. Gaiccanena kvattho? Ghate ca.

        gahaá¹‡aphala

        Types of suttas

        The rules can be classified into four categories, and additional subcategories, with examples given below:

        • saÃ±Ã±Ä (technical term)
          • anvattha (meaningful)

            8, 10.Aá¹ƒiti niggahitaá¹ƒ. saÃ±Ã±Ä anvattha
            Aá¹ƒ iti niggahitaá¹ƒ nÄma hoti. Tena kvattho? Aá¹ƒ byaÃ±jane niggahitaá¹ƒ.

          • rÅ«á¸·hÄ« (artificial)

            58, 29.Ivaá¹‡á¹‡uvaá¹‡á¹‡Ä jhalÄ. saÃ±Ã±Ä rÅ«á¸·hÄ«
            Ivaá¹‡á¹‡uvaá¹‡á¹‡Äiccete jhalasaÃ±Ã±Ä honti yathÄsaá¹…khyaá¹ƒ. Isino , aggino, gahapatino, daá¹‡á¸ino. Setuno, ketuno, bhikkhuno. Sayambhuno, abhibhuno. Jhalaiccanena kvattho? Jhalato sassa no vÄ.

        • adhikÄra (domain)
          • sÄ«hagatika (comprehensive)

            52, 60.Jinavacanayuttaá¹ƒhi. adhikÄra sÄ«hagatika
            “Jinavacanayuttaá¹ƒ hi” iccetaá¹ƒ adhikÄratthaá¹ƒ veditabbaá¹ƒ.

          • maá¹‡á¸Å«kagatika (selective)

            131, 0.Itthipumanapuá¹ƒsakasaá¹…khyaá¹ƒ. adhikÄra maá¹‡á¸Å«kagatika
            “Itthipumanapuá¹ƒsakasaá¹…khyaá¹ƒ” iccetaá¹ƒ adhikÄratthaá¹ƒ veditabbaá¹ƒ.

          • yathÄnupubbika (progressive)

            413, 427.KÄle. adhikÄra yathÄnupubbika
            “KÄle” iccetaá¹ƒ adhikÄratthaá¹ƒ veditabbaá¹ƒ.

        • paribhÄsÄ (metarule)
          • saÃ±Ã±aá¹…ga (definition metarule)

            9, 11.ParasamaÃ±Ã±Ä payoge. paribhÄsÄ saÃ±Ã±aá¹…ga
            YÄ ca pana paresu sakkataganthesu samaÃ±Ã±Ä ghosÄti vÄ aghosÄti vÄ, tÄ payoge sati etthÄpi yujjante. Tattha ghosÄ nÄma-ga gha á¹…a, ja jha Ã±a, á¸a á¸ha á¹‡a, da dha na, ba bha ma, ya ra la va ha á¸·a, iti ghosÄ nÄma. AghosÄ nÄma-ka kha, ca cha, á¹­a á¹­ha, ta tha, pa pha, sa, iti aghosÄ nÄma. Tena kvattho? Vagge ghosÄghosÄnaá¹ƒ tatiyapaá¹­hamÄ.

          • vidhyaá¹…ga (operational metarule)

            10, 12.Pubbamadhoá¹­hita massaraá¹ƒ sarena viyojaye. paribhÄsÄ vidhyaá¹…ga
            Tattha sandhiá¹ƒ kattukÄmo pubbabyaÃ±janaá¹ƒ adhoá¹­hitaá¹ƒ assaraá¹ƒ katvÄ saraÃ±ca upari katvÄ sarena viyojaye. TatrÄyamÄdi.

          • aÃ±Ã±aá¹…ga (other metarule)

            54, 62.Tato ca vibhattiyo. paribhÄsÄ aÃ±Ã±aá¹…ga
            Tato jinavacanayuttehi liá¹…gehi vibhattiyo parÄ honti.

        • vidhi (operation)
          • utsarga (general rule)

            12, 13.SarÄ sare lopaá¹ƒ. vidhi utsarga
            SarÄ kho sare pare lopaá¹ƒ papponti. YassindriyÄni samathaá¹…gatÄni. No hetaá¹ƒ bhante sametÄyasmÄ saá¹…ghena.

          • apavÄda (exception)

            13, 15.VÄ paro asarÅ«pÄ. vidhi apavÄda
            SaramhÄ asarÅ«pÄ paro saro lopaá¹ƒ pappoti vÄ. CattÄroâ€™me bhikkhave dhammÄ, kinnuâ€™ mÄvasamaá¹‡iyo. VÄti kasmÄ? PaÃ±cindriyÄni, tayassu dhammÄ jahitÄ bhavanti.

        According to Aleix Ruiz-FalquÃ©s in A Short Introduction to the PÄli KaccÄyana Grammar:

        Several saÃ±Ã±Ä â€œtechnical termsâ€,
        within an adhikÄra â€œdomainâ€,
        following paribhÄsÄ â€œmetarulesâ€,
        will be subject to vidhi â€œoperationsâ€
        in order to derive words or sentences.

        Megarules

        mahÄsutta or â€œmegarulesâ€ are four rules that are invoked in order to derive forms that cannot be derived otherwise.

        • 391, 423.YadanupapannÄ nipÄtanÄ sijjhanti.
          Ye saddÄ aniddiá¹­á¹­halakkhaá¹‡Ä, akkharapadabyaÃ±janato, itthipumanapuá¹ƒsakaliá¹…gato , nÄmupasagganipÄtato, abyayÄ«bhÄvasamÄsataddhitÄkhyÄtato, gaá¹‡anasaá¹…khyÄkÄlakÄrakappayogasaÃ±Ã±Äto, sandhipakativuddhilopÄgamavikÄraviparitato, vibhattivibhajanato ca, te nipÄtanÄ sijjhanti.
          â€œThose [words] that are not formed by the suttas, should be formed as irregular forms.â€
        • 403, 354.KvacÄdimajjhuttarÄnaá¹ƒ dÄ«gharassÄ paccayesu ca.
          Kvaci Ädimajjhauttaraiccetesaá¹ƒ dÄ«gharassÄ honti paccayesu ca apaccayesu ca.
          â€œSometimes, there is lengthening or shortening at the beginning, middle or end [vowels of a word], even before affixes.â€
        • 404, 370.Tesu vuddhilopÄgamavikÄraviparÄ«tÄdesÄ ca.
          Tesu Ädimajjhuttaresu yathÄjinavacanÄnuparodhena kvaci vuddhi hoti, kvaci lopo hoti, kvaci Ägamo hoti, kvaci vikÄro hoti, kvaci viparÄ«to hoti, kvaci Ädeso hoti.
          â€œAnd in those cases [cf. rule 405], [sometimes,] there is full grade, elision, augment, modification, change, or replacement.â€
        • 517, 488.Kvaci dhÄtuvibhattipaccayÄnaá¹ƒ dÄ«gha viparÄ«tÄdesalopÄgamÄ ca.
          Idha ÄkhyÄte aniddiá¹­á¹­hesu sÄdhanesu kvaci dhÄtuvibhattipaccayÄnaá¹ƒ dÄ«ghaviparÄ«tÄdesalopÄgamaiccetÄni kÄriyÄni jinavacanÄnurÅ«pÄni kÄtabbÄni.
          â€œSometimes [for verbal forms that cannot be derived otherwise, there is] lengthening, change, replacement or augment of the verbal root, the personal ending, or the affix(es).â€

        Rule 52 is halfway between a megarule and a normal rule:

        52, 60.Jinavacanayuttaá¹ƒhi.
        “Jinavacanayuttaá¹ƒ hi” iccetaá¹ƒ adhikÄratthaá¹ƒ veditabbaá¹ƒ.

        Ghost metarules

        “Ghost Metarules” are paribhÄsÄs that are consistently invoked in the commentaries, but that you will never see in the sÅ«tra treatise.

        Examples:

        • ekamhi vattabbe ekavacanaá¹ƒ bahumhi vattabbe bahuvacanan [e.g. Mmd 28,15â€“16]
          â€œThe singular is used when one [object] is to be stated, the plural is used when many [objects] are to be stated.â€
          [NOTE: in PÄá¹‡ini, 1.4.21 bahuá¹£u bahuvacanam (â€œplural for many [objects]â€) & 1.4.22 dvyekayor dvivacanaikavacane (â€œdual and singular for two or one [objects respectively]â€) are considered saá¹ƒjÃ±Ä (â€œdefinitionâ€) rules.]
        • vatticchÄnupubbikÄ saddapaá¹­ipatti [e.g. Mmd 64,17â€“18]
          â€œThe meaning of a word is determined by the intention of the speaker.â€
        • vuttatthÄnam appayogo [23 times in Mmd, e.g. 133,20]
          â€œWords whose meaning has already been stated are not used.â€
        • yogavibhÄgÄ iá¹­á¹­happasiddhi [Mmd, e.g. 252,29]
          â€œAfter the splitting up (vibhÄgÄ) of the sutta (yoga) [there is] the expected result [only].â€

        Usage of rÅ«á¸·hÄ«

        In a sutta, a rÅ«á¸·hÄ« (artificial technical term) will have a case ending that matches the role/usage of the term within a rule. For example jha (used for masculine/neuter nominal bases ending with i or Ä«):

        casejhausage
        â‘ jhoi/Ä« (*replacement)
        â‘¡jhaá¹ƒi/Ä« (substitute)
        â‘¢jhenanot used
        â‘£jhassanot used
        â‘¤jhamhÄ/jhatoâ€œafter i/Ä«â€
        â‘¥jhassaâ€œinstead of i/Ä«â€
        â‘¦jhasmiá¹ƒâ€œbefore i/Ä«â€

        Types of vidhi (operation)

        • Ädesa â€œreplacementâ€
        • Ägama â€œinsertionâ€
        • vikÄra â€œmodificationâ€
        • lopa â€œelisionâ€
        • viparÄ«ta â€œmetathesisâ€

        Structure of a vidhi (operation)

        An operation converts Before into After surrounded by Previous and Next, in the context of Marker and Semantic.

        block-beta
  columns 8
  
  
    Previous["Previous"]
    class Previous context
    
  
  block:operation:4
    columns 4
    
      Before("Before")
      class Before pre
      
    
    space:2
    
      After("After")
      class After post
      
    
    Before--"vidhi"-->After
  end
  
    Next["Next"]
    class Next context
    
  
  
    Marker[/"Marker"\]
    class Marker mod1
    
  
  
    Semantic[\"Semantic"/]
    class Semantic mod2
    
  
  class arrow operation
  classDef context fill:#D2C4D6,stroke:#615F5F
  classDef context0 fill:#D2C4D6,stroke:#A49E9E,stroke-dasharray: 3 3
  classDef operation fill:#64BFA4,stroke:#615F5F
  classDef operation0 fill:#64BFA4,stroke:#615F5F,stroke-dasharray: 3 3
  classDef pre fill:#64BFA4,stroke:#615F5F
  classDef pre0 fill:#64BFA4,stroke:#615F5F,stroke-dasharray: 3 3
  classDef post fill:#3CADD4,stroke:#615F5F
  classDef post0 fill:#3CADD4,stroke:#615F5F,stroke-dasharray: 3 3
  classDef mod1 fill:#EADA4F,stroke:#615F5F
  classDef mod10 fill:#EADA4F,stroke:#615F5F,stroke-dasharray: 3 3
  classDef mod2 fill:#F7CACA,stroke:#615F5F
  classDef mod20 fill:#F7CACA,stroke:#615F5F,stroke-dasharray: 3 3

        As an illustration, the sequence AXB is replaced with AYB:

        block-beta
  columns 8
  
  
    Previous["A"]
    class Previous context
    
  
  block:operation:4
    columns 4
    
      Before("X")
      class Before pre
      
    
    space:2
    
      After("Y")
      class After post
      
    
    Before--"becomes"-->After
  end
  
    Next["B"]
    class Next context
    
  
  
    space
  
  
    space
  
  class arrow operation
  classDef context fill:#D2C4D6,stroke:#615F5F
  classDef context0 fill:#D2C4D6,stroke:#A49E9E,stroke-dasharray: 3 3
  classDef operation fill:#64BFA4,stroke:#615F5F

        • ca

        • …

        Semantic: “in the sense of …”

        Case endings are used to determine the various roles in the rule

        tena + upasaá¹…kami
        â†’ ten(a) + upasaá¹…kami (rule 12)
        â†’ tenupasaá¹…kami

        Most vidhi â€œoperationalâ€ rules teach paccaya â€œaffixationâ€ or Ädesa â€œreplacementâ€ using previous definitions (saÃ±Ã±Ä-s). It is all about adding particles to a base, and then replacing them if/when needed. To understand vidhi-s, we should keep in mind the following code of case endings:

        • â‘¤ - â€œafter Xâ€
        • â‘¥ - â€œinstead of Xâ€
        • â‘  - â€œXâ€, Ädesa
        • â‘¦ - â€œbefore Xâ€
        • â‘¦ - â€œin the sense of Xâ€

        Other available translations

        • Satis Chandra Acharyva, Widyabhusana, Kaccayana’s Pali Grammar, The Mahabodhi Society, Calcutta (1901)
        • Phramaha Thiab Malai, KaccÄyana-VyÄkarana: A Critical Study, Department of Sanskrit and Pali Studies, University of Pune (1997)
        • A. Thitzana, KaccÄyana PÄli VyÄkaraá¹‡aá¹ Volumes 1 and 2, Pariyatti Press (2016)
        • U Silananda, U Nandisena, KaccÄyanabyÄkaraá¹‡aá¹, Institudo de Estudios Buddhistas Hispano (IEBH) (2005, 2017)

        Motivation

        I have decided to attempt a new translation of KaccÄyana’s grammar, because of several reasons:

        • I am not entirely satisfied with the existing translations. Some of them seem to lack clarity (primarily due to the writing style). Others don’t explain the examples well enough, and yet others are too verbose, inserting explanations not in the original text.
        • There are some spelling errors and mistakes in the edition published on Chaá¹­á¹­ha Saá¹…gÄyana Tipiá¹­aka, some of which have been incorporated into existing translations. I have taken the opportunity to correct the mistakes, uncovered by scholars such as O. H. Pind and A. Ruiz-FalquÃ©s.
        • Unlike some translations, I am honouring the use of option markers in KaccÄyana, and in most cases am faithfully translating vÄ as “optionally”, kvaci as “occasionally” and navÄ as “by exception.”
        • I am also cross referencing the use of technical terms with other classical PÄli grammars.
        • It is a good way to further my understanding of PÄli.
        • It is also a good opportunity for me to introduce the Brahmi script. As we know, there are no surviving Buddhist texts written in Brahmi, so there is no need to learn this script, however, I like it due to it’s elegance and simplicity.
        • I wanted to augment the translations with diagrams, and incorporate worked through grammatical analysis and rule derivations in the examples.
        • In comparison with the other classical PÄli grammars, KaccÄyana is brief and succinct, minimising repetition. It was used as a standard textbook for teaching PÄli in countries such as Burma for many years, and often used in various monasteries as a PÄli reference text.
        • I prefer KaccÄyana to most English PÄli textbooks and grammar books, as it describes PÄli without the distorting lens of Western linguistics.
        • My translation is presented using a modern responsive web design, featuring Google’s Noto Sans font.

        References

        • James Dâ€™Alwis, An introduction to KachchÄyana’s grammar of the PÄli language, with an introduction, appendix, notes, etc., Williams and Norgate, London (1863)
        • Dhammakitti, Dr. Satischandra Vidyabhusana; Punnananda Swami; Sailendranath Mitra, BaÌ„laÌ„vataÌ„raÌ„ - an Elementary PaÌ„li Grammar Abridged for the Undergraduate Course, University of Calcutta (1935)
        • Aleix Ruiz-FalquÃ©s, On the Authorship of KaccÄyana, the Oldest PÄli Grammar, Pariyatti: Studies In PÄli Language And Literature, Aditya Prakashan, New Dehli (2017)
        • Aleix Ruiz-FalquÃ©s, A Short Introduction to the PÄli KaccÄyana Grammar, Shan State Buddhist University, Taunggyi (Myanmar) (2020)
        • Mahesh A. Deokar, Technical Terms and Technique of The Pali and Sanskrit Grammars, Central Institute of Higher Tibetan Studies, Sarnath, Varanasi (2008)

        5.2 - 1. ğ‘€²ğ‘€¦ğ‘†ğ‘€¥ğ‘€ºğ‘€“ğ‘€§ğ‘†ğ‘€§ (Sandhikappa)

        sandhi is derived from saá¹ƒ + dhÄ meaning “putting together” and is used to refer to the transformation that result from the joining together of two words (or two parts of a word) for the sake of euphony.

        (a)
        To the Supreme, honoured in the three worlds, worthy of the ultimate salute,
        To the pure Dhamma of the Buddha and the highest collection (the Tipiá¹­aka);
        To fully understand the meaning of the excellent words of that Teacher,
        I will articulate thoroughly here the sutta (rules) in the sandhikappa (Sandhi Chapter)

        (b)
        The wise obtain using the excellent method proclaimed by the Conqueror,
        As well as fully understanding the meaning of his words;
        And the clear knowledge of the meaning in the words and letters,
        Excellent benefit for those who will listen to the words here in many ways.

        (Ka)
        Seá¹­á¹­haá¹ƒ tilokamahitaá¹ƒ abhivandiyaggaá¹ƒ,
        BuddhaÃ±ca dhammamamalaá¹ƒ gaá¹‡amuttamaÃ±ca;
        Satthussa tassa vacanatthavaraá¹ƒ suboddhuá¹ƒ,
        VakkhÄmi suttahitamettha susandhikappaá¹ƒ.

        (Kha)
        Seyyaá¹ƒ jineritanayena budhÄ labhanti,
        TaÃ±cÄpi tassa vacanatthasubodhanena;
        AtthaÃ±ca akkharapadesu amohabhÄvÄ,
        Seyyatthiko padamato vividhaá¹ƒ suá¹‡eyyaá¹ƒ.

        (ğ‘€“)
        ğ‘€²ğ‘‚ğ‘€ğ‘†ğ‘€ğ‘€ ğ‘€¢ğ‘€ºğ‘€®ğ‘„ğ‘€“ğ‘€«ğ‘€³ğ‘€ºğ‘€¢ğ‘€ ğ‘€…ğ‘€ªğ‘€ºğ‘€¯ğ‘€¦ğ‘†ğ‘€¤ğ‘€ºğ‘€¬ğ‘€•ğ‘†ğ‘€•ğ‘€
        ğ‘€©ğ‘€¼ğ‘€¤ğ‘†ğ‘€¥ğ‘€œğ‘†ğ‘€˜ ğ‘€¥ğ‘€«ğ‘†ğ‘€«ğ‘€«ğ‘€«ğ‘€®ğ‘€ ğ‘€•ğ‘€¡ğ‘€«ğ‘€¼ğ‘€¢ğ‘†ğ‘€¢ğ‘€«ğ‘€œğ‘†ğ‘€˜
        ğ‘€²ğ‘€¢ğ‘†ğ‘€£ğ‘€¼ğ‘€²ğ‘†ğ‘€² ğ‘€¢ğ‘€²ğ‘†ğ‘€² ğ‘€¯ğ‘€˜ğ‘€¦ğ‘€¢ğ‘†ğ‘€£ğ‘€¯ğ‘€­ğ‘€ ğ‘€²ğ‘€¼ğ‘€©ğ‘€¼ğ‘€¤ğ‘†ğ‘€¥ğ‘€¼ğ‘€
        ğ‘€¯ğ‘€“ğ‘†ğ‘€”ğ‘€¸ğ‘€«ğ‘€º ğ‘€²ğ‘€¼ğ‘€¢ğ‘†ğ‘€¢ğ‘€³ğ‘€ºğ‘€¢ğ‘€«ğ‘‚ğ‘€¢ğ‘†ğ‘€£ ğ‘€²ğ‘€¼ğ‘€²ğ‘€¦ğ‘†ğ‘€¥ğ‘€ºğ‘€“ğ‘€§ğ‘†ğ‘€§ğ‘€

        ğ‘€²ğ‘‚ğ‘€¬ğ‘†ğ‘€¬ğ‘€ ğ‘€šğ‘€ºğ‘€¦ğ‘‚ğ‘€­ğ‘€ºğ‘€¢ğ‘€¦ğ‘€¬ğ‘‚ğ‘€¦ ğ‘€©ğ‘€¼ğ‘€¥ğ‘€¸ ğ‘€®ğ‘€ªğ‘€¦ğ‘†ğ‘€¢ğ‘€º
        ğ‘€¢ğ‘€œğ‘†ğ‘€˜ğ‘€¸ğ‘€§ğ‘€º ğ‘€¢ğ‘€²ğ‘†ğ‘€² ğ‘€¯ğ‘€˜ğ‘€¦ğ‘€¢ğ‘†ğ‘€£ğ‘€²ğ‘€¼ğ‘€©ğ‘„ğ‘€¥ğ‘€¦ğ‘‚ğ‘€¦
        ğ‘€…ğ‘€¢ğ‘†ğ‘€£ğ‘€œğ‘†ğ‘€˜ ğ‘€…ğ‘€“ğ‘†ğ‘€”ğ‘€­ğ‘€§ğ‘€¤ğ‘‚ğ‘€²ğ‘€¼ ğ‘€…ğ‘€«ğ‘„ğ‘€³ğ‘€ªğ‘€¸ğ‘€¯ğ‘€¸
        ğ‘€²ğ‘‚ğ‘€¬ğ‘†ğ‘€¬ğ‘€¢ğ‘†ğ‘€£ğ‘€ºğ‘€“ğ‘„ ğ‘€§ğ‘€¤ğ‘€«ğ‘€¢ğ‘„ ğ‘€¯ğ‘€ºğ‘€¯ğ‘€ºğ‘€¥ğ‘€ ğ‘€²ğ‘€¼ğ‘€¡ğ‘‚ğ‘€¬ğ‘†ğ‘€¬ğ‘€

        (à¤•)
        à¤¸à¥‡à¤Ÿà¥à¤ à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¿à¤²à¥‹à¤•à¤®à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤…à¤­à¤¿à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¿à¤¯à¤—à¥à¤—à¤‚,

        à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¥à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¸ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¸ à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤¤à¥à¤¥à¤µà¤°à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤¬à¥‹à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥à¤‚,
