  namespace kattar {
    class ahaá¹ƒ {
      <<puggalanÄma>>
      âš§â¨€ğŸ‘†â‘ 
      english(I)
    }
    class tassa {
      <<nidassananÄma>>
      ğŸš¹â¨€ğŸ¤Ÿâ‘¥
      english(of that)
    }
    class yaÃ±Ã±assa {
      <<nÄma>>
      ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¥
      english(of sacrifice)
    }
    class yÄjetÄ {
      <<past participle>>
      âªğŸš¹â¨€â‘

    }
  }
  tassa <-- yaÃ±Ã±assa
  yaÃ±Ã±assa <-- yÄjetÄ
  sentence *-- ahaá¹ƒ : kattar
  sentence *-- tassa : chaá¹­á¹­hÄ«
  sentence *-- yaÃ±Ã±assa : chaá¹­á¹­hÄ«
  sentence *-- yÄjetÄ : kattar

        Genitive Absolute

        The “genitive absolute” consists of a noun (or pronoun) followed by a participle, both inflected in the genitive. This nexus stands apart from the other words of the sentence and means “while (the noun was doing the participle)”. Often the genitive absolute has the special sense of disregarding: “despite (the noun doing the participle)”, “under their very noses,” as when the participle means “seeing”, “looking on”. The genitive absolute is useful for constructing a sentence with two agents,

        classDiagram
  class sentence["kammaá¹ƒ kho pana me karontassa kÄyo kilamissati"] {
    <<vÄkya>>
    english(However, while I am doing the work, (my) body will become tired)
  }
  namespace genitive_absolute {
    class kammaá¹ƒ {
      <<nÄma>>
      ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¡
      english(work)
    }
    class kho {
      <<nipÄta>>
      english(indeed)
    }
    class pana {
      <<nipÄta>>
      english(however)
    }
    class me {
      <<puggalanÄma>>
      âš§â¨€ğŸ‘†â‘¥
      english(of I)
    }
    class karontassa {
      <<past participle>>
      âªğŸš¹â¨€â‘¥
      english(of doing)
    }
  }
  class kÄyo {
    <<nÄma>>
    ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ 
    english(body)
  }
  class kilamissati {
    <<ÄkhyÄta>>
     â¨€ğŸ¤Ÿâ­
    english(will be tired)
  }
  kammaá¹ƒ --> karontassa : kamma
  me <-- karontassa : chaá¹­á¹­hÄ«
  sentence *-- kammaá¹ƒ
  sentence *-- kho
  sentence *-- pana
  sentence *-- me : genitive absolute
  sentence *-- karontassa : genitive absolute
  sentence *-- kÄyo : katar
  sentence *-- kilamissati : bhavissanti

     â¨€ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸

        not the right time

        for which you think it is now the right time

        The last expression is extremely common in saying (formally) goodbye (spoken by the host, not the guest - who for his part has made the excuse of pressure of work). It is used also by servants reporting to their master that preparations are completed, implying “you can start whenever you wish”, etc.

        classDiagram
  class sentence["yassa dÄni kÄlaá¹ƒ maÃ±Ã±asi"] {
    <<vÄkya>>
    english(for which you think it is now the right time)
  }
  class yassa {
    <<anvayÄ«nÄma>>
    âš§â¨€â‘£
    english(for which)
  }
  class dÄni {
    <<nipÄta>>
    english(now)
  }
  class kÄlaá¹ƒ {
    <<nÄma>>
    ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ 
    english(time)
  }
  class maÃ±Ã±asi {
    <<ÄkhyÄta>>
     â¨€ğŸ¤˜â–¶ï¸
    english([you] think)
  }
  sentence *-- yassa: sampadÄna
  sentence *-- dÄni: nipÄta
  sentence *-- kÄlaá¹ƒ: kattar
  sentence *-- maÃ±Ã±asi: ÄkhyÄta

        relative clause

        classDiagram
  class sentence["atha kho ye icchiá¹ƒsu te akaá¹ƒsu"] {
    <<vÄkya>>
    english(then [indeed] those who wished, they worked)
  }
  class atha {
    <<nipÄta>>
    english(then)
  }
  class kho {
    <<nipÄta>>
    english(now)
  }
  namespace relative {
    class ye {
      <<anvayÄ«nÄma>>
      âš§â¨‚â‘ 
      english(those who)
    }
    class icchiá¹ƒsu {
      <<ÄkhyÄta>>
      â¨‚ğŸ¤Ÿâ®
      english([they] wished)
    }
  }
  namespace main {
    class te {
      <<puggalanÄma>>
      âš§â¨‚â‘ 
      english(they)
    }
    class akaá¹ƒsu {
      <<ÄkhyÄta>>
      â¨‚ğŸ¤Ÿâ®
      english([they] worked)
    }
  }
  sentence *-- atha: nipÄta
  sentence *-- kho: nipÄta
  sentence *-- ye: aniyamuddesa
  sentence *-- icchiá¹ƒsu: ajjatanÄ«
  sentence *-- te: kattar
  sentence *-- akaá¹ƒsu: ajjatanÄ«

        emphatic demonstrative pronoun

        classDiagram
  class sentence["yo so satto paá¹­hamaá¹ƒ upapanno, tassa evaá¹ƒ hoti: ahaá¹ƒ asmi brahmÄ"] {
    <<vÄkya>>
    english(that being who has come into existence first (in the evolution of the universe) thinks he is God)
  }
  namespace relative {
    class yoso["yo so"] {
      <<anvayÄ«nÄma>>
      âš§â¨€â‘ 
      english(he who)
    }
    class satto {
      <<nÄma>>
      ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ 
      english(being)
    }
    class paá¹­hamaá¹ƒ {
      <<nipÄta>>
      english(firstly)
    }
    class upapanno {
      <<past participle>>
      âªğŸš¹â¨€â‘ 
      english(arose)
    }
  }
  namespace idiom {
    class tassa {
      <<puggalanÄma>>
      âš§â¨‚â‘£
      english(to him)
    }
    class evaá¹ƒ {
      <<nipÄta>>
      english(thus)
    }
    class hoti {
      <<ÄkhyÄta>>
      â¨€ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸
      english(is)
    }
  }
  namespace thought {
    class ahaá¹ƒ {
      <<puggalanÄma>>
      âš§â¨€â‘ ğŸ‘†
      english(I)
    }
    class asmi {
      <<ÄkhyÄta>>
      â¨€ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸
      english([I] am)
    }
    class brahmÄ {
      <<nÄma>>
      ğŸš¹â¨€â‘¡
      english(God)
    }
  }
  sentence *-- yoso: nidassananÄma
  sentence *-- satto: kattar
  sentence *-- paá¹­hamaá¹ƒ: nipÄta
  sentence *-- upapanno: kattar
  sentence *-- tassa: sampadÄna
  sentence *-- evaá¹ƒ: nipÄta
  sentence *-- hoti: ÄkhyÄta
  sentence *-- ahaá¹ƒ: kattar
  sentence *-- asmi: ÄkhyÄta
  sentence *-- brahmÄ: kattar

        Relative Indeclinable

        relative clause follows main clause = elevated speech emphasising main clause

        classDiagram
  class sentence["hoti kho so samayo yaá¹ƒ â€¦ ayaá¹ƒ loko vivaá¹­á¹­ati"] {
    <<vÄkya>>
    english(there is indeed the (so) time that (i.e. when) ... this world evolves)
  }
  namespace main {
    class hoti {
      <<ÄkhyÄta>>
      â¨€ğŸ¤Ÿâ–¶ï¸
      english(is)
    }
    class kho {
      <<nipÄta>>
      english(indeed)
    }
    class so {
      <<pucchÄnÄma>>
      ğŸš¹â¨€ğŸ¤Ÿ
      english(that)
    }
    class samayo {
      <<nÄma>>
      ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ 
      english(time)
    }
  }
  namespace relative {
    class yaá¹ƒ {
      <<anvayÄ«nÄma>>
      âš§â¨€â‘ 
      english(when)
    }
    class ayaá¹ƒ {
      <<nidassananÄma>>
      âš§â¨€ğŸ¤Ÿâ‘ 
      english(this)
    }
    class loko {
      <<nÄma>>
      ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ 
      english(world)
    }
    class vivaá¹­á¹­ati {
      <<ÄkhyÄta>>
      â¨€ğŸ¤˜â–¶ï¸
      english(revolves)
    }
  }
  sentence *-- hoti : ÄkhyÄta
  sentence *-- kho: nipÄta
  sentence *-- so: kattar
  sentence *-- samayo: kattar
  sentence *-- yaá¹ƒ: aniyamuddesa
  sentence *-- ayaá¹ƒ: nidassananÄma
  sentence *-- loko: kattar
  sentence *-- vivaá¹­á¹­ati: ÄkhyÄta

        Interrogative

        classDiagram
  class sentence["ko 'si tvaá¹ƒ Ävuso"] {
    <<vÄkya>>
    english(Who are you, friend?)
  }
  class ko {
    <<pucchÄnÄma>>
    ğŸš¹â¨€ğŸ¤Ÿ
    english(who?)
  }
  class asi {
    <<ÄkhyÄta>>
     â¨€ğŸ¤˜â–¶ï¸
    english([you] are)
  }
  class tvaá¹ƒ {
    <<puggalanÄma>>
    âš§â¨€ğŸ¤˜â‘ 
    english(you)
  }
  class Ävuso {
    <<nÄma>>
    ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ 
    english(friend)
  }
  sentence *-- ko: pucchÄnÄma
  sentence *-- asi : ÄkhyÄta
  sentence *-- tvaá¹ƒ: kattar
  sentence *-- Ävuso: kattar

        Interrogative (indeclinable)

        classDiagram
  class sentence["kiá¹ƒ saddaá¹ƒ assosi"] {
    <<vÄkya>>
    english(Did he hear the noise?)
  }
  class kiá¹ƒ {
    <<nipÄta>>
    english(who?)
  }
  class saddaá¹ƒ {
    <<nÄma>>
    ğŸš¹â¨€â‘ 
    english(noise)
  }
  class assosi {
    <<ÄkhyÄta>>
     â¨€ğŸ¤Ÿâ®
    english([he] heard)
  }
  sentence *-- kiá¹ƒ: nipÄta
  sentence *-- saddaá¹ƒ: kattar
  sentence *-- assosi : ÄkhyÄta

        6.4 - Answers to Warder Lesson 7

        Answers to A.K. Warder “Introduction to Pali” Lesson 7

        Translate from Pali

        1. iminÄ mayaá¹ƒ nimmitÄ (D I 18,16)
        2. mayaá¹ƒ brahmunÄ nimmitÄ (D I 18,16)

        DN 1 2.5.10:
        IminÄ mayaá¹ (bhotÄ) brahmunÄ nimmitÄ.
        ğŸš¹â‘¢â¨€(ima) ğŸ‘†â‘ â¨‚(ahaá¹ƒ) ğŸš¹â‘¢â¨€(bhavant) ğŸš¹â‘¢â¨€(brahma) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(nimmita)
        By this | we | by sir | by God | created
        We have been created by this Lord God.

        1. desito Ä€nanda mayÄ dhammo (D II 100,2)

        DN 16 2.25.2:
        Desito, Änanda, mayÄ dhammo (anantaraá¹ abÄhiraá¹ karitvÄ).
        ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(desita) ğŸš¹â“ªâ¨€(Änanda) ğŸ‘†â‘¢â¨€(ahaá¹ƒ) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(dhamma) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(anantara) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(abÄhira) ğŸ”¼(karitvÄ)
        Taught by , Ä€nanda , by me | teaching | no secret teaching | no public teaching | having made
        The Dhamma was taught by me, Ä€nanda, (having made no secret teaching and no public teaching).

        1. iminÄ tvaá¹ƒ purisa dhanena jivÄhi (D III 66,2-3)

        DN 26 10.15:
        Atha kho, bhikkhave, rÄjÄ khattiyo muddhÄbhisitto tassa purisassa dhanamanuppadÄsi:
        â€˜iminÄ tvaá¹, (ambho) purisa, dhanena (attanÄ ca) jÄ«vÄhi, mÄtÄpitaro ca posehi, puttadÄraÃ±ca posehi, kammante ca payojehi, samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡esu uddhaggikaá¹ dakkhiá¹‡aá¹ patiá¹­á¹­hÄpehi sovaggikaá¹ sukhavipÄkaá¹ saggasaá¹vattanikanâ€™ti.
        ğŸ”¼(atha kho) , ğŸš¹â“ªâ¨‚(bhikkhu) , ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(rÄja) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(khattiya) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(muddhÄbhisitta) ğŸš¹â‘£â¨€(ta) ğŸš¹â‘£â¨€(purisa) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(dhanamanuppadÄsi) :
        After that , monks , king | noble | inaugurated | for that | for man | gave money :
        After that, the noble inaugurated king gave money to that man:
        ğŸš¹â‘¢â¨€(ima) ğŸ¤˜â‘ â¨€(tvaá¹ƒ) ğŸ”¼(ambho) ğŸš¹â“ªâ¨€(purisa) ğŸš»â‘¢â¨€(dhana) ğŸš¹â‘¢â¨€(atta) ğŸ”¼(ca) â¹ğŸ¤˜â¨€(jÄ«vati)
        With this | you | look here | man | with money | with self | and | may you subsist
        Look here, my man, with this money, may you subsist by yourself,
        ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨‚(mÄtÄpitar) ğŸ”¼(ca) â¹ğŸ¤˜â¨€(poseti) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(puttadÄra)
        Parents | and | please look after , wife and kids | please look after ,
        And please look after parents, wife and kids,
        ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨‚(kammanta) ğŸ”¼(ca) â¹ğŸ¤˜â¨€(payojeti) ,
        Work | and | engage in
        And engage in work,
        ğŸš¹â‘¦â¨‚(samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡a) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(uddhaggika) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(dakkhiá¹‡a) â¹ğŸ¤˜â¨€(patiá¹­á¹­hÄpeti)
        In religious practitioners | promoting spiritual welfare | donation | please offer
        Please offer donation to religious practitioners promoting spiritual welfare
        ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(sovaggika) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(sovaggika) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(saggasaá¹ƒvattanika) ğŸ”¼(ti)
        Leading to heaven | resulting in happiness | leading to heaven | quote
        Leading to heaven and resulting in happiness.

        1. vimutto tathÄgato (D I 29,31)

        DN 1 1.36.4:
        VedanÄnaá¹ samudayaÃ±ca atthaá¹…gamaÃ±ca assÄdaÃ±ca ÄdÄ«navaÃ±ca nissaraá¹‡aÃ±ca yathÄbhÅ«taá¹ viditvÄ (anupÄdÄ)vimutto, bhikkhave, tathÄgato.
        ğŸšºâ‘£â¨‚(vedanÄ) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(samudaya) ğŸ”¼(ca) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(atthaá¹…gama) ğŸ”¼(ca) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(assÄda) ğŸ”¼(ca) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(ÄdÄ«nava) ğŸ”¼(ca) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(nissaraá¹‡a) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(yathÄbhÅ«ta) ğŸ”¼(viditvÄ)
        For feelings | appearance | and | passing away | and | satisfaction | and | unsatisfactoriness | and | escape from | as it truly is | having perceived
        â€¦ ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(anupÄdÄvimutta) ğŸš¹â“ªâ¨‚(bhikkhu) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(tathÄgata)
        liberated through non-attachment | monks | TathÄgata
        Having perceived the appearance and passing away of feelings, satisfaction and dissatisfaction, escape from feelings, as they truly are,
        â€¦ the TathÄgata is liberated (through non-attachment).

        1. te ca me evaá¹ƒ puá¹­á¹­hÄ ÄmÄ ti vadanti (Cf. D III 28,16 & D I 194,1)

        1. idam Äsanaá¹ƒ paÃ±Ã±attaá¹ƒ (D III 39,22-23)

        1. ete manussÄ gehaá¹ƒ pavisanti (D I 83,7-8)

        DN 2 96.1:
        SeyyathÄpi, mahÄrÄja, majjhe siá¹…ghÄá¹­ake pÄsÄdo.         Just like | o great king | middle of | crossroads | palace
        ğŸ”¼(tattha) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(cakkhumant) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(purisa) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(á¹­hita) â¯ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(passati) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨‚(manussa) ğŸš»â‘¡â¨€(geha) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨‚(pavisanta) ğŸ”¼(pi) ğŸ”µâ–¶ï¸ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚(nikkhamati) ğŸ”¼(pi) ğŸšºâ‘¦â¨€(rathikÄ) ğŸ”¼(pi) ğŸšºâ‘¡â¨€(vÄ«thi) ğŸ”µâ–¶ï¸ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚(saÃ±carati) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨‚(majjha) ğŸš»â‘¡â¨‚(siá¹…ghÄá¹­aka) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨‚(nisinna) ğŸ”¼(pi)
        In that place | who can see | person | stood still | will see | people | house | entering | too | exiting | too | at main road | too | path | wandering | middle of | crossroads | seated | too
        ğŸš¹â‘¥â¨€(ta) ğŸ”¼(evamassa) :
        Of that | he would think thus :
        ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(eta) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(manussa) ğŸš»â‘¡â¨€(geha)
        These | people | house | enter
        ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(eta) â–¶ï¸ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚(nikkhamati)
        These exit
        ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(eta) ğŸšºâ‘¦â¨€(rathikÄ) ğŸšºâ‘¡â¨€(vÄ«thi) â–¶ï¸ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚(saÃ±carati)
        These | at main road | path | wander
        ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(eta) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨‚(majjha) ğŸš»â‘¡â¨‚(siá¹…ghÄá¹­aka) â‘ â¨‚(nisinna) ğŸ”¼(ti)
        These | middle of | crossroads | seated | quote
        (O great king, just like a palace in the middle of a crossroad. In that place, a person who is able to see, standing still, will see people entering a house, exiting, wandering along a path on the main road, seated in the middle of the crossroad. Of that, he would think thus): â€œThese people enter a house, (exit, wander along a path on the main road, seated in the middle of the crossroad).â€

        1. niggahÄ«to ‘si (D III 117,13-14)

        DN 29 1.5:
        â€œna tvaá¹ imaá¹ dhammavinayaá¹ ÄjÄnÄsi, ahaá¹ imaá¹ dhammavinayaá¹ ÄjÄnÄmi, kiá¹ tvaá¹ imaá¹ dhammavinayaá¹ ÄjÄnissasi? MicchÄpaá¹­ipanno tvamasi, ahamasmi sammÄpaá¹­ipanno.         ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(adhiciá¹‡á¹‡a) ğŸ¤˜â‘¢â¨€(tvaá¹ƒ) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(viparÄvatta) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(Äropita) ğŸ¤˜â‘¢â¨€(tvaá¹ƒ) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(vÄda) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(niggahita) ğŸ¤˜â‘ â¨€(tvaá¹ƒ) â–¶ï¸ğŸ¤˜â¨€(atthi) â¹ğŸ¤˜â¨€(carati) ğŸš¹â‘£â¨€(vÄdappamokkha) â¹ğŸ¤˜â¨€(nibbeá¹­heti) ğŸ”¼(vÄ) ğŸ”¼(sace) â–¶ï¸ğŸ¤˜â¨€(pahoti) ğŸ”¼(ti)
        What one has prepared | by you | refuted | debunked | by you | statement | disproved | you | is , wandered | saving an argument , you must wriggle | or | if | you are able | quote
        â€œ(What has been prepared by you is refuted, statement by you is debunked), you are disproved, (you must wander around to save the argument, or wriggle, if you are able).â€

        1. kilanto ‘smi (D II 128,18)

        DN 16 4.39.3:
        â€œiá¹…gha me tvaá¹, cundaka, catugguá¹‡aá¹ saá¹…ghÄá¹­iá¹ paÃ±Ã±apehi, kilantosmi, cundaka, nipajjissÄmÄ«â€ti.

        1. dÄnaá¹ƒ detha (D II 357,15)

        Translate into Pali

        1. They experience happiness (Cf. D I 75,7-8)
          sukhaá¹ƒ paá¹­isaá¹ƒvedenti.

        2. The doctrine has been declared by me (D II 154,6)
          mayÄ dhammo paÃ±Ã±atto.

        3. The wanderer is (hoti) contented (Cf. D I 71,3)
          paribbÄjako santuá¹­á¹­ho hoti.

        4. Death (is) misery (D II 305,3)
          maraá¹‡aá¹ƒ dukkhaá¹ƒ.

        5. I have heard this (D I 128,29)
          sutaá¹ƒ (kho pana) me taá¹ƒ.

        6. I did the work (D III 257,1-2)
          ahaá¹ƒ (kho) kammaá¹ƒ akÄsiá¹ƒ.

        7. He gives a donation (D III 258,10)
          dÄnaá¹ƒ deti.

        8. The body (is) tired (D III 255,16)
          kÄyo kilanto.

        6.5 - Answers to Warder Lesson 8

        We go to the Blessed One and the Dhamma for refuge.

        jÄ«vitaá¹ƒ demi (D I 148,3)
        ğŸš»â‘¡â¨€(jÄ«vita) â–¶ï¸ğŸ‘†â¨€(deti)
        life | I give
        (I) give life.

        Translate into Pali

        They enter by this gate (D II 83,16)
        Te iminÄ dvÄrena pavisanti.

        The king, having greeted the fortunate one, sat down (D I 50,33 - 51,1)
        RÄjÄ Bhagavantaá¹ƒ abhivÄdetvÄ nisÄ«di.

        Having approached (and) greeted the fortunate one, they sat down (D II 84,16-17)

        The honourable JotipÄla went forth (D II 249,19-21)

        Gacchaá¹ƒ (or gacchanto) passati.

        N’ahaá¹ƒ (or just na) brahmuá¹‡Ä mantemi.

        AjÄ haÃ±Ã±anti.

        MÄlaá¹ƒ ÄdÄya yena sÄlÄ tena upasaá¹…kamiá¹ƒsu.

        Indeed I did work. However, while I was doing work, the body became tired, now I must rest.

        imaá¹ƒ mayaá¹ƒ addasÄma idha upapannaá¹ƒ (D I 18,17-18)
        ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(ima) ğŸ‘†â‘ â¨‚(ahaá¹ƒ) â®ğŸ‘†â¨‚(addasa) ğŸ”¼(idha) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(upapanna)
        this | we | saw | here | appeared
        We saw this appearing here.

        Translate into Pali

        The universe is infinite (D I 188,1-2)
        Ananto (or anantavÄ) loko.

        This is not easy (use the neuter: impersonal statement) (D I 63,3-4)
        Na idaá¹ƒ sukaraá¹ƒ.

        I followed the road (D III 255,24)
        Ahaá¹ƒ maggaá¹ƒ agamÄsiá¹ƒ (or paá¹­ipajjiá¹ƒ).

        The king saw the boy (D II 16,3-4)
        AddasÄ rÄjÄ kumÄraá¹ƒ.

        The city was prosperous (Cf. D II 146,29 and D I 211,7)
        Nagaraá¹ƒ phÄ«taá¹ƒ ahosi.

        He (is) fixed, permanent, eternal (four words, order as here) (D I 18,35)
        So dhuvo nicco sassato.

        We saw the fortunate one (D III 39,32)
        AddasÄma Bhagavantaá¹ƒ.

        The speech (is) agreeable (D III 173,13-14)
        VÄcÄ kantÄ (or bhÄsitaá¹ƒ kantaá¹ƒ).

        My life (was) given by him (he spared my life), his life (was) given by me (I spared his life) (Cf. D I 148,3)
        Tena ca me jÄ«vitaá¹ƒ dinnaá¹ƒ, mayÄ ca tassa jÄ«vitaá¹ƒ dinnaá¹ƒ.

        See! Ananda - They (are) past, ended, changed (D II 198,18-19)
        Passa, Ä€nanda, te atÄ«tÄ niruddhÄ vipariá¹‡atÄ.

        He has much gold (Cf. D II 351,11 and D III 163,5-6)
        Tassa pahÅ«taá¹ƒ suvaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ hoti.

        6.9 - Answers to Warder Lesson 12

        Answers to A.K. Warder “Introduction to Pali” Lesson 12

        Passage for reading

        PÄyÄsisutta DN 23 PTS 2.316â€“2.358 19.3-19.9 (D II 337,9-23):

        bhÅ«tapubbaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±ataro saá¹…khadhamo saá¹…khaá¹ƒ ÄdÄya paccantimaá¹ƒ janapadaá¹ƒ agamÄsi. so yen’ aÃ±Ã±ataro gÄmo ten’ upasaá¹ƒkami. upasaá¹ƒkamitvÄ saá¹…khaá¹ƒ upaá¸·ÄsitvÄ saá¹…khaá¹ƒ nikkhipitvÄ nisÄ«di. atha kho tesaá¹ƒ paccantajÄnaá¹ƒ manussÄnaá¹ƒ etad ahosi: kissa nu kho eso saddo evaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yo evaá¹ƒ kamanÄ«yo evaá¹ƒ madanÄ«yo ti. sannipatitvÄ taá¹ƒ saá¹…khadhamaá¹ƒ etad avocuá¹ƒ: ambho kissa nu kho eso saddo evaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yo evaá¹ƒ kamanÄ«yo evaá¹ƒ madanÄ«yo ti. eso kho bho saá¹…kho nÄma yass’ eso saddo evaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yo evaá¹ƒ kamanÄ«yo evaá¹ƒ madanÄ«yo ti.

        bhÅ«tapubbaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±ataro saá¹…khadhamo saá¹…khaá¹ƒ ÄdÄya paccantimaá¹ƒ janapadaá¹ƒ agamÄsi.
        âï¸(bhÅ«tapubbaá¹ƒ) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(aÃ±Ã±atara) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(saá¹…khadhama) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(saá¹…kha) ğŸ”¼(ÄdÄya) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(paccantima) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(janapada) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(agamÄsi)

        so yen’ aÃ±Ã±ataro gÄmo ten’ upasaá¹ƒkami.

        upasaá¹ƒkamitvÄ saá¹…khaá¹ƒ upaá¸·ÄsitvÄ saá¹…khaá¹ƒ nikkhipitvÄ nisÄ«di.

        atha kho tesaá¹ƒ paccantajÄnaá¹ƒ manussÄnaá¹ƒ etad ahosi: kissa nu kho eso saddo evaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yo evaá¹ƒ kamanÄ«yo evaá¹ƒ madanÄ«yo ti.

        After that the thought occured for those frontier people: â€œWhat is this sound that is so enticing, beautiful and intoxicating?â€

        sannipatitvÄ taá¹ƒ saá¹…khadhamaá¹ƒ etad avocuá¹ƒ: ambho kissa nu kho eso saddo evaá¹ƒ rajanÄ«yo evaá¹ƒ kamanÄ«yo evaá¹ƒ madanÄ«yo ti.

        6.10 - Answers to Warder Lesson 13

        Answers to A.K. Warder “Introduction to Pali” Lesson 13

        Passage for reading

        PÄyÄsisutta DN 23 PTS 2.316â€“2.358 19.10-19.18 (D II 337,23 - 338,9):

        te taá¹ƒ saá¹…khaá¹ƒ uttÄnaá¹ƒ nipÄtesuá¹ƒ: vadehi bho saá¹…kha, vadehi bho saá¹…khÄÂ ti. n’eva so saá¹…kho saddaá¹ƒ akÄsi. te taá¹ƒ saá¹…khaá¹ƒ passena nipÄtesuá¹ƒ â€¦ uddhaá¹ƒ á¹­hapesuá¹ƒ â€¦ daá¹‡á¸ena Äkoá¹­esuá¹ƒ â€¦ sandhuniá¹ƒsu: vadehi bho saá¹…kha, vadehi bho saá¹…khÄ ti. n’eva so saá¹…kho saddaá¹ƒ akÄsi. atha kho tassa saá¹…khadhamassa etad ahosi: yÄva bÄlÄ. ime paccantajÄ manussÄ. kathaá¹ƒ hi nÄma ayoniso saá¹…khasaddaá¹ƒ gavesissantÄ« ti. tesam pekkhamÄnÄnaá¹ƒ saá¹…khaá¹ƒ gahetvÄ tikkhattuá¹ƒ saá¹…khaá¹ƒ upaá¸·ÄsitvÄ saá¹…khaá¹ƒ ÄdÄya pakkÄmi.

        te taá¹ƒ saá¹…khaá¹ƒ uttÄnaá¹ƒ nipÄtesuá¹ƒ:
        ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(ta) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(ta) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(saá¹…kha) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(uttÄna) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚(nipÄtesi)
        they | that | conch shell | lying on itâ€™s back | placed down
        They placed down that conch shell lying on itâ€™s back.

        vadehi bho saá¹…kha, vadehi bho saá¹…khÄÂ ti.
        â¹ğŸ¤˜â¨€(vadeti) ğŸš¹â“ªâ¨€(bhavant) ğŸš¹â“ªâ¨€(saá¹…kha) â¹ğŸ¤˜â¨€(vadeti) ğŸš¹â“ªâ¨€(bhavant) ğŸš¹â“ªâ¨€(saá¹…kha) ğŸ”¼(ti)

        n’eva so saá¹…kho saddaá¹ƒ akÄsi.
        ğŸ”¼(neva) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(ta) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(saá¹…kha) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(sadda) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(akÄsi)
        not even | that | conch | sound | made

        te taá¹ƒ saá¹…khaá¹ƒ passena nipÄtesuá¹ƒ â€¦ uddhaá¹ƒ á¹­hapesuá¹ƒ â€¦ daá¹‡á¸ena Äkoá¹­esuá¹ƒ â€¦ sandhuniá¹ƒsu:
        ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(ta) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(ta) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(saá¹…kha) ğŸš»â‘¢â¨€(passa) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚(nipÄtesi) â€¦ ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(uddha) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚(á¹­hapesi) â€¦ ğŸš¹â‘¢â¨€(daá¹‡á¸a) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚(Äkoá¹­esi) â€¦ â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚(sandhuni)
        they | that | conch shell | side | placed down â€¦ upright | placed â€¦ with stick | tapped â€¦ shook together
        they lied down the conch on its side â€¦ placed upright â€¦ tapped with stick â€¦ shook [it].

        vadehi bho saá¹…kha, vadehi bho saá¹…khÄ ti.
        â¹ğŸ¤˜â¨€(vadeti) ğŸš¹â“ªâ¨€(bhavant) ğŸš¹â“ªâ¨€(saá¹…kha) ğŸ”¼(ti)
        make sound | sir | conch | make sound | sir | conch | quote
        â€œMake sound, Sir Conch! Make sound, Sir Conch!â€

        n’eva so saá¹…kho saddaá¹ƒ akÄsi.
        ğŸ”¼(neva) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(ta) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(saá¹…kha) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(sadda) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(akÄsi)
        not even | that | conch | sound | made
        That conch did not even make any sound.

        atha kho tassa saá¹…khadhamassa etad ahosi:
        ğŸ”¼(atha kho) ğŸš¹â‘£â¨€(ta) ğŸš¹â‘£â¨€(saá¹…khadhama) ğŸ”¼(etadahosi) :
        after that | for that | for conchblower | this thought occured
        after that this thought occured for the conch blower:

        yÄva bÄlÄ ime paccantajÄ manussÄ.
        ğŸ”¼(yÄva) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(bÄla) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(ima) ğŸ”¼(paccantajÄ) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(manussa)
        how | foolish | these | from the frontier | people
        â€œHow foolish are these people from the frontier!â€

        kathaá¹ƒ hi nÄma ayoniso saá¹…khasaddaá¹ƒ gavesissantÄ« ti.
        ğŸ”¼(kathaá¹ƒ hi nÄma) ğŸ”¼(ayoniso) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(saá¹…khasadda) â­ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚(gavesati)
        how | truly | certainly | unwisely | sound of a conch shell | will search for
        â€œTruly how unwisely they will search for the sound of a conch shell!â€

        tesam pekkhamÄnÄnaá¹ƒ saá¹…khaá¹ƒ gahetvÄ tikkhattuá¹ƒ saá¹…khaá¹ƒ upaá¸·ÄsitvÄ saá¹…khaá¹ƒ ÄdÄya pakkÄmi.
        ğŸš¹â‘¥â¨‚(ta) ğŸš¹â‘¥â¨‚(pekkhamÄna) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(saá¹…kha) ğŸ”¼(gahetvÄ) ğŸ”¼(tikkhattuá¹ƒ) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(saá¹…kha) ğŸ”¼(upaá¸·ÄsitvÄ) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(saá¹…kha) ğŸ”¼(ÄdÄya) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(pakkÄmi)
        of that | of observing | conch shell | having taken | three times | conch shell | having made the sound,
        While observing that, having taken the conch shell, having made a sound three times, he left, holding the conch shell.

        Translate from Pali

        brÄhmaá¹‡o mante vÄcesi (D II 236,19-21)
        ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(brÄhmaá¹‡a) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨‚(manta) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(vÄcesi)
        brahman | sacred hymns | recited
        The brahman recited the sacred hymns.

        so taá¹ƒ cittaá¹ƒ bhÄveti (D III 259,10-11)
        ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(ta) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(ta) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(citta) â–¶ï¸ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(bhÄveti)
        he | that | mind | cultivates
        He cultivates the mind.

        na taá¹ƒ (2nd. person) deva paccatthikÄnaá¹ƒ demi (D I 50,9)
        ğŸ”¼(na) ğŸ¤˜â‘¡â¨€(tvaá¹ƒ) ğŸš¹â“ªâ¨€(deva) ğŸš¹â‘£â¨‚(paccatthika) â–¶ï¸ğŸ‘†â¨€(deti)
        no | you | o Lord | for hostile | must give
        i am not giving you up to the enemy, Your Highness

        ayaá¹ƒ dukkhasamudayo (D I 84,1)
        ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(ima) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(dukkhasamudaya)
        this | arising of suffering
        This is the arising of suffering.

        rÄjÄ kumÄrassa (dative) pÄsÄde kÄrÄpesi (D II 21,6-7)
        ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(rÄja) | ğŸš¹â‘£â¨€(kumÄra) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨‚(pÄsÄda) â–¶ï¸ğŸ¤˜â¨€(kÄrÄpeti)
        king | for boy | palace | caused to make

        so iminÄ ca ariyena sÄ«lakkhandhena samannÄgato iminÄ ariyena indriyasaá¹ƒvarena samannÄgato â€¦ vivittaá¹ƒ senÄsanaá¹ƒ bhajati: araÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ rukkhamÅ«laá¹ƒ, pabbataá¹ƒ, … abbhokÄsaá¹ƒ palÄlapuÃ±jaá¹ƒ (D I 71,12-17)
        ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(ta) ğŸš¹â‘¢â¨€(ima) ğŸ”¼(ca) ğŸš¹â‘¢â¨€(ariya) ğŸš¹â‘¢â¨€(sÄ«lakkhandha) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(samannÄgata) ğŸš¹â‘¢â¨€(ima) ğŸš¹â‘¢â¨€(ariya) ğŸš¹â‘¢â¨€(indriyasaá¹ƒvara) â€¦ ğŸšºâ‘¡â¨€(vivittÄ) ğŸš»â‘¡â¨€(senÄsana) â–¶ï¸ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(bhajati) : ğŸš»â‘¡â¨€(araÃ±Ã±a) ğŸš»â‘¡â¨€(rukkhamÅ«la) ğŸš»â‘¡â¨€(pabbata) â€¦ ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(abbhokÄsa) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(palÄlapuÃ±ja)
        he | by this | and | by noble | by virtuous conduct | endowed with | by noble | by sense restraint | endowed with â€¦ seclusion | housing | retires to : forest | base of a tree | mountain â€¦ open air | heap of straw

        idha tathÄgatena anuttaraá¹ƒ dhammacakkaá¹ƒ pavattitaá¹ƒ (D II 140,25-26)

        tvaá¹ƒ pana samma JÄ«vaka kiá¹ƒ tuá¹‡hÄ« (D I 49,11-12)

        6.11 - Answers to Warder Lesson 14

        bhÅ«tapubbaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±ataro janapado vuá¹­á¹­hÄsi. atha kho sahÄyako sahÄyakaá¹ƒ Ämantesi: ÄyÄma samma. yena so janapado ten’ upasaá¹…kamissÄma. app eva nÄm’ ettha kiÃ± ci dhanaá¹ƒ adhigaccheyyÄmÄ ti. evaá¹ƒ sammÄ ti kho sahÄyako sahÄyakassa paccassosi. te yena so janapado yen’ aÃ±Ã±ataraá¹ƒ gÄmapaá¹­á¹­aá¹ƒ ten’ upasaá¹ƒkamiá¹ƒsu. tatth’ addasaá¹ƒsu pahÅ«taá¹ƒ sÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ chaá¸á¸itaá¹ƒ. disvÄ sahÄyako sahÄyakaá¹ƒ Ämantesi: idaá¹ƒ kho samma pahÅ«taá¹ƒ sÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ chaá¸á¸itaá¹ƒ. tena hi samma tvaÃ±1 ca sÄá¹‡abhÄraá¹ƒ bandha, ahaÃ± ca sÄá¹‡abhÄraá¹ƒ bandhissÄmi. ubho sÄá¹‡abhÄraá¹ƒ ÄdÄya gamissÄmÄ ti. evaá¹ƒ sammÄ ti kho sahÄyako sahÄyakassa paá¹­issutvÄ sÄá¹‡abhÄraá¹ƒ bandhi.

        yena so janapado ten’ upasaá¹…kamissÄma.

        tatth’ addasaá¹ƒsu pahÅ«taá¹ƒ sÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ chaá¸á¸itaá¹ƒ. ğŸ”¼(tattha) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚(addasa) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(pahÅ«ta) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(sÄá¹‡a) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(chaá¸á¸ita) in that place | they saw | considerable | hemp | discarded In that place they saw considerable hemp discarded.

        tena hi samma tvaÃ± ca sÄá¹‡abhÄraá¹ƒ bandha, ahaÃ± ca sÄá¹‡abhÄraá¹ƒ bandhissÄmi. ğŸ”¼(tenahi) ğŸ”¼(samma) ğŸ”¼(tvaÃ±ca) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(sÄá¹‡abhÄra) â¹ğŸ¤˜â¨€(bandhati) ğŸ”¼(ahaÃ±ca) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(sÄá¹‡abhÄra) â­ğŸ‘†â¨€(bandhati) therefore / mate / and you / load of hemp / you must bind / and I / load of hemp / I will bind â€œTherefore, mate, you must bind a load of hemp, and I will bind a load of hemp.â€

        idha samaá¹‡o vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡o vÄ kusalaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ adhigaccheyya. kusalaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ adhigantvÄ na parassa Äroceyya. kiá¹ƒ hi paro parassa karissati. seyyathÄ pi nÄma purÄá¹‡aá¹ bandhanaá¹ƒ chinditvÄ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ navaá¹ƒ bandhanaá¹ƒ kareyya. (D I 224, 9-13)
        ğŸ”¼(idha) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(samaá¹‡a) ğŸ”¼(vÄ) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(brÄhmaá¹‡a) ğŸ”¼(vÄ) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(kusala) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(dhamma) â¯ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(adhigacchati) . ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(kusala) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(dhamma) ğŸ”¼(adhigantvÄ) ğŸ”¼(na) ğŸš¹â‘£â¨€(para) â¯ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(Äroceti) . ğŸš¹â‘¦â¨€(ka) ğŸ”¼(paro) ğŸš»â‘£â¨€(para) â­ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(karoti) . ğŸ”¼(seyyathÄ pi nÄma) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(purÄá¹‡a) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(bandhana) ğŸ”¼(chinditvÄ) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(aÃ±Ã±a) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(nava) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(bandhana) â¯ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(karoti)
        here | ascetic | or | brahmin | or | good | thing | will find. good | thing | having found | no | for other | will inform another. in what? | more | for other | will do . imagine if | too | certainly | old | connection | having cut off | another | new | connection | should be made
        Here an ascetic or brahmin may find a good thing. Having found a good thing, he will not inform another. What more will it do for another? Imagine having cut off an old connection, another new connection will be made.

        (Ahaá¹ƒ) uá¹­á¹­hÄy’ÄsanÄ pakkÄmiá¹ƒ

        6.12 - Answers to Warder Lesson 15

        Answers to A.K. Warder “Introduction to Pali” Lesson 15

        Reading Passage

        PÄyÄsisutta DN 23 PTS 2.316â€“2.358 29.9-29.14 (D II 349,25 - 350,7)

        te ubho sÄá¹‡abhÄraá¹ƒ ÄdÄya yen’ aÃ±Ã±ataraá¹ƒ gÄmapadaá¹ƒ ten’ upasaá¹ƒkamiá¹ƒsu. tatth’ addasaá¹ƒsu pahÅ«taá¹ƒ sÄá¹‡asuttaá¹ƒ chaá¸á¸itaá¹ƒ. disvÄ sahÄyako sahÄyakaá¹ƒ Ämantesi: yassa kho samma atthÄya iccheyyÄma sÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ, idaá¹ƒ pahÅ«taá¹ƒ sÄá¹‡asuttaá¹ƒ chaá¸á¸itaá¹ƒ. tena hi samma tvaÃ± ca sÄá¹‡abhÄraá¹ƒ chaá¸á¸ehi, ahaÃ± ca sÄá¹‡abhÄraá¹ƒ chaá¸á¸essÄmi. ubho sÄá¹‡asuttabhÄraá¹ƒ ÄdÄya gamissÄmÄ ti. ayaá¹ƒ kho me samma sÄá¹‡abhÄro dÅ«rÄbhato ca susannaddho ca. alam1 me; tvaá¹ƒ pajÄnÄhÄ« ti. atha kho so sahÄyako sÄá¹‡abhÄraá¹ƒ chaá¸á¸etvÄ sÄá¹‡asuttabhÄraá¹ƒ Ädiyi.

        te ubho sÄá¹‡abhÄraá¹ƒ ÄdÄya yen’ aÃ±Ã±ataraá¹ƒ gÄmapadaá¹ƒ ten’ upasaá¹ƒkamiá¹ƒsu.
        ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(ta) â¨â‘ â¨€(ubha) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(sÄá¹‡abhÄra) ğŸšºâ‘¦â¨€(Äda) ğŸ”¼(yena) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(aÃ±Ã±atara) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(gÄmapaá¹­á¹­a) ğŸ”¼(tena) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(upasaá¹ƒkami)
        they | both | load of hemp | in taking | by where | a certain | site of a village | by where | approached
        They both taking a load of hemp approached (another) certain site of a village.

        tatth’ addasaá¹ƒsu pahÅ«taá¹ƒ sÄá¹‡asuttaá¹ƒ chaá¸á¸itaá¹ƒ.
        ğŸ”¼(tattha) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚(addasa) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(pahÅ«ta) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(sÄá¹‡asutta) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(chaá¸á¸ita)
        in that place | they saw | considerable | hemp thread | discarded
        In that place they saw considerable hemp thread discarded.

        disvÄ sahÄyako sahÄyakaá¹ƒ Ämantesi: yassa kho samma atthÄya iccheyyÄma sÄá¹‡aá¹ƒ, idaá¹ƒ pahÅ«taá¹ƒ sÄá¹‡asuttaá¹ƒ chaá¸á¸itaá¹ƒ.
        ğŸ”¼(disvÄ) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(sahÄyaka) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(sahÄyaka) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(Ämantesi): ğŸš¹â‘£â¨€(ya) ğŸ”¼(kho) ğŸ”¼(samma) ğŸš¹â‘£â¨€(attha) â¯ğŸ‘†â¨‚(icchati) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(sÄá¹‡a) , ğŸ”¼(idaá¹ƒ) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(pahÅ«ta) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(sÄá¹‡asutta) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(chaá¸á¸ita)
        having seen | friend | friend | discussed : for whatever | indeed | friend | for purpose | we will desire | hemp , here | considerable | hemp thread | discarded
        Having seen, friend discussed to friend: â€œMate, for whatever purpose we will wish for hemp, here is considerable hemp thread discarded.â€

        tena hi samma tvaÃ± ca sÄá¹‡abhÄraá¹ƒ chaá¸á¸ehi, ahaÃ± ca sÄá¹‡abhÄraá¹ƒ chaá¸á¸essÄmi.
        ğŸ”¼(tenahi) ğŸ”¼(samma) ğŸ”¼(tvaÃ±ca) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(sÄá¹‡abhÄra) â¹ğŸ¤˜â¨€(chaá¸á¸eti) ğŸ”¼(ahaÃ±ca) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(sÄá¹‡abhÄra) â­ğŸ‘†â¨€(chaá¸á¸eti)
        therefore / mate / and you / load of hemp / you must dischard / and I / load of hemp / I will discard
        â€œTherefore, mate, you must discard (your) load of hemp, and I will discard (my) load of hemp.â€

        ubho sÄá¹‡asuttabhÄraá¹ƒ ÄdÄya gamissÄmÄ ti.
        â¨â‘ â¨€(ubha) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(sÄá¹‡asuttabhÄra) ğŸ”¼(ÄdÄya) â­ğŸ‘†â¨‚(gamissati) ğŸ”¼(ti)
        both | load of hemp thread | having taken | will go | quote
        â€œBoth having taken a load of hemp thread, we will go.â€

        ayaá¹ƒ kho me samma sÄá¹‡abhÄro dÅ«rÄbhato ca susannaddho ca.
        ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(ima) ğŸ”¼(kho) ğŸ‘†â‘¢â¨€(ahaá¹ƒ) ğŸ”¼(samma) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(sÄá¹‡abhÄra) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(dÅ«rÄbhata) ğŸ”¼(ca) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(susannaddha) ğŸ”¼(ca)
        this | indeed | by me | mate | load of hemp | carried far | and | well tied up
        â€œMate, this load of hemp has been well tied up and carried far by me.â€

        alam me; tvaá¹ƒ pajÄnÄhÄ« ti.
        ğŸ”¼(alaá¹ƒ) ğŸ‘†â‘£â¨€(ahaá¹ƒ) ; ğŸ¤˜â‘ â¨€(tvaá¹ƒ) â¹ğŸ¤˜â¨€(pajÄnÄti) ğŸ”¼(quote)
        thatâ€™s enough | for me ; you | must understand | quote
        â€œThatâ€™s enough for me, you must understand.â€

        atha kho so sahÄyako sÄá¹‡abhÄraá¹ƒ chaá¸á¸etvÄ sÄá¹‡asuttabhÄraá¹ƒ Ädiyi.
        ğŸ”¼(atha kho) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(ta) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(sahÄyaka) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(sÄá¹‡abhÄra) ğŸ”¼(chaá¸á¸etvÄ) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(sÄá¹‡asuttabhÄra) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(Ädiyi)
        after that | that | friend | load of hemp | having discarded | load of hemp thread | took
        After that, that friend. having discarded (his) load of hemp. took a load of hemp thread.

        Translate from Pali

        tena hi brÄhmaá¹‡a suá¹‡Ähi (D I 124,19)
        ğŸ”¼(tena hi) ğŸš¹â“ªâ¨€(brÄhmaá¹‡a) â¹ğŸ¤˜â¨€(suá¹‡Äti)
        therefore | o Brahman | you must listen
        Therefore, o Brahman, you must listen!

        na tvaá¹ƒ imaá¹ƒ dhammavinayaá¹ƒ ÄjÄnÄsi. ahaá¹ƒ imaá¹ƒ dhammavinayaá¹ƒ ÄjÄnÄmi (D III 117,7-9)
        ğŸ”¼(na) ğŸ¤˜â‘ â¨€(tvaá¹ƒ) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(ima) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(dhammavinaya) â–¶ï¸ğŸ¤˜â¨€(ÄjÄnÄti) . ğŸ‘†â‘ â¨€(ahaá¹ƒ) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(ima) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(dhammavinaya) â–¶ï¸ğŸ‘†â¨€(ÄjÄnÄti)
        no | you | this | teaching and training | understand . i | this | teaching and training | understand
        You do not understand this teaching and training. I understand this teaching and training.

        idha tathÄgato jÄto (D II 140,20)
        ğŸ”¼(idha) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(tathÄgata) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(jÄta)
        here | tathÄgata | born
        Here the TathÄgata was born.

        ko imaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ khippam eva ÄjÄnissati (D II 40,5-6)
        ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(ka) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(ima) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(dhamma) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(khippa) ğŸ”¼(eva) â­ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(ÄjÄnÄti)
        who? | this | doctrine | quickly | just | will understand
        Who will understand this doctrine quickly?

        ekacco dÄnaá¹ƒ deti samaá¹‡assa vÄ brÄhmaá¹‡assa vÄ annaá¹ƒ pÄnaá¹ƒ vatthaá¹ƒ yÄnaá¹ƒ mÄlÄgandhavilepanaá¹ƒ seyyÄvasathapadÄ«peyyaá¹ƒ (D III 259,3-5)
        ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(ekacca) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(dÄna) â–¶ï¸ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(deti) ğŸš¹â‘£â¨€(samaá¹‡a) ğŸ”¼(vÄ) ğŸš¹â‘£â¨€(brÄhmaá¹‡a) ğŸ”¼(vÄ) ğŸš»â‘¡â¨€(anna) ğŸš»â‘¡â¨€(pÄna) ğŸš»â‘¡â¨€(vattha) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(mÄlÄgandhavilepana) ğŸš»â‘¡â¨€(seyyÄvasathapadÄ«peyya)
        some/certain | alms/gift | he gave | for ascetic | or | for brahmin | or | food | drink | cloth | footwear | garlands/perfumes/oils | bedding/housing/lighting
        A certain person gave some gifts for ascetics or brahmins: food, drink, clothing, footwear, garlands, perfumes, oils, bedding, housing, lighting.

        ko nu kho papa bho jÄnÄti. madanÄ«yÄ kÄmÄ (D II 234,10-11)
        ğŸ”¼(ko nu kho) ğŸš»â‘ â¨‚(papa) ğŸš¹â“ªâ¨€(bhavant) â–¶ï¸ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(jÄnÄti) . ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(madanÄ«ya) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(kÄma)
        who? | indeed | bar | sir | know. intoxicating | sensual pleasures
        Sir, who knows (this) bar? Sensual pleasures are intoxicating.

        jÄnÄhi yadi vÄ taá¹ƒ bhavantaá¹ƒ Gotamaá¹ƒ tathÄ santaá¹ƒ yeva saddo abbhuggato, yadi vÄ no tathÄ (D I 88,22-24)
        â¹ğŸ¤˜â¨€(jÄnÄti) ğŸ”¼(yadi) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(ta) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(bhavant) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(gotama) ğŸš»â‘ â¨‚(tatha) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(santa) ğŸ”¼(yeva) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(sadda) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(abbhuggata) , ğŸ”¼(yadi) ğŸ”¼(vÄ) ğŸ”¼(no) ğŸš»â‘ â¨‚(tatha)
        you must understand | whether | or | that | Venerable | Gotama | true | existing | only/just | reputation | arisen/spread , or whether | or | not | real/true
        You must understand whether that reputation that has spread regarding Venerable Gotama is truly correct, or whether it is not true.

        tassa evaá¹ƒ jÄnato evaá¹ƒ passato kÄmÄsavÄ pi cittaá¹ƒ vimuccati bhavÄsavÄ pi cittaá¹ƒ vimuccati avijjÄsavÄ pi cittaá¹ƒ vimuccati (D I 84,8- 10)
        ğŸš¹â‘¥â¨€(ta) ğŸ”¼(evaá¹ƒ) ğŸš»â‘¥â¨€(jÄnanta) ğŸ”¼(evaá¹ƒ) ğŸš¹â‘¥â¨€(passanta) ğŸš¹â‘¤â¨€(kÄmÄsava) ğŸ”¼(pi) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(citta) â–¶ï¸ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(vimuccati) ğŸš¹â‘¤â¨€(bhavÄsava) ğŸ”¼(pi) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(citta) â–¶ï¸ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(vimuccati) ğŸš¹â‘¤â¨€(avijjÄsava) ğŸ”¼(pi) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(citta) â–¶ï¸ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(vimuccati)
        of that | thus | of knowing | thus | of seeing | from effluent of sensual pleasure | too | mind | released from | from effluent of being | too | mind | released from | from effluent of ignorance | too | mind | released from
        When knowing and seeing thus, the mind is released from the effluents of sensual pleasures, being and ignorance.

        yaá¹ƒ kiÃ± ci samudayadhammaá¹ƒ, sabban taá¹ƒ nirodhadhammaá¹ƒ (D II 41,20-21) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(ya) ğŸ”¼(kiÃ±ci) | ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(samudayadhamma) , ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(sabbanta) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(nirodhadhamma)
        whatever | something | subject to arising, entire | subject to ceasing
        Whatever arises, will cease completely.

        n’ atthi jÄtassa amaraá¹‡aá¹ƒ (D II 246,16)
        â–¶ï¸ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(natthi) ğŸš¹â‘¥â¨€(jÄta) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(amaraá¹‡a)
        is not | of born | immortality
        One who has been born is not immortal.

        Translate into Pali

        What I know, you know what you know, I know (D I 88,8-10)
        Yaá¹ƒ ahaá¹ƒ jÄnÄmi, taá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ jÄnÄsi; yaá¹ƒ tvaá¹ƒ jÄnÄsi, taá¹ƒ ahaá¹ƒ jÄnÄmi.

        I learn the saying of the fortunate one (D I 184,30-31)
        Ahaá¹ƒ Bhagavato bhÄsitaá¹ƒ (or vacanaá¹ƒ) ÄjÄnÄmi.

        He will grasp what I explain (fut.) quickly (D II 150,16-17)
        Yaá¹ƒ ahaá¹ƒ vyÄkarissÄmi, taá¹ƒ khippam eva ÄjÄnissati.

        After some time he hears the excellent doctrine (D II 214,11-12)
        So aparena samayena ariyaá¹ƒ dhammaá¹ƒ sunÄti.

        The fortunate one, taking robe-and-bowl, entered RÄjagaha for alms (D III 180,9-10)
        Â BhagavÄ pattacÄ«varaá¹ƒ ÄdÄya RÄjagahaá¹ƒ piá¹‡á¸Äya pÄvisi.

        Stop! Ananda, don’t grieve (D II 144,10)
        Alaá¹ƒ Ä€nanda, mÄ paridevesi.

        He understands that (use direct speech) these beings (are) endowed with bad-conduct-of-the-body (D I 82,25-29)
        So pajÄnÄti: ‘ime sattÄ kÄyaduccaritena samannÄgatÄ’.

        Not-memorizing that speech, I left (D I 53,13-14)
        Taá¹ƒ vÄcam (or bhÄsitam or vacanam) anuggaá¹‡hanto pakkÄmiá¹ƒ.

        Why (is) this unexplained by the philosopher Gotama? (Cf. D I 188,32)
        KasmÄ idaá¹ƒ samanena Gotamena avyÄkataá¹ƒ?

        You (plur.) have gone forth from house to homelessness (D III 84,14-15)
        Tumhe agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajitÄ.

        6.13 - Answers to Warder Lesson 16

        Answers to A.K. Warder “Introduction to Pali” Lesson 16

        Passage 1

        PÄyÄsisutta DN 23 PTS 2.316â€“2.358 29.15-29.36 (D II 350,19 - 351,21)

        te yen’ aÃ±Ã±ataraá¹ƒ gÄmapadaá¹ƒ ten’ upasaá¹ƒkamiá¹ƒsu. tatth’ addasaá¹ƒsu pahÅ«taá¹ƒ khomaá¹ƒ chaá¸á¸itaá¹ƒ. disvÄ. pe. pahÅ«taá¹ƒ khomasuttaá¹ƒ chaá¸á¸itaá¹ƒ. disvÄ. pe.         ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(ta) ğŸ”¼(yena) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(aÃ±Ã±atara) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(gÄmapaá¹­á¹­a) ğŸ”¼(tena) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(upasaá¹ƒkami)

        tatth’ addasaá¹ƒsu pahÅ«taá¹ƒ khomaá¹ƒ chaá¸á¸itaá¹ƒ.

        having seen â€¦ ditto â€¦ considerable | gold | discarded

        ğŸ”¼(disvÄ) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(sahÄyaka) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(sahÄyaka) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(Ämantesi): ğŸš¹â‘£â¨€(ya) ğŸ”¼(kho) ğŸ”¼(samma) ğŸš¹â‘£â¨€(attha) â¯ğŸ‘†â¨‚(icchati) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(sÄá¹‡a) ğŸ”¼(vÄ) ğŸš»â‘¡â¨€(sÄá¹‡asutta) ğŸ”¼(vÄ) â€¦

        Having seen, friend discussed to friend: â€œMate, for whatever purpose we will wish for hemp, or hemp thread, or â€¦â€

        sÄ«saá¹ƒ vÄ sajjhuá¹ƒ vÄ, idaá¹ƒ pahÅ«taá¹ƒ suvaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ chaá¸á¸itaá¹ƒ.
        ğŸš»â‘¡â¨€(sÄ«sa) ğŸ”¼(vÄ) ğŸš»â‘¡â¨€(sajjhu) ğŸ”¼(vÄ) , ğŸ”¼(idaá¹ƒ) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(pahÅ«ta) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(suvaá¹‡á¹‡a) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(chaá¸á¸ita)

        â€œâ€¦ or ear of corn, or silver, here is considerable gold discarded.

        tena hi samma tvaÃ± ca sÄá¹‡abhÄraá¹ƒ chaá¸á¸ehi, ahaÃ± ca sajjhubhÄraá¹ƒ chaá¸á¸essÄmi.
        ğŸ”¼(tenahi) ğŸ”¼(samma) ğŸ”¼(tvaÃ±ca) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(sÄá¹‡abhÄra) â¹ğŸ¤˜â¨€(chaá¸á¸eti) ğŸ”¼(ahaÃ±ca) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(sajjhubhÄra) â­ğŸ‘†â¨€(chaá¸á¸eti)

        â€œTherefore, mate, you must discard (your) load of hemp, and I will discard (my) load of silver.â€

        ubho suvaá¹‡á¹‡abhÄraá¹ƒ ÄdÄya gamissÄmÄ ti.
        â¨â‘ â¨€(ubha) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(suvaá¹‡á¹‡abhÄra) ğŸ”¼(ÄdÄya) â­ğŸ‘†â¨‚(gamissati) ğŸ”¼(ti)
        both | load of gold | having taken | will go | quote
        â€œBoth having taken a load of gold, we will go.â€

        ayaá¹ƒ kho me samma sÄá¹‡abhÄro durÄbhato ca susannaddho ca.

        Passage 2

        PÄyÄsisutta DN 23 PTS 2.316â€“2.358 25.3-25.13 (D II 347,9 - 348,1)

        bhÅ«tapubbaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±ataro sÅ«karaposako puriso sakamhÄ gÄmÄ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ gÄmaá¹ƒ agamÄsi. tatth’ addasÄ pahÅ«taá¹ƒ sukkhagÅ«thaá¹ƒ chaá¸á¸itaá¹ƒ. disvÄn’ assa etad ahosi: ayaá¹ƒ me bahuko sukkhagÅ«tho chaá¸á¸ito, mamaÃ± ca sÅ«karabhattaá¹ƒ. yan nÅ«nÄhaá¹ƒ ito sukkhagÅ«thaá¹ƒ hareyyan ti. so uttarÄsaá¹…gaá¹ƒ pattharitvÄ pahÅ«taá¹ƒ sukkhagÅ«thaá¹ƒ ÄharitvÄ bhaá¹‡á¸ikaá¹ƒ bandhitvÄ sÄ«se ubbÄhetvÄ agamÄsi. tassa antarÄ magge mahÄ akÄlamegho pÄvassi. so uggharantaá¹ƒ paggharantaá¹ƒ yÄva agganakhÄ gÅ«thena makkhito gÅ«thabhÄraá¹ƒ ÄdÄya agamÄsi. tam enaá¹ƒ manussÄ disvÄ evam Ähaá¹ƒsu: kacci no tvaá¹ƒ bhaá¹‡e ummatto, kacci veceto, kathaá¹ƒ hi nÄma uggharantaá¹ƒ paggharantaá¹ƒ yÄva, agganakhÄ gÅ«thena makkhito gÅ«thabhÄraá¹ƒ harissasÄ« ti. tumhe kho ettha bhaá¹‡e ummattÄ tumhe vecetÄ tathÄ hi pana me sÅ«karabhattan ti.

        bhÅ«tapubbaá¹ƒ aÃ±Ã±ataro sÅ«karaposako puriso sakamhÄ gÄmÄ aÃ±Ã±aá¹ƒ gÄmaá¹ƒ agamÄsi.
        ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(bhÅ«tapubba) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(aÃ±Ã±atara) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(sÅ«karaposaka) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(purisa) ğŸš¹â‘¤â¨€(saka) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(gÄma) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(aÃ±Ã±a) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(gÄma) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(agamÄsi)
        once upon a time | a certain | pig farmer | person | from oneâ€™s own | from oneâ€™s own | village | another | village | travelled
        Once upon a time a certain pig farmer travelled from own village to another village.

        tatth’ addasÄ pahÅ«taá¹ƒ sukkhagÅ«thaá¹ƒ chaá¸á¸itaá¹ƒ.
        ğŸ”¼(tattha) â†©ï¸ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(addasÄ) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(pahÅ«ta) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(sukkhagÅ«tha) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(chaá¸á¸ita)
        in that place | he saw | a lot of | dry dung | discarded
        In that place he saw a lot of dry dung discarded.

        disvÄn’ assa etad ahosi: ayaá¹ƒ me bahuko sukkhagÅ«tho chaá¸á¸ito, mamaÃ± ca sÅ«karabhattaá¹ƒ.
        ğŸ”¼(disvÄ) ğŸš¹â‘£â¨€(ta)ğŸ”¼(etadahosi) : ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(ima) ğŸ‘†â‘£â¨€(ahaá¹ƒ) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(bahuka) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(sukkhagÅ«tha) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(chaá¸á¸ita) , ğŸ‘†â‘£â¨€(ahaá¹ƒ) ğŸ”¼(ca) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(sÅ«karabhatta)
        having seen | for him | this thought occured : this | for me | a lot of | dry dung | discarded . for me | and | pig feed
        Having seen this thought occurred for him: â€œThere is plenty of dry dung discarded for me: feed for my pigs.â€

        yan nÅ«nÄhaá¹ƒ ito sukkhagÅ«thaá¹ƒ hareyyan ti.
        ğŸ”¼(yannÅ«nÄhaá¹ƒ) ğŸ”¼(ito) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(sukkhagÅ«tha) ğŸ”µâ¯ğŸ‘†â¨€(harati) ğŸ”¼(ti)
        what if I were to | from here | dry dung | take | quote
        â€œWhat if I were to take the dry dung from here.â€

        so uttarÄsaá¹…gaá¹ƒ pattharitvÄ pahÅ«taá¹ƒ sukkhagÅ«thaá¹ƒ ÄharitvÄ bhaá¹‡á¸ikaá¹ƒ bandhitvÄ sÄ«se ubbÄhetvÄ agamÄsi.
        ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(ta) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(uttarÄsaá¹…ga) ğŸ”¼(pattharitvÄ) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(pahÅ«ta) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(sukkhagÅ«tha) ğŸ”¼(ÄharitvÄ) ğŸšºâ‘¡â¨€(bhaá¹‡á¸ikÄ) ğŸ”¼(bandhitvÄ) ğŸš»â‘¦â¨€(sÄ«sa) ğŸ”¼(ubbÄhetvÄ) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(agamÄsi)
        he | upper robe | having spread out | a lot of | dry dung | havng brought | bundle | having tied up | on head | having lifted up
        He left, having spread out upper robe, having fetched dry dung, having tied up bundle, having lifted up on head.

        tassa antarÄ magge mahÄ akÄlamegho pÄvassi.
        ğŸš¹â‘¥â¨€(ta) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(antara) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨‚(magga) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(maha) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(akÄlamegha) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(pÄvassi)
        of that | along the way | road | great | unseasonal downpour | shed rain
        Regarding that, along the road, a huge unseasonal cloud rained heavily.

        so uggharantaá¹ƒ paggharantaá¹ƒ yÄva agganakhÄ gÅ«thena makkhito gÅ«thabhÄraá¹ƒ ÄdÄya agamÄsi.
        ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(ta) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(uggharanta) ğŸš»â‘¡â¨€(paggharanta) ğŸ”¼(yÄva) ğŸš¹â‘¤â¨€(agganakha) ğŸš¹â‘¢â¨€(gÅ«tha) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(makkhita) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(gÅ«thabhÄra) ğŸ”¼(ÄdÄya) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(agamÄsi)
        he | oozing | dripping | so much so | from tip of nail | with dung | smeared with | load of dung | holding | travelled
        Holding load of dung, he travelled, smeared with so much dung oozing and dripping from tip of nails.

        tam enaá¹ƒ manussÄ disvÄ evam Ähaá¹ƒsu: kacci no tvaá¹ƒ bhaá¹‡e ummatto, kacci veceto, kathaá¹ƒ hi nÄma uggharantaá¹ƒ paggharantaá¹ƒ yÄva, agganakhÄ gÅ«thena makkhito gÅ«thabhÄraá¹ƒ harissasÄ« ti.
        ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(ta) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(eta) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(manussa) ğŸ”¼(disvÄ) ğŸ”¼(evamÄhaá¹ƒsu) : ğŸ”¼(kacci no) ğŸ¤˜â‘ â¨€(tvaá¹ƒ) ğŸ”¼(bhaá¹‡e) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(ummatta) ğŸ”¼(kacci) ğŸ”¼(veceto) ğŸ”¼(kathaá¹ƒ) ğŸ”¼(hi) ğŸ”¼(nÄma) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(uggharanta) ğŸš»â‘¡â¨€(paggharanta) ğŸ”¼(yÄva) ğŸš¹â‘¤â¨€(agganakha) ğŸš¹â‘¢â¨€(gÅ«tha) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(makkhita) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(gÅ«thabhÄra) â­ğŸ¤˜â¨€(harati) ğŸ”¼(ti)
        that | this | people | having seen | they said this : I wonder | no | I say, look here | mad , I wonder | daft , whatâ€™s the reason | certainly | truly | oozing | dripping | so much so | from tip of nail | with dung | smeared with | load of dung | you will take | quote
        People having seen that person said this: â€œI say, I wonder if you are not mad, I wonder if you are daft, whatâ€™s the reason you will take away the load of dung, surely you are smeared with dung oozing and dripping from tip of the nails.â€

        tumhe kho ettha bhaá¹‡e ummattÄ tumhe vecetÄ tathÄ hi pana me sÅ«karabhattan ti.
        ğŸ¤˜â‘ â¨‚(tvaá¹ƒ) ğŸ”¼(kho) ğŸ”¼(ettha) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(ummatta) ğŸ¤˜â‘ â¨‚(tvaá¹ƒ) ğŸ”¼(vecetÄ) ğŸšºâ‘¤â¨‚(tatha) ğŸ”¼(pana) ğŸ‘†â‘£â¨€(ahaá¹ƒ) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(sÅ«karabhatta) ğŸ”¼(ti)
        you | indeed | in this case | mad | actually | but | for me | pig feed | quote
        â€œI say, in this case you all are mad, you all are daft, but actually it is feed for my pigs.â€

        BhagavÄ RÄjagahe viharati (D I 47,1-2)

        Blessed One | in RÄjagaha | dwells

        ime candimasuriyÄ parasmiá¹ƒ loke na imasmiá¹ƒ D II 319,23-24)

        kismiá¹ƒ vo viggaho, kismiá¹ƒ vivÄdo (D I 237,7-8)

        on what | with youse | quarrel , on what | dispute
        What is the quarrel amongst you, what is the dispute?

        evaá¹ƒ vutte aÃ±Ã±ataro rÄjÄmacco rÄjÄnaá¹ƒ etad avoca (D I 47,14-15)

        Translate into Pali

        Soá¹‡adaá¹‡á¸asutta DN 4 PTS 1.111â€“1.126 DN 4 8.2-8.5, 8.9-8.12 (D I 117,28 - 118,11):

        If (ce) now (va kho pana) I (put first) were to ask (optative) the philosopher Gotama a question, if (ce) in that connection the philosopher Gotama were to ask me thus: “Priest, this question, now (ca), should not be asked (future passive participle) thus, but (nÄma) thus, priest, this question should be asked”, this assembly would despise me for that (tena - place at beginning of clause): “The priest Soá¹‡adaá¹‡á¸a is a fool (put first), unintelligent, he could (sak(k), aorist) not ask (pucchituá¹ƒ - infinitive of pucch, Lesson 19; place at end of clause) the philosopher Gotama a question consequently (precedes ‘question’).”
        Ahaá¹ƒ ce va kho pana samaá¹‡aá¹ƒ Gotamaá¹ƒ paÃ±haá¹ƒ puccheyyaá¹ƒ, tatra ce maá¹ƒ samaá¹‡o Gotamo evaá¹ƒ vadeyya: “Na c’esa brÄhmaá¹‡a paÃ±ho evaá¹ƒ pucchitabbo, evaá¹ƒ nÄm’esa brÄhmaá¹‡a paÃ±ho pucchitabbo” ti, tena maá¹ƒ ayaá¹ƒ parisÄ paribhaveyya: “BÄlo Soá¹‡adaá¹‡á¸o brÄhmaá¹‡o avyatto, nÄsakkhi samaá¹‡aá¹ƒ Gotamaá¹ƒ yoniso paÃ±haá¹ƒ pucchitun” ti.

        If now (as before) the philosopher Gotama were to ask me (put first) a question, and I were not to satisfy (optative) (his: omit) mind (accusative) with (my) explanation of his question, if in that connection the philosopher Gotama were to say to me (accusative) thus: “Priest, this question, now, should not be explained thus, but thus, priest, this question should be explained,” this assembly would despise me for that: “The priest Soá¹‡adaá¹‡á¸a is a fool, unintelligent, he couldn’t satisfy (ÄrÄdhetuá¹ƒ - infinitive) (his) mind with (his) explanation of the philosopher Gotama’s question.”
        Maá¹ƒ ce va kho pana samaá¹‡o Gotamo paÃ±haá¹ƒ puccheyya, tassa cÄham paÃ±hassa veyyÄkaraá¹‡ena cittaá¹ƒ na ÄrÄdheyyaá¹ƒ. Tatra ce maá¹ƒ Samaá¹‡o Gotamo evaá¹ƒ vadeyya: “Na c’esa brÄhmaá¹‡a paÃ±ho evaá¹ƒ vyÄkÄtabbo, evaá¹ƒ nÄm’esa brÄhmaá¹‡a paÃ±hvyÄkÄtabbo” ti, tena maá¹ƒ ayaá¹ƒ parisÄ paribhaveyya: “BÄlo Soá¹‡adaá¹‡á¸o brÄhmaá¹‡o avyatto, nÄsakkhi samaá¹‡assa Gotamassa paÃ±hassa veyyÄkaraá¹‡ena cittaá¹ƒ ÄrÄdhetun” ti.

        6.14 - Answers to Warder Lesson 17

        Answers to A.K. Warder “Introduction to Pali” Lesson 17

        Passage for reading

        PÄyÄsisutta DN 23 PTS 2.316â€“2.358 23.3-23.10 (D II 342,20 - 343,7):

        bhutapubbaá¹ƒ mahÄ sakaá¹­asattho sakaá¹­asahassaá¹ƒ puratthimÄ janapadÄ pacchimaá¹ƒ janapadam agamÄsi. so yena yena gacchati khippam eva pariyÄdiyati tiá¹‡akaá¹­á¹­hodakaá¹ƒ haritakavaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ. tasmiá¹ƒ kho pana satthe dve satthavÄhÄ ahesuá¹ƒ ; eko paÃ±cannaá¹ƒ sakaá¹­asatÄnaá¹ƒ, eko paÃ±cannaá¹ƒ sakaá¹­asatÄnaá¹ƒ. atha kho tesaá¹ƒ satthavÄhÄnaá¹ƒ etad ahosi : ayaá¹ƒ kho mahÄ sakatasattho sakatasahassam. te mayaá¹ƒ yena yena gacchÄma khippam eva pariyÄdiyati tiá¹‡akaá¹­á¹­hodakaá¹ƒ haritakavaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ. yan nÅ«na mayaá¹ƒ imaá¹ƒ satthaá¹ƒ dvidhÄ vibhajeyyÄma ekato paÃ±ca sakatasatÄni.

        bhÅ«tapubbaá¹ƒ mahÄ sakaá¹­asattho sakaá¹­asahassaá¹ƒ puratthimÄ janapadÄ pacchimaá¹ƒ janapadam agamÄsi.
        ğŸ”¼(bhÅ«tapubbaá¹ƒ) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(maha) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(sakaá¹­asattha) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(sakaá¹­asahassa) ğŸš¹â‘¤â¨€(puratthima) ğŸš¹â‘¤â¨€(janapada) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(pacchima) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(janapada) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(agamÄsi)
        once upon a time / great / caravan / one thousand cars / from eastern / from country / to western / to country / left for
        Once upon a time, a great caravan with a thousand carts went to the western country from eastern country.

        so yena yena gacchati khippam eva pariyÄdiyati tiá¹‡akaá¹­á¹­hodakaá¹ƒ haritakavaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ.
        ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(ta) ğŸ”¼(yena yena) â–¶ï¸ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(gacchati) ğŸ”¼(khippaá¹ƒ) ğŸ”¼(eva) â–¶ï¸ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(pariyÄdiyati) ğŸš»â‘¡â¨€(tiá¹‡akaá¹­á¹­hodaka) ğŸ”¼(haritaka) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(vaá¹‡á¹‡a)
        he / wherever / go / quickly / only / uses up / grass, wood and water / green colour
        Wherever it goes, it really uses up fresh grass, firewood and water quickly.

        tasmiá¹ƒ kho pana satthe dve satthavÄhÄ ahesuá¹ƒ ;
        ğŸš¹â‘¦â¨€(ta) ğŸ”¼(kho) ğŸš¹â‘¦â¨€(sattha) âš§â‘ â¨‚(dvi) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(satthavÄha) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚(ahosi)
        in that / indeed / however / caravans / two / caravan merchants / were
        In that situation however there were two caravan merchants in the caravans;

        eko paÃ±cannaá¹ƒ sakaá¹­asatÄnaá¹ƒ, eko paÃ±cannaá¹ƒ sakaá¹­asatÄnaá¹ƒ.
        ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(eka) âš§â‘¥â¨‚(paÃ±ca) ğŸš»â‘¥â¨‚(sakaá¹­asata) , ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(eka) âš§â‘¥â¨‚(paÃ±ca) ğŸš»â‘¥â¨‚(sakaá¹­asata)
        one | 100 | carts , one | 100 | carts
        one of 500 carts, another of 500 carts.

        atha kho tesaá¹ƒ satthavÄhÄnaá¹ƒ etad ahosi :
        ğŸ”¼(atha kho) ğŸš¹â‘£â¨‚(ta) ğŸš¹â‘£â¨‚(satthavÄha) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(eta) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(ahosi)
        after that / for those / for caravan merchants / this / was
        After that this thought occurred for the caravan merchants:

        ayaá¹ƒ kho mahÄ sakaá¹­asattho sakatasahassam.
        ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(ima) ğŸ”¼(kho) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(maha) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(sakaá¹­asattha) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(sakaá¹­asahassa)
        this / ğŸ’¡/ great / caravan / 1000 carts
        This is indeed a great caravan with a thousand carts.

        te mayaá¹ƒ yena yena gacchÄma khippam eva pariyÄdiyati tiá¹‡akaá¹­á¹­hodakaá¹ƒ haritakavaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ƒ.
        ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(ta) ğŸ‘†â‘ â¨‚(ahaá¹ƒ) ğŸ”¼(yena yena) â–¶ï¸ğŸ‘†â¨‚(gacchati) ğŸ”¼(khippaá¹ƒ) ğŸ”¼(eva) â–¶ï¸ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(pariyÄdiyati) ğŸš»â‘¡â¨€(tiá¹‡akaá¹­á¹­hodaka) ğŸ”¼(haritaka) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(vaá¹‡á¹‡a)
        that / we / wherever / go / quickly / only / uses up / grass, wood and water / green colour
        Wherever we go they use up fresh grass, firewood and water quickly.

        yan nÅ«na mayaá¹ƒ imaá¹ƒ satthaá¹ƒ dvidhÄ vibhajeyyÄma ekato paÃ±ca sakatasatÄni.
        ğŸ”¼(nÅ«na) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(sattha) ğŸ”¼(dvidhÄ) â¯ğŸ‘†â¨‚(vibhajati) ğŸš¹â‘¤â¨€(eka) ğŸš»â‘¡â¨‚(sakaá¹­asata)
        indeed/could it be / we / this / caravan / in two pieces / should distribute / from one / 5 / one hundred carts
        Perhaps we can divide this caravan from one into two pieces of 500 carts.

        Translate from Pali

        tena hi brÄhmaá¹‡a suá¹‡Ähi, bhÄsissÄmi (D I 124,19)
        ğŸ”¼(tena hi) ğŸš¹â“ªâ¨€(brÄhmaá¹‡a) â¹ğŸ¤˜â¨€(suá¹‡Äti) â­ğŸ‘†â¨€(bhÄsati)
        therefore / O Brahman / may you listen / I will speak
        Therefore, O Brahman, please listen for I will speak.

        dÄ«ghaá¹ƒ assasÄmi (D II 291,7)

        deeply / I breath
        I breath deeply.

        mÄ ekena dve agamittha (D II 45,32)
        ğŸ”¼(mÄ) ğŸš¹â‘¢â¨€(eka) âš§â‘¡â¨‚(dvi) â®ğŸ¤˜â¨‚(agami)
        do not / by one / two / you all went
        Donâ€™t go together (two must not go by one direction/way)

        disvÄ va mayaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ bhagavantaá¹ƒ Gotamaá¹ƒ gamissÄma (D I 151,4-5)
        ğŸ”¼(disvÄ va) ğŸ‘†â‘ â¨‚(ahaá¹ƒ) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(ta) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(bhagavant gotama) â­ğŸ‘†â¨‚(gamissati) having seen / only / we / that / Blessed Gotama / will go
        Only after having seen, we will go to that Gotama the Blessed One.

        devÄ sabhÄyaá¹ƒ sannisinnÄ honti (D II 225,10-11)
        ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(deva) ğŸšºâ‘¦â¨€(sabhÄ) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(sannisinna) â–¶ï¸ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚(hoti)
        gods / at assembly hall / seated together / are
        Gods are seated together at assembly hall.

        santÄnâ€™ eva nu kho saddÄni nÄssosi, udÄhu asantÄni (D I 152,25-28)
        ğŸš»â‘ â¨‚(santa) ğŸ”¼(eva nu kho) ğŸš»â‘ â¨‚(sadda) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(nÄssosi) ğŸ”¼(udÄhu) ğŸš»â‘ â¨‚(asanta)
        existing / really / ? / indeed / sound / he did not hear / 2nd part / non-existing
        Was the sound he did not hear existing, or was (the sound) non-existent?

        aham pana agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajissÄmi (D III 64,11-13)
        ğŸ‘†â‘ â¨€(ahaá¹ƒ) ğŸ”¼(pana) ğŸš»â‘¤â¨€(agÄra) ğŸš»â‘¡â¨€(anagÄriya) â­ğŸ‘†â¨€(pabbajati)
        I / but / from household life / to homeless state / will renounce
        However, I will renounce from household life to a homeless state.

        katame paÃ±ca (D II 85,14)
        ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(katama) âš§â‘ â¨‚(paÃ±ca)
        what/which / five
        Which Five?

        kÄmesu micchÄ na caritabbÄ (D III 62,18)
        ğŸš¹â‘¦â¨‚(kÄma) ğŸ”¼(micchÄ na) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(caritabba)
        to sensual pleasure / wrongly / no / should be practised
        (I) should not be wrongly living a life of sensual pleasure.

        yaá¹ƒ sukho bhavaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ sukhÄ mayam, yaá¹ƒ dukkho bhavaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ dukkhÄ mayaá¹ƒ (D II 233,7-9)
        ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(ya) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(sukha) ğŸš¹â“ªâ¨€(bhavanta) ğŸšºâ‘¡â¨€(ta) ğŸšºâ‘¡â¨‚(sukha) ğŸ‘†â‘ â¨‚(ahaá¹ƒ) â€¦
        whatever / pleasant / existence / that / pleasant / us â€¦
        Whatever is pleasant your honourable, that is pleasant for us, whatever is unpleasant your honourable, that is unpleasant for us.

        Translate into Pali

        Soá¹‡adaá¹‡á¸asutta DN 4 PTS 1.111â€“1.126 13.2, 16.4-16.5, 18.5-20.4, 21.5, 21.12 (D I 120,10 -124,10):

        Priests declare (one) endowed with these five characteristics a priest. (D I 120,10-11)
        â€œpaÃ±cahi, (bho gotama), aá¹…gehi samannÄgataá¹ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä brÄhmaá¹‡aá¹ paÃ±Ã±apenti;

        Of these five characteristics let us except class, for what will class effect (kar) ? (D I 120,32-34)
        ImesaÃ±hi, (bho gotama), paÃ±cannaá¹ aá¹…gÄnaá¹ jÄtiá¹ á¹­hapayÄma
        KiÃ±hi jÄti karissati?

        " Don’t you bother, let the priest Soá¹‡adaá¹‡á¸a discuss with me." When it had been spoken thus the priest Soá¹‡adaá¹‡á¸a said this to the fortunate one : â€œ Let the honourable Gotama not trouble, let the honourable Gotama be silent, I by myself (eva) will make a reply to them according to the doctrine." Then (add kho for emphasis) the priest Soá¹‡adaá¹‡á¸a said this to those priests : â€œ Sirs ! Do not speak thus : â€˜ His honour Soá¹‡adaá¹‡á¸a surely disparages class, disparages prayers, certainly his honour Soá¹‡adaá¹‡á¸a- is going over to the argument of the philosopher Gotama himself (eva),â€™ I do not, sir, disparage either class or prayers." (D I 122,19 - 123,2)
        tiá¹­á¹­hatha tumhe, soá¹‡adaá¹‡á¸o brÄhmaá¹‡o mayÄ saddhiá¹ paá¹­imantetÅ«â€ti.
        Evaá¹ vutte, soá¹‡adaá¹‡á¸o brÄhmaá¹‡o bhagavantaá¹ etadavoca:
        â€œtiá¹­á¹­hatu bhavaá¹ gotamo, tuá¹‡hÄ« bhavaá¹ gotamo hotu, ahameva tesaá¹ sahadhammena paá¹­ivacanaá¹ karissÄmÄ«â€ti.
        Atha kho soá¹‡adaá¹‡á¸o brÄhmaá¹‡o te brÄhmaá¹‡e etadavoca:
        â€œmÄ bhavanto evaá¹ avacuttha, mÄ bhavanto evaá¹ avacuttha:
        â€˜apavadateva bhavaá¹ soá¹‡adaá¹‡á¸o vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹, apavadati mante, apavadati jÄtiá¹, ekaá¹sena bhavaá¹ soá¹‡adaá¹‡á¸o samaá¹‡asseva gotamassa vÄdaá¹ anupakkhandatÄ«â€™ti.
        NÄhaá¹, bho, apavadÄmi vaá¹‡á¹‡aá¹ vÄ mante vÄ jÄtiá¹ vÄâ€ti.

        At that very (kho puna) time a young priest called Aá¹…gaka, a nephew of the priest Sonadaná¸a, was sitting (past participle and hoti) in that assembly. (D I 123,3-5)
        Tena kho pana samayena soá¹‡adaá¹‡á¸assa brÄhmaá¹‡assa bhÄgineyyo aá¹…gako nÄma mÄá¹‡avako tassaá¹ parisÄyaá¹ nisinno hoti.

        Do you see (3rd person), sirs, this young priest Aá¹…gaka, our nephew ? (make interrogative merely by inversion of agent and verb). Yes (evam), sir. (D I 123,6-8)
        (Atha kho soá¹‡adaá¹‡á¸o brÄhmaá¹‡o te brÄhmaá¹‡e etadavoca:)
        â€œpassanti no bhonto imaá¹ aá¹…gakaá¹ mÄá¹‡avakaá¹ amhÄkaá¹ bhÄgineyyanâ€ti?
        â€œEvaá¹, bhoâ€.

        Where (there is) virtue, there (there is) wisdom, where wisdom, virtue. (D I 124,2-3)
        Yattha sÄ«laá¹ tattha paÃ±Ã±Ä, yattha paÃ±Ã±Ä tattha sÄ«laá¹.

        It is reported (passive) that (â€”omit " that â€ and put the subject spoken of in the accusative â€” “specification of state “) in the world the supreme is of-virtue-and-wisdom. (D I 124,9-10)
        SÄ«lapaÃ±Ã±Äá¹‡aÃ±ca pana lokasmiá¹ aggamakkhÄyatÄ«â€ti.

        6.15 - Answers to Warder Lesson 18

        Answers to A.K. Warder “Introduction to Pali” Lesson 18

        Passage 1

        DN 23 27.3-27.17 (D II 348,19 - 349,7):

        bhÅ«tapubbaá¹ƒ dve akkhadhuttÄ akkhehi dibbiá¹ƒsu. eko akkhadhutto ÄgatÄgataá¹ƒ kaliá¹ƒ gilati. addasÄ kho dutiyo akkhadhutto taá¹ƒ akkhadhuttaá¹ƒ ÄgatÄgataá¹ƒ kaliá¹ƒ gilantaá¹ƒ disvÄ akkhadhuttaá¹ƒ etad avoca: tvaá¹ƒ kho samma ekantikena jinÄsi, dehi samma akkhe, pajohissÄmi ti. evaá¹ƒ sammÄ ti kho so akkhadhutto tassa akkhadhuttassa akkhe pÄdÄsi. atha kho so akkhadhutto akkhe visena paribhÄvetvÄ taá¹ƒ akkhadhuttaá¹ƒ etad avoca: ehi kho samma akkhehi dibbissÄmÄ ti. evaá¹ƒ sammÄ ti kho so akkhadhutto tassa akkhadhuttassa paccassosi. dutiyam pi kho te akkhadhuttÄ akkhehi dibbiá¹ƒsu, dutyam pi kho so akkhadhutto ÄgatÄgataá¹ƒ kaliá¹ƒ gilati. addasÄ kho dutiyo akkhadhutto taá¹ƒ akkhadhuttaá¹ƒ dutiyam pi ÄgatÄgataá¹ƒ kaliá¹ƒ gilantaá¹ƒ. disvÄ taá¹ƒ akkhadhuttaá¹ƒ etad avoca:

        littaá¹ƒ paramena tejasÄ
        gilam akkhaá¹ƒ puriso na bujjhati
        gila re gila pÄpadhuttaka
        pacchÄ te kaá¹­ukaá¹ƒ bhavissatÄ« ti.

        bhÅ«tapubbaá¹ƒ dve akkhadhuttÄ akkhehi dibbiá¹ƒsu.
        ğŸ”¼(bhÅ«tapubbaá¹ƒ) âš§â‘ â¨‚(dvi) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(akkhadhutta) ğŸš¹â‘¢â¨‚(akkha) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚(dibbi)
        once upon a time / two / gamblers / with dice / played/gambled
        Once upon a time two gamblers played with dice.

        eko akkhadhutto ÄgatÄgataá¹ƒ kaliá¹ƒ gilati.
        ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(eka) â‘ â¨€(akkhadhutta) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(ÄgatÄgata) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(kali) â–¶ï¸ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(gilati)
        one / gambler / come whenever / bad luck / swallows
        One gambler swallows (the dice) whenever bad luck comes.

        addasÄ kho dutiyo akkhadhutto taá¹ƒ akkhadhuttaá¹ƒ ÄgatÄgataá¹ƒ kaliá¹ƒ gilantaá¹ƒ
        â†©ï¸ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(addasÄ) ğŸ”¼(kho) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(dutiya) â‘ â¨€(akkhadhutta) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(ta) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(akkhadhutta) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(ÄgatÄgata) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(kali) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(gilanta)
        saw / indeed / 2nd / gambler / that / gambler / come whenever / bad luck / swallowing
        The second gambler saw that first gambler swallowing (the dice) whenever bad luck comes.

        disvÄ akkhadhuttaá¹ƒ etad avoca: tvaá¹ƒ kho samma ekantikena jinÄsi, dehi samma akkhe, pajohissÄmi ti.
        ğŸ”¼(disvÄ) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(akkhadhutta) ğŸš»â‘¡â¨€(eta) ğŸ”µâ®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(avoca) : ğŸ¤˜â‘ â¨€(tvaá¹ƒ) ğŸ”¼(kho) ğŸ”¼(samma) ğŸš¹â‘¢â¨€(ekantika) â–¶ï¸ğŸ¤˜â¨€(jinÄti) , ğŸš¹â‘¢â¨‚(da) ğŸ”¼(samma) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨‚(akkha) , â­ğŸ‘†â¨€(pajohati) ğŸ”¼(ti)
        having seen /gambler / this / said : you / indeed / friend / conclusively / wins , by offering / friend / throw dice / quote
        Having seen, the gambler said this: â€œFriend, you will conclusively win by giving the dice (to me), I will throw.â€

        evaá¹ƒ sammÄ ti kho so akkhadhutto tassa akkhadhuttassa akkhe pÄdÄsi.
        ğŸ”¼(evaá¹ƒ) ğŸ”¼(samma) ğŸ”¼(ti kho) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(ta) â‘ â¨€(akkhadhutta) ğŸš¹â‘¥â¨€(ta) ğŸš¹â‘¥â¨€(akkhadhutta) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨‚(akkha) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(pÄdÄsi)
        yes / friend / quote / that / gambler / of that / of gambler / dice / presented
        â€œYes, friendâ€ that gambler of the gambler presented the dice.

        atha kho so akkhadhutto akkhe visena paribhÄvetvÄ taá¹ƒ akkhadhuttaá¹ƒ etad avoca: ehi kho samma akkhehi dibbissÄmÄ ti.
        ğŸ”¼(atha kho) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(ta) â‘ â¨€(akkhadhutta) â‘¡â¨‚(akkha) ğŸš»â‘¢â¨€(visa) ğŸ”¼(paribhÄvetvÄ) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(ta) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(akkhadhutta) ğŸš»â‘¡â¨€(eta) ğŸ”µâ®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(avoca) : ğŸš¹â‘¢â¨‚(ima) ğŸ”¼(kho) ğŸ”¼(samma) ğŸš¹â‘¢â¨‚(akkha) â­ğŸ‘†â¨‚(dibbati) ğŸ”¼(ti)
        after that / that / gambler / dice / with poison / having treated / that / gambler / this / said : with this / indeed / friend / with dice / (I) will play
        After that, that gambler having treated the dice with poison, that gambler said this: I will play with this dice, friend.

        evaá¹ƒ sammÄ ti kho so akkhadhutto tassa akkhadhuttassa paccassosi.
        ğŸ”¼(evaá¹ƒ) ğŸ”¼(samma) ğŸ”¼(ti) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(ta) â‘ â¨€(akkhadhutta) ğŸš¹â‘¥â¨€(ta) ğŸš¹â‘¥â¨€(akkhadhutta) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(paccassosi)
        yes / friend / quote / that / gambler / of that / of gambler / agreed
        â€œYes, friendâ€ that gambler of the gambler agreed.

        dutiyam pi kho te akkhadhuttÄ akkhehi dibbiá¹ƒsu, dutiyam pi kho so akkhadhutto ÄgatÄgataá¹ƒ kaliá¹ƒ gilati.
        ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(dutiya) ğŸ”¼(pi kho) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(ta) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(akkhadhutta) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨‚(dibbi) , ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(dutiya) ğŸ”¼(pi kho) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(ta) â‘ â¨€(akkhadhutta) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(ÄgatÄgata) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(kali) â–¶ï¸ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(gilati)
        secondly / too / indeed / those / gamblers / with dice / secondly too / indeed / that / gambler / come whenever / bad luck / swallows
        For the second time, those gamblers played with dice. And for the second time, that gambler swallows (the dice) when bad luck comes.

        addasÄ kho dutiyo akkhadhutto taá¹ƒ akkhadhuttaá¹ƒ dutiyam pi ÄgatÄgataá¹ƒ kaliá¹ƒ gilantaá¹ƒ.
        â†©ï¸ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(addasÄ) ğŸ”¼(kho) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(dutiya) â‘ â¨€(akkhadhutta) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(ta) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(akkhadhutta) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(ÄgatÄgata) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(dutiya) ğŸ”¼(pi) â‘¡â¨€(ÄgatÄgata) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(kali) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(gilanta)
        saw / indeed / 2nd / gambler / that / gambler / secondly / too / come whenever / bad luck / swallowing
        The second gambler saw that first gambler swallowing (the dice) whenever bad luck comes for the second time.

        disvÄ taá¹ƒ akkhadhuttaá¹ƒ etad avoca:
        ğŸ”¼(disvÄ) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(akkhadhutta) ğŸš»â‘¡â¨€(eta) ğŸ”µâ®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(avoca) :
        having seen /gambler / this / said :
        Having seen, the gambler said this:

        littaá¹ƒ paramena tejasÄ
        ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(litta) ğŸš¹â‘¢â¨€(parama) ğŸš¹â‘¢â¨€(tejas)
        smeared / by the best / by poison
        â€œSmeared by the strongest poison

        gilam akkhaá¹ƒ puriso na bujjhati
        ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(gilanta) ğŸš¹â‘¡â¨€(akkha) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(purisa) â–¶ï¸ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(bujjhati)
        swallowing / the dice / person / no / aware
        The person swallowing the dice is not aware

        gila re gila pÄpadhuttaka
        â¹ğŸ¤˜â¨€(gilati) ğŸ”¼(re) â¹ğŸ¤˜â¨€(gilati) ğŸš¹â“ªâ¨€(pÄpadhuttaka)
        swallow! / damn you / swallow! / you bad cheat
        Swallow! Damn you, swallow! You bad cheat!

        pacchÄ te kaá¹­ukaá¹ƒ bhavissatÄ« ti.
        ğŸ”¼(pacchÄ) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨‚(ta) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(kaá¹­uka) â­ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(bhavati) ğŸ”¼(ti)

        Afterwards, there will be bitterness.â€

        Passage 2

        DN 26 2.1-7.16 (D III 59,1 - 63,16):

        bhÅ«tapubbaá¹ƒ rÄjÄ Daá¸·hanemi nÄma ahosi cakkavatti dhammiko dhammarÄjÄ … atha kho rÄjÄ Daá¸·hanemi vassasahassÄnaá¹ƒ accayena aÃ±Ã±ataraá¹ƒ purisaá¹ƒ Ämantesi. yadÄ tvaá¹ƒ ambho purisa passeyyÄsi dibbaá¹ƒ cakkaratanaá¹ƒ osakkitaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnÄ cutaá¹ƒ, atha me ÄroceyyÄsÄ« ti. evaá¹ƒ devÄ ti kho so puriso raÃ±Ã±o Daá¸·hanemissa paccassosi. addasÄ kho so puriso vassasahassÄnaá¹ƒ accayena dibbaá¹ƒ cakkaratanaá¹ƒ osakkitaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnÄ cutaá¹ƒ. disvÄ yena rÄjÄ Daá¸·hanemi tenâ€™ upasaá¹ƒkami, upasaá¹ƒkamitvÄ rÄjÄnaá¹ƒ Daá¸·hanemiá¹ƒ etad avoca. yagghe deva jÄneyyÄsi dibbaá¹ƒ te cakkaratanaá¹ƒ osakkitaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnÄ cutan ti. atha kho rÄjÄ Daá¸·hanemi jeá¹­á¹­haputtaá¹ƒ kumÄraá¹ƒ ÄmantÄpetvÄ etad avoca. dibbaá¹ƒ kira me tÄta kumÄra cakkaratanaá¹ƒ osakkitaá¹ƒ á¹­hÄnÄ cutaá¹ƒ. sutaá¹ƒ kho pana mâ€™etaá¹ƒ, yassa raÃ±Ã±o cakkavattissa dibbaá¹ƒ cakkaratanaá¹ƒ osakkati á¹­hÄnÄ cavati, na dÄni tena raÃ±Ã±a ciraá¹ƒ jÄ«vitabbaá¹ƒ hotÄ« ti. bhuttÄ kho pana me mÄnusakÄ kÄmÄ, samayo dibbe kÄme pariyesituá¹ƒ. ehi tvaá¹ƒ tÄta kumÄra imaá¹ƒ paá¹­haviá¹ƒ paá¹­ipajja. ahaá¹ƒ pana kesamassuá¹ƒ, ohÄretvÄ, kÄsÄyÄni vatthÄni acchÄdetvÄ, agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbajissÄmi ti. atha kho rÄjÄ Daá¸·hanemi jeá¹­á¹­haputtaá¹ƒ kumÄraá¹ƒ sÄdhukaá¹ƒ rajje samanusÄsitvÄ, kesamassuá¹ƒ ohÄretvÄ kÄsÄyÄni vatthÄni acchÄdetvÄ, agÄrasmÄ anagÄriyaá¹ƒ pabbaji. sattÄhapabbajite kho pana rÄjisimhi dibbaá¹ƒ cakkaratanaá¹ƒ antaradhÄyi. atha kho aÃ±Ã±ataro puriso yena rÄjÄ khattiyo tenâ€™upasaá¹ƒkami, upasaá¹ƒkamitvÄ rÄjÄnaá¹ƒ khattiyaá¹ƒ etad avoca: yagghe deva jÄneyyÄsi dibbaá¹ƒ cakkaratanaá¹ƒ antarahitan ti.

        atha kho rÄjÄ khattiyo dibbe cakkaratane antarahite anattamano ahosi. so yena rÄjisi tenâ€™upasaá¹ƒkami, upasaá¹ƒkamitvÄ rÄjisiá¹ƒ etad avoca: yagghe deva jÄneyyÄsi dibbaá¹ƒ cakkaratanaá¹ƒ antarahitan ti. evaá¹ƒ vutte rÄjisi rÄjÄnaá¹ƒ khattiyaá¹ƒ etad avoca: mÄ kho tvaá¹ƒ tÄta dibbe cakkaratane antarahite anattamano ahosi. na hi te tÄta dibbaá¹ƒ cakkaratanaá¹ƒ pettikaá¹ƒ dÄyajjaá¹ƒ. iá¹…gha tvaá¹ƒ tÄta ariye cakkavattivatte vattÄhi. á¹­hÄnaá¹ƒ kho panâ€™etaá¹ƒ vijjati yan te dibbaá¹ƒ cakkaratanaá¹ƒ pÄtubhavissaJ ti. katamaá¹ƒ panâ€™etaá¹ƒ deva ariyaá¹ƒ cakkavattivattan ti. tena hi tvaá¹ƒ tÄta dhammaá¹ƒ yeva nissÄya dhammaá¹ƒ mÄnento dhammaá¹ƒ pÅ«jento dhammikaá¹ƒ rakkhÄvaraá¹‡aguttiá¹ƒ saá¹ƒvidahassu khattiyesu anuyuttesu brÄhmaá¹‡agahapatikesu negamajÄnapadesu samaá¹‡abrÄhmaá¹‡esu migapakkhÄ«su. mÄ ca te tÄta vijite adhammakÄro pavattittha. ye ca te tÄta vijite adhanÄ assu, tesaÃ± ca dhanaá¹ƒ anuppadeyyÄsi. ye ca te tÄta vijite samaá¹‡abrahmaá¹‡Ä madappamÄdÄ paá¹­iviratÄ, te kÄlena kÄlaá¹ƒ upasaá¹ƒkamitvÄ paripuccheyyÄsi: kiá¹ƒ bhante kusalaá¹ƒ kiá¹ƒ akusalaá¹ƒ, kiá¹ƒ me kayiramÄnaá¹ƒ dÄ«gharattaá¹ƒ ahitÄya dukkhÄya assa, kiá¹ƒ vÄ pana me kayiramÄnaá¹ƒ dÄ«gharattaá¹ƒ hitÄya sukhÄya assa ti. tesaá¹ƒ sutvÄ yaá¹ƒ akusalaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ abhinivajjeyyÄsi, yaá¹ƒ kusalaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ samÄdÄya vatteyyÄsi. idaá¹ƒ kho tÄta taá¹ƒ ariyaá¹ƒ cakkavattivattan ti. evaá¹ƒ devÄ ti kho rÄjÄ khattiyo rÄjisissa paá¹­issutvÄ ariye cakkavattivatte vatti. tassa ariye cakkavattivatte vattamÄnassa dibbaá¹ƒ cakkarantanaá¹ƒ pÄturahosi. disvÄ raÃ±Ã±o khattiyassa etad ahosi: sutaá¹ƒ kho pana mâ€™etaá¹ƒ: yassa raÃ±Ã±o khattiyassa dibbaá¹ƒ cakkaratanaá¹ƒ pÄtubhavati, so hoti cakkavattÄ« ti. assaá¹ƒ nu kho ahaá¹ƒ rÄjÄ cakkavattÄ« ti.

        atha kho taá¹ƒ cakkaratanaá¹ƒ puratthimaá¹ƒ disaá¹ƒ pavatti, anvad eva rÄjÄ cakkavatto saddhiá¹ƒ caturaá¹…giniyÄ senÄya. yasmiá¹ƒ kho pana padese cakkaratanaá¹ƒ patiá¹­á¹­hÄsi, tattha rÄjÄ cakkavatti vÄsaá¹ƒ upagacchi saddhiá¹ƒ caturaá¹…giniyÄ senÄya. ye kho pana puratthimÄya disÄya paá¹­irÄjÄno, te rÄjÄnaá¹ƒ cakkavattiá¹ƒ upasaá¹ƒkamitvÄ evam Ähaá¹ƒsu: ehi kho mahÄrÄja, svÄgataá¹ƒ te mahÄrÄja, sakan te mahÄrÄja, anusÄsa mahÄrÄjÄ ti. rÄjÄ cakkavatti evam Äha: pÄno na hantabbo. adinnaá¹ƒ nâ€™ÄdÄtabbaá¹ƒ. kÄmesu micchÄ na caritabbÄ. musÄ na bhÄsitabbÄ. majjaá¹ƒ na pÄtabbaá¹ƒ. yathÄbhuttaÃ± ca bhuÃ±jathÄ ti. ye kho pana puratthimÄya disÄya paá¹­irÄjÄno, te raÃ±Ã±o cakkavattissa anuyuttÄ ahesuá¹ƒ… dakkhiá¹‡am disaá¹ƒ pavatti. pe. pacchimaá¹ƒ. pe. uttaraá¹ƒ. pe. ye kho pana uttarÄya disÄya paá¹­irÄjÄno, te raÃ±Ã±o cakkavattissa anuyuttÄ ahesuá¹ƒ.

        bhÅ«tapubbaá¹ƒ rÄjÄ Daá¸·hanemi nÄma ahosi cakkavatti dhammiko dhammarÄjÄ …
        ğŸ”¼(bhÅ«tapubbaá¹ƒ) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(rÄja Daá¸·hanemi) ğŸ”¼(nÄma) â®ğŸ¤Ÿâ¨€(ahosi) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(cakkavattÄ«) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(dhammika) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(dhammarÄja)
        once upon a time / king / Daá¸·hanemi / named / was / wheel turning monarch / just / righteous

        atha kho rÄjÄ Daá¸·hanemi vassasahassÄnaá¹ƒ accayena aÃ±Ã±ataraá¹ƒ purisaá¹ƒ Ämantesi.

        And, my son, having approached, from time to time, whichever religious practioners that have abstained from intoxication and heedlessness, you should ask them about: â€œWhat, Venerable Sir, is skilful? What is unskilful? What have been done by me for a long time that is harmful and unpleasant? Or moreover what have been done by me for a long time that is beneficial and pleasant?â€

        tesaá¹ƒ sutvÄ yaá¹ƒ akusalaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ abhinivajjeyyÄsi, yaá¹ƒ kusalaá¹ƒ taá¹ƒ samÄdÄya vatteyyÄsi.
        ğŸš¹â‘¥â¨‚(ta) ğŸ”¼(sutvÄ) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(ya) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(akusala) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(ta) â¯ğŸ¤˜â¨€(abhinivajjeti) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(ya) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(kusala) ğŸš»â‘ â¨€(ta) ğŸ”¼(samÄdÄya) â¯ğŸ¤˜â¨€(vattati) ğŸš¹â‘¥â¨€(ima)

        â€œHaving heard that (response), you should remove anything unskilful and continue or take up anything skilful.â€

        And next, at whatever place the comet planted itself, in that place the wheel turning king went towards and took residence, together with an army of four divisions, elephants, chariots and infantry.

        Translate from Pali

        1. brÄhmaá¹‡o va seá¹­á¹­ho vaá¹‡á¹‡o (D III 81,10-11)
          ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(brÄhmaá¹‡a) ğŸ”¼(va) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(seá¹­á¹­ha) ğŸš¹â‘ â¨€(vaá¹‡á¹‡a)

          Only the brahmin caste is supreme.

        2. purisena purisaá¹ƒ karitvÄ khattiyÄ va seá¹­á¹­hÄ hÄ«nÄ brÄhmaá¹‡Ä (D I 98,8-9)
